questions.text: Which of the following is the gold standard treatment for the condition shown in the image?
questions.solution:
The gold standard for the treatment of varicose veins is endothermal ablation. The given image shows tortuous dilated veins suggestive of varicose veins.

The management of varicose veins is as follows:

Incompetence Management
Great saphenous vein (GSV) and saphenofemoral (SFJ) 
  • Endothermal ablation (gold standard treatment for varicose veins). It includes:
  • Endovenous laser ablation (EVLA)
  • Radiofrequency ablation (RFA)
  • Trendelenburg procedure (Flush Ligation of Saphenofemoral Junction (SFJ) after ligation of 6 tributaries) ± stripping (retrogradely up to the knee, to prevent saphenous nerve injury.)     
Short saphenous vein (SSJ) and saphenopopliteal (SPJ)
  • Flush ligation of SPJ 
  • Endothermal ablation
  • Endovenous laser ablation (EVLA)
  • Radiofrequency ablation (RFA)
Perforator 
  • Dodd and Crockett surgery - Multiple subfascial ligations
  • Subfascial endoscopic perforator surgery (SEPS) - smaller incision, so cosmetically better
  • Endothermal ablation:
  • Endovenous laser ablation (EVLA)
  • Radiofrequency ablation (RFA)

New treatment modalities:

  • Foam sclerotherapy - The Tessari method is a widely used method to prepare foam for sclerotherapy. Sclerosant: air ratio taken is 1:3 or 1:4
  • Endovenous glue therapy - endoluminal application of cyanoacrylate adhesive 
  • Transilluminated powered phlebectomy

 

Option B: Injection sclerotherapy: In this technique, a detergent is injected directly into the veins.

  • Most commonly used sclerosant is Sodium tetradecyl sulfate.
  • The detergent causes endothelial damage leading to thrombosis, fibrosis, and obliteration (sclerosis) of veins.
  • Injection sclerotherapy alone can be successful in varicose veins <3 mm in diameter and in telangiectatic vessels.
  • Complications from sclerotherapy include allergic reaction, local hyperpigmentation, air embolism, stroke and pain at the site of injection.

Option C: Phlebectomy -Small stab incisions are made to revert the reflux by occluding the refluxing tributaries of the veins.

Option D: Saphenous vein ligation and stripping is the preferred therapy for patients with GSVs of very large diameter (>2 cm).

Related Pearl: Classification of Chronic Lower Extremity Venous Disease

to chronic venous disease

*The descriptor A (asymptomatic) or S (symptomatic) is placed after the C clinical class.

Telangiectases are less than 1 mm, reticular veins are between 1 and 3 mm, and varicose veins are greater than 3 mm measured in the upright position.

questions.text: A young man presented with painful lesions as shown in the image below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above image shows confluent, red, pustular lesions in a single dermatome associated with severe pain is suggestive of herpes zoster or shingles. 

Initial infection with the virus causes chickenpox, associated with disseminated vesicular rash and fever. Upon resolution of the acute infection, the virus remains latent in a cranial nerve or dorsal root ganglia. Herpes zoster infection or shingles is a segmental eruption due to the reactivation of latent varicella-zoster virus from the dorsal root ganglia. An earlier infection with varicella is essential before zoster can occur. 

The first symptom of zoster is usually painful and it may be accompanied by fever, headache, malaise, and tenderness localized to areas of one or more dorsal roots. The mucous membranes within the affected dermatomes are involved. The patients are infectious, both from the virus in the lesions and nasopharynx. The thoracic dermatomes are most commonly affected in all ages. The posterior nerve roots and ganglia show inflammatory changes.

Zoster is a self‐limiting infection but it is painful and carries a risk of secondary infection and post‐herpetic neuralgia. Analgesia and treatment of secondary infections are sufficient for mild infections.

Indications for antivirals in VZV (Acyclovir 800 mg):

  • Painful zoster infections in adults
  • Facial zoster at any age
  • Immunocompromised

Other options:

Option B: The lesions of the molluscum contagiosum are shiny, white, and hemispherical. It is umbilicated with a central pore. It is caused by poxvirus. 

The below image shows the lesions seen in Molluscum contagiosum

Option C: Herpes simplex virus are classified into two major antigenic types,

  • Type 1 (HSV-1) which is classically associated with facial infections;
  • Type 2(HSV-2) which is typically genital.

Below image shows small, closely grouped vesicles on an inflamed base and is characteristic of Herpes Labialis or Cold sore.

Option D: Chickenpox is caused by a primary infection with the varicella-zoster virus. Most infections occur before the age of 5 but can occur in older children and adults. The lesions develop in 3-5 crops and are polymorphic (present at different stages in each site). In 2–4 days, a dry crust forms leaving a shallow pink depression which, in the absence of secondary infection, heals without scarring. It is non-contagious after the lesions have crusted. They have a typical dewdrop on rose-petal appearance.

questions.text: The process in the oxidation pond is ________________

choices.text: Aerobic during day, anaerobic during night
Anaerobic during day, aerobic during night

questions.solution:
The process in the oxidation ponds is aerobic during day, and anaerobic during night.

An oxidation pond is a method of sewage disposal that is used to treat both sewage and industrial waste. It is an open, shallow pool of around 1 – 1.5m depth with an inlet and outlet. It requires algae, certain types of saprophytic bacteria and sunlight.

The organic matter is oxidized by bacteria into carbon dioxide, ammonia and water. Algae grow by utilising these with the help of sunlight creating a balance. The oxidation ponds are predominantly aerobic during sunshine hours and some hours of the night. In the remaining hours of the night, the bottom layers are generally anaerobic. The effluent formed can be used for land irrigation or can be forwarded for further treatment.

questions.text: A 50-year-old factory worker was brought to the emergency room with complaints of headache, vomiting, and blurring of vision after he consumed local spirit. Which of the following is used for the treatment of his condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of methanol toxicity. Ethanol and fomepizole is used for the treatment of this condition.

Methanol poisoning is caused due to ingestion of illicit liquor which contains ethanol adulterated with methanol. Methanol is metabolized to formaldehyde and formic acid by alcohol and aldehyde dehydrogenases, respectively. The metabolites of ethanol are responsible for the toxic effects.

Clinically, patients present with headache, vomiting, abdomen pain, uneasiness, confusion, delirium, and coma. Formic acid specifically damages the retina and optic nerve and results in blurring of vision and blindness.

Elevated levels of formic acid and other organic acids result in metabolic acidosis in arterial blood gas analysis(ABG).

Treatment of methanol poisoning includes gastric lavage with sodium bicarbonate if the patient is brought within 2 hours of ingesting methanol to combat acidosis. Ethanol infusion since ethanol is preferentially metabolized by alcohol dehydrogenase over methanol and helps by reducing the rate of generation of formaldehyde and formic acid.

Fomepizole is a competitive inhibitor of alcohol dehydrogenase and the drug of choice for methanol poisoning. Folate therapy with calcium leucovorin reduces blood formate levels by enhancing its oxidation. Hemodialysis is used in severe cases of methanol toxicity.

Other options: 

Option B: Flumazenil is the inverse agonist of benzodiazepine receptors and is used for the treatment of benzodiazepine overdose.

Option C: N-acetyl cysteine is used as an antidote for the treatment of paracetamol poisoning.

Option D: Naloxone is a competitive opioid antagonist used for the treatment of opioid overdose.

questions.text: A 49-year-old male presents with recurrent episodes of watery diarrhea, dehydration, hypokalemia, and achlorhydria. Which of the following neuroendocrine tumors can be responsible for these symptoms?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of VIPoma.

Vasoactive intestinal peptide-secreting tumors (VIPomas) are neuroendocrine tumors that secrete excessive amounts of vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP). The condition is known as Verner–Morrison syndrome or WDHA syndrome.

WDHA stands for:

  • WD - Watery Diarrhea
  • H – Hypokalemia
  • A – Achlorhydria

Diagnosis can be made by the demonstration of an elevated plasma VIP level and the history of large-volume diarrhea.

Treatment includes correction of dehydration, hypokalemia, and electrolyte losses with fluid and electrolyte replacement. Long-acting somatostatin analogs such as octreotide and lanreotide are the drug of choice. 

Related Pearl: Pancreatic Endocrine Neoplasms

Endocrine neoplasm

Syndrome

Glucagonoma

Mild diabetes mellitus, a characteristic skin rash (necrolytic migratory erythema), and anemia

Insulinoma

Clinically significant hypoglycemia

Gastrinoma

Peptic ulceration often unresponsive to therapy and in unusual locations such as the jejunum

Somatostatinoma

Diabetes mellitus, cholelithiasis, steatorrhea, and hypochlorhydria

VIPoma

Watery diarrhea, hypokalemia, achlorhydria, or WDHA syndrome

Pancreatic polypeptide-secreting endocrine tumors

Present as mass lesions as even high plasma levels of this hormone fail to cause symptoms
  • Islet hyperplasia (previously known as nesidioblastosis) is seen in maternal diabetes, Beckwith–Wiedemann syndrome , and rare mutations in the β-cell K+-channel protein or sulfonylurea receptor.
  • In maternal diabetes, the fetal islets respond to hyperglycemia by increasing their size and number. In the postnatal period, these hyperactive islets may be responsible for serious episodes of hypoglycemia.

questions.text: A  male patient presented with a sudden onset tearing type of chest pain radiating to the back, shortness of breath, and nausea. CT chest image is given.What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of a male patient with tearing chest pain is suggestive of aortic dissection. Beta-blockers such as Labetalol should be given to all patients with aortic dissection and surgical repair is done after stabilizing the patient. So, option A is the correct answer.

Aortic dissection occurs when a tear or flap occurs in the intima or inner media of the aorta resulting in progressive separation of the layers of the aorta.

Risk factors for aortic dissection are:

  • Smoking
  • Hypertension
  • Atherosclerosis 
  • Hypercholesterolemia
  • Aortopathy, aortitis, bicuspid aortic valve, or preexisting medial degenerative disease.
  • Aortic injury during cardiac catheterization, surgery, endovascular aortic repair (Iatrogenic) 
  • Cocaine or amphetamine abuse 
 

The most typical presentation of aortic dissection is tearing chest pain. Other clinical features include dyspnea, nausea, vomiting, murmurs due to aortic valvular insufficiency, and shock. A discrepancy between the extremities in pulse, blood pressure, or both is the classic physical finding in patients with aortic dissection.

The dissection can extend distally down the aorta to involve the:

  • Renal arteries (renal pain and renal failure)
  • Mesenteric arteries (abdominal pain and bowel ischemia)
  • Spinal arteries (paraplegia, incontinence)
  • Iliofemoral arteries (leg pain, pallor, loss or reduced pulses, and limb ischemia).

The dissection may track proximally to involve the:

  • Head and neck vessels (syncope and focal neurological deficits)
  • Coronary vessels (cardiac ischemia, cardiac tamponade)
  • Aortic root (aortic regurgitation)

Delays in diagnosis and treatment of aortic dissection can have disastrous consequences.

Investigations in aortic dissection:

  • Transesophageal echocardiography can be done at the bedside in patients who are hemodynamically unstable; it can give information about flow in the true and false lumen and shows very high sensitivity for confirmation of the aortic dissection.
  • Currently, a CT scan is the initial best investigation for the diagnosis of aortic dissection in the hemodynamically stable patent. Additionally, it tells about the segments involved and the acuity, and complications of the dissection. The classic feature seen in the CT scan is a double-lumen aorta.

Treatment:

The initial management of patients diagnosed with aortic dissection is beta-blocker medication to control hypertension, along with pain management. The preferred beta-blocker drug is esmolol, a cardio-selective beta blocker. These reduce cardiac contractility and blood pressure. It can be used in patients with bronchospastic disorders. Labetalol, a non-selective beta blocker decreases systemic vascular resistance without impairing the cardiac output. Enalapril and other angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors can be used if there is decreased renal perfusion.

 Calcium channel blockers like diltiazem may be used IV if beta-blockers cannot be employed.

Once hypertension is controlled, definitive surgical repair of aortic dissection is done. Nitroprusside, a direct vasodilator is given after adequate beta-blockade is achieved. Definitive management is by surgical repair.

Types: 

  • Stanford type A (DeBakey types I and II) requires surgical intervention once the patient's blood pressure is stabilized.
  • Stanford type B (DeBakey type III) is best managed by antihypertensive drugs. Surgical intervention is indicated in complicated cases if the pain increases (signaling impending rupture) or when there is evidence of malperfusion of organs or neurological symptoms.

questions.text: Which vitamin deficiency causes xeropthalmia, a condition which causes dry eyes?
questions.solution:
Xeropthalmia which presents initially as dry eyes is due to a deficiency of vitamin A.

Related Pearl: WHO grading of Vitamin A deficiency

The term xerophthalmia is reserved to cover all the ocular manifestations of vitamin A deficiency.

Stage Features Pathophysiology
XN Night blindness Lack of rhodopsin
X1A Conjunctival Xerosis Conjunctival epithelial alteration, loss of goblet cells
X1B Bitot’s spots Conjunctival keratinization and plaque formation
X2 Corneal xerosis Corneal epithelial alteration
X3A Corneal ulceration/ Keratomalacia affecting <1/3rd of the corneal surface Liquefaction of corneal stroma
X3B Corneal ulceration/ Keratomalacia affecting >1/3rd of the corneal surface              -
XS Corneal scar              -
XF Xerophthalmic fundus Degeneration of the retinal pigment epithelium

The first symptom of xerophthalmia is nyctalopia.

The first sign of xerophthalmia is conjunctival xerosis.

The pathognomonic feature of xerophthalmia is the appearance of Bitot's spots.

Note:

Up to the level of Stage 2, the manifestations are reversible if treated with vitamin A supplements.

However, active conjunctival xerosis and Bitot’s spots begin to resolve within 2—5 days after supplementation. Most will disappear within 2 weeks, although a significant proportion of temporal lesions may persist in shrunken form and may therefore not be completely reversible.

questions.text:
What is the cause of LH surge?

FSH: Follicle-stimulating Hormone

LH: Luteinizing hormone
questions.solution:
Estradiol causes LH surge. Estradiol concentrations of 200 pg/mL for 50 hours are necessary to initiate this LH surge.

Phases of the menstrual cycle :

Follicular phase (days 0–14)

  • A higher FSH level at the beginning of this phase is responsible for the recruitment of the follicle cohort that contains the follicle destined for ovulation. A primordial follicle develops to the Graafian stage, with atresia of neighboring follicles.
  • LH receptors are up-regulated in theca and granulosa cells. During the mid-follicular phase, follicles produce greater amounts of estrogen and inhibin.
  • Estradiol levels increase and cause proliferation of the uterus.
  • FSH are suppressed by the negative feedback effect of estradiol and inhibin on the anterior pituitary.

Ovulation (day 14)

  • A burst of estradiol synthesis at the end of the follicular phase has a positive feedback effect on the secretion of LH (LH surge). There is a small preovulatory rise in progesterone concentrations generates an FSH level surge, which occurs with the LH surge.
  • Ovulation occurs as a result of the estrogen-induced LH surge.

Luteal phase (days 14–28)

  • Ovulation is assumed to have occurred if the progesterone level exceeds 3 nglmL on cycle day 21. Progesterone levels are high in this phase.
  • The corpus luteum begins to develop, and it synthesizes estrogen and progesterone. Vascularity and secretory activity of the endometrium increase to prepare for the receipt of a fertilized egg.
  • If fertilization does not occur, the corpus luteum regresses at the end of the luteal phase. As a result, estradiol and progesterone levels decrease abruptly.

Menses (days 0–4)

  • The endometrium is sloughed because of the abrupt withdrawal of estradiol and progesterone.

questions.text: Which of the following is a cause of exudative pleural effusion?
questions.solution:
Rheumatoid arthritis is a cause of exudative pleural effusion.

Pleural effusion refers to the pathological accumulation of fluid in the pleural space due to:

  • excess fluid formation from the interstitial spaces of the lung, parietal pleura, or peritoneal cavity
  • decreased fluid removal by the lymphatics

Light’s criteria can be used to differentiate between transudative and exudative pleural effusions. Exudative effusions will meet at least one of the following criteria:

  1. Pleural fluid protein/serum protein >0.5
  2. Pleural fluid LDH/serum LDH >0.6
  3. Pleural fluid LDH is more than two-thirds of the upper limit of normal for serum. 

Related Pearl: Types of pleural effusion

Transudative Pleural effusion

  • Congestive heart failure
  • Cirrhosis
  • Nephrotic syndrome
  • Peritoneal dialysis
  • Superior vena cava obstruction
  • Myxedema 
  • Urinothorax

Exudative Pleural effusion 

  • Neoplastic disease: metastatic disease and mesothelioma
  • Infectious disease
  • Pulmonary embolization
  • GI: Esophageal perforation, pancreatic disease, intraabdominal abscess etc.,
  • Collagen vascular disease: SLE, rheumatoid pleuritis, Wegener's, Churg Strauss syndrome etc.,
  • Post coronary bypass surgery
  • Asbestos exposure
  • Sarcoidosis
  • Drug-induced pleural disease: nitrofurantoin, dantrolene, bromocriptine, amiodarone etc.,
  • Radiation therapy
  • Hemothorax
  • Chylothorax

questions.text: Sickness absenteeism of workers in the industry is used to evaluate__________
questions.solution:
Sickness absenteeism of workers in the industry is used to evaluate the health of the workers.

Sickness absenteeism refers to employees' self-reported absence from work due to health problems. The apparent cause for sickness absenteeism may or may not be due to actual sickness. These include

  • Economic causes: reporting sick to avail a sick leave with pay
  • Social causes: obligations such as weddings, and festivals
  • Medical causes: due to occupational accidents
  • Non-occupational causes: nutritional disorders, alcoholism and drug addiction.

Absenteeism is an index used in industries to assess the state of health of workers and their physical, mental and social well-being. Interventions to reduce sickness absenteeism should focus on areas, such as periodic medical checkups, monitoring work schedules, improving employees’ job satisfaction, and reducing workplace stress.

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presents to the surgical OPD with a painless left inguinal reducible mass. On examination cough impulse is positive. After further investigations, the patient is diagnosed with an inguinal hernia. What is the surgical management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggestive of inguinal hernia which is managed with Lichtenstein mesh repair which is a type of hernioplasty.

Inguinal hernias can either be direct or indirect. The contents of a direct hernia protrude medially to the inferior epigastric artery. Whereas, the contents of an indirect hernia protrude laterally to the inferior epigastric artery. Despite the differences in origin, the management of both hernias is done by a Lichenstein repair.

A Lichtenstein mesh repair is currently one of the most frequently used methods for treating an inguinal hernia. It is done for the reconstruction of the inguinal floor in adults. It is an anterior tension-free mesh repair that reduces the chances of recurrence of a hernia. A piece of prosthetic nonabsorbable mesh is used to fit the canal to bridge the defect in this repair.

Other surgical methods used for the repair of a hernia are:

  • Bassini repair - It is done for the reconstruction of the inguinal floor in adults. In this method, a mesh is not used. It is associated with a high recurrence and is not used frequently now. It is used only in cases of hernial strangulation and peritonitis where the use of a mesh is not preferred. It is performed by suturing the transversus abdominis and internal oblique musculoaponeurotic arches/conjoined tendon to the inguinal ligament. 
  • Shouldice repair - It is a multilayered repair, where the posterior wall of the inguinal canal is strengthened by continuous sutures. It involves double-breasting of the transversalis fascia. It is associated with a very low recurrence rate.
  • Gilbert repair (plug and patch repair) - It is an extension of Lichtenstein’s original mesh repair and has now become the most commonly performed primary anterior inguinal hernia repair. In this technique, a cone-shaped plug of polypropylene mesh is used. It is deployed like an upside-down umbrella when inserted into the internal inguinal ring to occlude the hernia
  • McVay repair (Cooper's ligament repair) is used for the correction of direct inguinal hernia, large indirect hernia, recurrent hernia, femoral hernias (particularly suited for strangulated femoral hernias). In this method, the transversus abdominis aponeurosis is approximated to Cooper's ligament.
  • Stoppa-Rives repair - It is used for the repair of large, recurrent, or bilateral hernias. In this method, a sub-umbilical midline incision is given to place a large mesh into the preperitoneal space.
  • Herniotomy - It is used to treat inguinal hernia in a child which occurs due to the presence of a patent processus vaginalis. Therefore in herniotomy, the repair of the inguinal ring is not done

questions.text: A patient presents with urinary symptoms due to benign prostatic hyperplasia. Which of the following is used to manage the urinary symptoms in the initial stage of this condition?
questions.solution:
Tamsulosin is used for the management of urinary symptoms in the initial stages of Benign prostatic hyperplasia(BPH). It improves the urinary flow by inhibiting the smooth muscle contraction of the prostate thereby reducing the resistance at the bladder neck.

BPH is characterized by symptoms of urinary frequency, urgency, nocturia, incontinence, slow urinary stream, straining to void, urinary intermittency (stream starting and stopping during micturition), or hesitancy, splitting of the voiding stream, and terminal dribbling. Physical examination reveals a smooth enlarged and non-tender prostate. Lab investigations reveal a normal PSA (prostate-specific antigen). Diagnosis is made based on clinical presentation and a lack of lab findings suggestive of malignancy (elevated PSA). A biopsy is rarely indicated.

Conservative treatment is recommended for men with mild symptoms, flow rate >10ml/s, and good bladder emptying with residual urine <100ml. 

Medical management includes alpha-adrenergic blocking agents that inhibit the contraction of smooth muscle that is found in the prostate. Tamsulosin is an adrenoreceptor antagonist with receptor selectivity at α1A. It is used in the treatment of benign prostatic hyperplasia.

The other class of drugs is the 5α-reductase inhibitors, which inhibit the conversion of testosterone to DHT, the most active form of androgen. Finasteride is a 5α-reductase enzyme inhibitor. It is effective in the treatment of palpable enlarged prostate. These drugs result in a 25% shrinkage of the prostate gland.

Indications for surgical management:

  • Lower urinary tract symptoms that are refractory to medical therapy
  • Refractory urinary retention
  • Recurrent urinary tract infection (UTI)
  • Hematuria
  • Stone formation
  • Hydronephrosis, hydroureter with renal functional impairment

Surgical management involves the use of the transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP). Laser ablative techniques using holmium YAG can also be done. 

Related Pearl: Benign prostatic hyperplasia treatment

  • Static component: 5 alpha-reductase inhibitor [eg: Finasteride]
  • Dynamic component: Alpha 1 blockers [eg: Tamsulosin, terazosin etc]

questions.text: Which of the following procedures has the highest risk to cause the recurrence of duodenal ulcers?
questions.solution:
Highly selective vagotomy (HSV) has the highest risk to cause the recurrence of duodenal ulcers among the given options.

HSV retains the vagal innervation to the antrum, pylorus, and the remaining abdominal viscera while cutting off the vagal nerve supply to the proximal two-thirds of the stomach, which houses nearly all of the parietal cells. As a result, the procedure reduces overall gastric acid secretion by around 75%, and GI side effects are uncommon. However, HSV has not had great success treating type II (gastric and duodenal) and type III (prepyloric) gastric ulcers, possibly as a result of hypergastrinemia brought on by prolonged antral stasis and gastric outlet obstruction.

Option A: Resective procedures like gastrectomy have the least rates of recurrence but are less preferred nowadays due to higher rates of morbidity and mortality.

Option C: Unlike HSV, vagotomy and drainage is widely accepted as a successful definitive operation for complicated PUD, with lower rates of recurrence.

Option D: Gastrojejunostomy is a good choice in patients with gastric outlet obstruction or a severely diseased proximal duodenum.

questions.text:
Which of the following is not true about CHPS?

CHPS- Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis

choices.text: Caused by hypertrophy of longitudinal muscles
USG is very sensitive in diagnosing this condition

questions.solution:
Infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis is caused by the hypertrophy of circular muscles, not longitudinal muscles.

Infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (IHPS):

It most commonly presents with non-bilious projectile vomiting. It is common between 3 and 6 weeks of age. It is associated with hypertrophy of the circular muscle of the pylorus. This results in constriction and obstruction of the gastric outlet. First-born male infants are at the highest risk. 

Infants usually present with projectile, non-bilious vomiting. Clinically, an olive-shaped mass is palpable in the right upper quadrant or epigastrium. When the infant is given a test feed, visible peristalsis is usually observed moving from left to right (not from right to left), followed by projectile vomiting.

Infants with hypertrophic pyloric stenosis develop a characteristic metabolic abnormality i.e hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis with paradoxical aciduria. 

Ultrasound examination is the investigation of choice for this condition. Ultrasound examination confirms the diagnosis of congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (CHPS) in the majority of cases. The diagnostic criteria for pyloric stenosis is a muscle thickness of ≥4 mm and a pyloric length of ≥16 mm.

Cervix sign and Nipple sign are signs of congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis in USG. Double-layered hypertrophic mucosa protrudes into the stomach, creating the so-called Nipple sign. The sonographic appearance of the hypertrophied pylorus resembles that of the uterine cervix and is sometimes referred to as the cervix sign.

Management includes the correction of metabolic abnormality before the correction of the pylorus. The hypertrophic pylorus is surgically corrected by Ramstedt’s pyloromyotomy.

The image below shows the cervix and nipple sign seen in IHPS.

questions.text: A young sexually active female patient presented to the outpatient department with complaints of lower abdominal pain, fever, vomiting, and foul-smelling vaginal discharge. On examination, the body temperature is 103 degrees Fahrenheit, pulse rate is 109 per minute and there is abdominal tenderness. Cervical motion tenderness is present on examination. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in this patient is pelvic inflammatory disease(PID).

Pelvic inflammatory disease is characterized by inflammation of the upper genital tract including the fallopian tubes as well as the ovaries.

This disease is commonly seen in sexually active young women and is usually preceded by a sexually transmitted disease. Gonococcal and chlamydial infections are commonly associated with PID.

Patients present with lower abdominal pain, fever, vomiting, dysuria, dysmenorrhea, dyspareunia and vaginal discharge. The symptoms also vary depending on the causative organism. On examination, there is a fever of around 103- 104°F, abdominal tenderness, tachycardia, and pelvic mass. Chronic PID is associated with sequelae such as chronic pelvic pain, menorrhagia, ectopic pregnancy, and infertility.

Acute PID is diagnosed if uterine tenderness, adnexal tenderness, or cervical motion tenderness is present and other etiologies are excluded or unlikely. One or more of the following can be used to diagnose PID on the clinical findings:

  1. Oral temperature >38.3°C (101.6°F),
  2. Mucopurulent cervical discharge or cervical friability,
  3. Abundant WBCs on saline microscopy of cervical secretions,
  4. Elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) or C-reactive protein (CRP), and
  5. Presence of cervical N gonorrhea or C trachomatis

Other options:

Option B: Endometriosis is a condition characterized by ectopic benign endometrial tissue that occurs outside the uterine cavity. Patients present with dysmenorrhea, dyspareunia, menorrhagia, and infertility. There is no foul-smelling vaginal discharge or fever hence this option is incorrect.

Option C: Adenomyosis is seen in multiparous women >40 years. The most common symptom involves menorrhagia and dysmenorrhea. Per-Vaginal examination reveals symmetrical enlargement of the uterus corresponding to <12 weeks of pregnancy.

Option D: Migrating abdominal pain from the periumbilical area to the right iliac fossa is classic for appendicitis. The abdominal pain also causes nausea and vomiting. Other nonspecific signs of appendicitis include low-grade fever, abdominal tenderness, guarding, and rebound tenderness. 

Related Pearl: Organisms Responsible for Pelvic Inflammatory Disease

Sexually transmitted: Gonococcus, Chlamydia, Mycoplasma, Trichomonas 
Aerobes: Staphylococci , Streptococci ,E. coli
Anaerobes: Bacteroides fragilis, Peptococcus, Clostridium, Actinomyces (IUD)
Others: Tubercular salpingitis

questions.text: Hamman sign is seen in:
questions.solution:
Hamman’s sign can be elicited in pneumomediastinum. It is a crunching or clicking sound that is synchronous with the heartbeat and best heard in the left lateral decubitus position.

Pneumomediastinum:

The main causes of gas/air in the interstices of the mediastinum are

  1. Alveolar rupture, perforation or
  2. Rupture of esophagus/trachea/bronchi,
  3. Dissection of air from the neck or abdomen into the mediastinum.

Clinical features include severe substernal chest pain (may or may not radiate to the neck and arms) and subcutaneous emphysema over the suprasternal notch.

The examination may reveal subcutaneous emphysema in the suprasternal notch with Hamman’s sign.

Chest x-ray confirms the diagnosis. No treatment is usually required, but inhaling high concentrations of oxygen will help absorb the mediastinal air. Needle aspiration can be performed if mediastinal structures are compressed.

questions.text: Which of the following procedures is done with the instrument shown below?
questions.solution:
Pipelle aspirator (a) and Vabra (b) aspirator are shown in the image above which are used to obtain endometrial sampling.

Endometrial sampling using Pipelle aspirator - aspiration of the uterine cavity and sending the sample for histopathological examination. It is used as a screening test in menopausal women on HRT or tamoxifen.

Postmenopausal bleeding is defined as bleeding from the genital tract, more than 12 months after the last menstrual period in a woman not on hormone replacement. All postmenopausal women with unexpected uterine bleeding should be evaluated for endometrial malignancy since age is a significant risk factor for this.

Transvaginal ultrasound(TVS) is the first-line investigation. Endometrial sampling is indicated if:

  • The endometrial thickness is >4 mm
  • The endometrium shows diffuse or focal increased echogenicity (heterogeneity)
  • The endometrium is not adequately visualized on transvaginal sonography
  • The woman has persistent bleeding, as it can be a sign of endometrial cancer even when the endometrial thickness is less than 4mm.

The image below gives a summary of the evaluation of postmenopausal bleeding, as per the FOGSI guidelines.

Leech-Wilkinson cannula is used to inject dye in hysterosalpingography. The image below is that of a Leech-Wilkinson cannula.  

 
 

The instrument shown below is a Sim's uterine curette, used for endometrial curettage.

questions.text: A 29-year-old male patient presents to the OPD with a 10-year history of coarse facial features and progressive enlargement of the hands and feet. Laboratory evaluation revealed elevated IGF-1 and non-suppressible growth hormone levels after the 75 g glucose challenge test. A diagnosis of acromegaly is made. Which of the following drugs is preferred for the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Lanreotide depot formulation is useful in the management of acromegaly.

Acromegaly commonly occurs due to growth hormone-secreting somatotrophic adenoma. Increased secretion of growth hormone (GH) and insulin-like growth factor- 1 (IGF-1) results in acral bone overgrowth. Patients present with frontal bossing, increased hand, and foot size, mandibular enlargement with prognathism, and widened space between the lower incisor teeth. Soft tissue swelling results in increased heel pad thickness, ring tightening, characteristic coarse facial features, and a large fleshy nose.

The cardiovascular system has a significant impact on GH excess characterized by cardiomyopathy with arrhythmias, left ventricular hypertrophy, diastolic dysfunction, and hypertension. 

Other manifestations seen in growth hormone excess are obstructive sleep apnea and diabetes mellitus.

Serum IGF-1 levels and GH suppression test with oral glucose are useful in the diagnosis. The levels of GH do not reduce in response to the oral glucose load. 

GH-secreting adenomas are managed with surgery. Transsphenoidal surgical treatment is the preferred surgery. The preferred medical treatments include long-acting injectable somatostatin receptor ligand (SRL) depot formulations of octreotide and lanreotide as well as oral octreotide capsules. Another drug that is useful in acromegaly is pegvisomant. It is a growth hormone receptor antagonist and therefore, antagonizes the actions of GH. 

Other options: 

Option B: Terlipressin is a vasopressin analogue that acts selectively on V1 receptors and is used in the management of bleeding oesophageal varices and hepatorenal syndrome.

Option C: Ketoconazole is used in the management of Cushing's disease. Ketoconazole inhibits several P450 enzymes and effectively lowers cortisol levels in most patients with Cushing’s disease.

Option D: Leuprolide is a long-acting GnRH agonist. It is used as a palliation of carcinoma prostate, uterine fibroids, endometriosis, and precocious puberty. Side effects include hot flashes, decreased bone mineral density, vaginal dryness, and erectile dysfunction.

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the Gaisböck syndrome?
questions.solution:
Patients with Gaisböck syndrome do not have hypotension, but rather present with hypertension.

Gaisböck syndrome is a stress polycythemia where affected individuals are usually hypertensive, obese, and anxious. They have a high hematocrit, low plasma volume, normal leukocyte counts, and no splenomegaly (differentiating them from polycythemia vera).

The plasma volume is therefore used to differentiate relative polycythemia where there is a reduction in plasma volume from absolute polycythemia, which is due to an absolute increase in red cell mass.

Polycythemia denotes an abnormally high red cell count, usually with a corresponding increase in the hemoglobin level (> 16 ±2 g/dL). It is 2 types:

Causes of relative polycythemia include:

  • Dehydration - deprivation of water, prolonged vomiting or diarrhea, excessive use of diuretics
  • Gaisböck syndrome 

Causes of absolute polycythemia include:

  • Primary - intrinsic abnormality of hematopoietic precursors 
    • Polycythemia vera
    • Inherited erythropoietin receptor mutations
  • Secondary - red cell progenitors responding to increased levels of erythropoietin
    • Compensatory due to cyanotic heart and lung disease, high altitude
    • Paraneoplastic erythropoietin-secreting tumors

questions.text: Ground-glass appearance on HRCT is seen in which of the following condition?
questions.solution:
Silicosis on HRCT shows a ground-glass appearance.

Silicosis is due to the inhalation of crystalline silicon dioxide (silica) seen in individuals employed in sandblasting or rock mining. Macrophages phagocytose inhaled silica particles, thereby activating and releasing inflammatory mediators (IL-1, IL-8) that cause fibroblast recruitment.

Microscopy reveals coalescent nodules of whorled collagen fibers surrounded by a peripheral zone of silica-laden macrophages. HRCT shows a “crazy paving” pattern due to interlobular septal thickening on the background of ground-glass opacity.

Given below is a HRCT image of silicosis:

Option A: Asbestosis - X-ray shows peripheral reticular opacities predominantly in the lower zones. It predominantly affects the lower lobes of the lung, in contrast to other forms of pneumoconiosis, which affect the upper lobes.

Option C: Anthracosis/coal workers' pneumoconiosis is a pulmonary condition seen in coal miners. The inhaled carbon pigment is engulfed by alveolar or interstitial macrophages, which accumulate in the connective tissue. Initially, it causes simple coal workers pneumoconiosis with little or no pulmonary dysfunction. With continued exposure, lung tissue undergoes progressive massive fibrosis which is called complicated coal workers pneumoconiosis. The upper lobes of the lungs are commonly involved.

Simple coal workers' pneumoconiosis appears as small round nodular opacities with an occasional appearance of reticular or reticulonodular opacities. Compared to silicosis, the nodules in CWP tend to have less well-defined margins and a more granular appearance.

Option D: Cotton dust causes byssinosis and can induce occupational asthma. It is characterized clinically as occasional (early-stage) and then regular (late-stage) chest tightness toward the end of the first day of the workweek-Monday chest tightness.

questions.text: Identify the rib highlighted in the X-ray.
questions.solution:
The above-marked area in the chest X-ray shows the posterior part of the 4th rib.

In the chest X-ray, ribs appear as light grey strips. The anterior part of the rib is more oblique and the medial part cannot be demonstrable as it ends with costal cartilage. The posterior part of the rib is more horizontal and the attachment of the rib with the vertebra can be easily made out.

 

The anterior(yellow) and posterior(red) ribs are highlighted in the image given below.

questions.text: In the Mental State Examination, (100-7=93) is done to examine which of the following mental function?
questions.solution:
(100-7=93) test in Mental Status Examination (MSE) is done to test concentration.

MSE is a structured way of observing and describing a patient's psychological functioning at a given point in time. It does not involve the scoring of a patient.

The main components of MSE are:

  1. Appearance and behavior
  2. Mood and affect
  3. Speech
  4. Thought process and content
  5. Perceptual disturbances
  6. Cognition
  7. Abstract reasoning
  8. Insight
  9. Judgment

The elements of cognitive functioning that are assessed are alertness, orientation, concentration, memory (both short and long-term), calculation, fund of knowledge, abstract reasoning, insight, and judgment.

Concentration is elicited in the following ways:

  • Starting at 100, the patient can be asked to count backward by 7 - (100-7) test
  • The patient can be asked to say the letters of the alphabet backward starting with Z.
  • Can be asked to name the months of the year backward starting with December.

When conducting the MSE or interpreting MSE findings, it is important to consider the cultural background of both the clinician conducting the MSE and the interviewee because behavioral patterns vary significantly across cultures (e.g., nodding your head as a sign of approval in some countries might signify disagreement in others)

Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE), also known as Folstein's test, is done out of a score out of 30 and is used to measure cognitive impairment.

Note: Mental Status Examination (MSE) and Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE) are two different assessment tests.

questions.text: In which of the following situations is ventouse delivery contraindicated?
questions.solution:
Ventouse delivery is contraindicated in preterm babies as it increases the risk of scalp avulsion or sub-aponeurotic haemorrhage.

Contraindications of vacuum delivery:

  • Any presentation other than vertex (such as face/breech)
  • Preterm fetus (less than 34 weeks)
  • Suspected fetal coagulation disorder
  • Fetal macrosomia (more than 4 kg estimated weight)

A vacuum extractor is an instrument used in operative vaginal delivery by creating a vacuum between it and the fetal scalp. 

The instrument consists of 

  • Suction cup
  • Vacuum generator
  • Traction tubing device.

The suction cup is placed on the fetal head at a point near the occiput called the flexion point, which is an imaginary point on the sagittal suture, located about 6 cm from the centre of the anterior fontanel or about 3 cm in front of the posterior fontanel. The flexion point is closer to the posterior fontanel as shown in the image below.

Related Pearl: Vacuum delivery- indications and contraindications

Indications of ventouse:    

Therapeutic-

  • Fetal distress in second stage
  • Maternal distress in second stage
  • Prolonged second stage
  • Deep transverse arrest and persistent occipitoposterior
  • High vacuum for second twin

Prophylactic-

  • Preeclampsia
  • VBAC
  • Cardiac defects
  • Anemia

Contraindications of ventouse:     

  • Preterm head
  • Face presentation         
  • Fetal coagulopathy
  • Fetal blood sampling

questions.text: An 18-year-old female patient comes with the following findings. Which of the following is pathognomic of the primary stage of this disease?
questions.solution:
Comedones are pathognomic of the primary stage.

Acne is a polymorphic inflammatory disease of the pilosebaceous unit, frequently affecting the face, back, and chest. Comedonal lesions are the earliest lesions of acne. They represent the keratin plugs of the pilosebaceous duct. When the keratin plug is inside the follicle, it is called a closed comedone (Whitehead). When the keratin plug is exposed to the environment, it gets oxidized by the air and turns black which is known as an open comedone (blackhead).

Precipitating factors include:

  • Lifestyle and environmental factors, diet, BMI, smoking and alcohol use, menstrual cycle, stress, and sleep deprivation
  • Drugs like corticosteroids, anticonvulsants, etc

The severity of acne according to lesion type and extent:

Type of acne Description
1. Comedonal

- Non‐inflamed lesions
- Open comedones/blackheads
- Closed (whiteheads) comedones
2. Mild

- Non‐inflamed lesions
- Inflammatory lesions <5 mm
3. Moderate

- Non‐inflamed lesions
- Papulopustular lesions
4. Severe

- Deep-seated inflammatory lesions
- Nodules and deep pustules
- Small nodules are >5 mm; large nodules are >1 cm
- Painful lesions with exudative sinus tracts, disfiguring tissue destruction, and scarring

Acne conglabata:

- Multiple-grouped comedones
- Papules, tender inflammatory nodules of varying sizes, suppurative and coalesce to form sinus tract
- Extensive scarring

Assessment of acne includes:

  • Leed's photometric grading scale
  • Comprehensive acne severity system (CASS)

Management: 

  • Mild acne - 
    • Comedonal acne - topical retinoid
    • Papular and pustular acne - topical retinoid and topical antibiotics
  • Moderate papular or pustular acne and nodular acne - oral antibiotic + topical retinoid ± benzoyl peroxide
  • Severe nodular and conglobate acne - oral isotretinoin
  • Other therapies -  topical niacinamide, salicylic acid, chemical peels, lasers, and photodynamic therapy
  • Novel drugs - 
    • Drugs that target both retinoic acid receptors -beta and -gamma - 
      • Adapalene
      • Tazarotene 
      • Tretinoin
    • Topical androgen receptor inhibitor - 1% clascoterone cream

Related Pearl: Global Alliance Algorithm for Acne Treatment

Global Alliance Algorithm for Acne Treatment

Image: Global Alliance Algorithm for Improving Outcomes in acne

BPO - Benzoyl peroxide

questions.text: A 60-year-old female patient presents with complaints of pain and swelling in the left wrist following a fall on an outstretched hand. On examination, dinner fork deformity can be noticed. What is the most likely displacement seen in this patient?

choices.text: Proximal and  ventral displacement of radius
Proximal and dorsal displacement of radius
Proximal and dorsal displacement of ulna
Proximal and ventral displacement of ulna

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Colles’ fracture in which proximal and dorsal displacement of the radius is most likely seen.

Colle's fracture is common in postmenopausal after a fall on an outstretched hand.

Clinical presentation -
The patient presents with pain, swelling, and deformity of the wrist. Tenderness may be present. The 'dinner fork deformity ' is the prominence on the back of the wrist and depression in the front. It is due to the dorsal angulation of the distal fracture fragment. The radial styloid process comes to lie at the same level or a little higher than the ulnar styloid process.  

 

Displacements(radius) that may be seen in Colles' fracture:

  • Dorsal tilt
  • Dorsal shift
  • Lateral tilt (Radial tilt)
  • Lateral shift (Radial shift)
  • Supination
  • Impaction of fragment
  • Proximal shift

Diagnosis -
Diagnosis is by X-ray.  X-rays show there is a transverse fracture of the radius at the cortico-cancellous junction. A dorsal tilt is the most common.

Management -

  • Undisplaced fracture - immobilization in a below-elbow plaster cast for six weeks
  • Displaced fractures - manipulative reduction followed by immobilization in Colles' cast in palmar flexion, pronation, and ulnar deviation.
  • Comminuted fractures -  transfixed percutaneously using two K-wires

Related Pearl: Named fractures of the upper limb

Colle's fracture: Extra-articular fracture of the distal radius with dorsal angulation of the distal bone fragment.

 

Galeazzi fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the lower third of the radius and subluxation of the distal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Monteggia fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the shaft of the ulna with dislocation of a proximal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Barton’s fracture: Intra-articular fracture of the distal radius.

 

Rolando's fracture: Intra-articular comminuted fracture of the base of the first metacarpal with a T or Y configuration.

 

Smith's fracture: Reverse Colles' fracture. Extra-articular fracture of the distal one-third of the radius with palmar or ventral displacement (Image below).

 

Chauffeur's fracture or the Hutchinson fracture: Fracture of the radial styloid.

Essex–Lopresti lesion: Fracture of the radial head with disruption of the interosseous membrane and distal radial ulnar joint ligaments.

Nightstick fracture: Isolated fracture of radial or ulnar bone.

questions.text: Which of the following is an inhalational agent of choice in a 10-year-old child?
questions.solution:
Induction agent of choice in pediatric anesthesia is sevoflurane.

Although both halothane and sevoflurane provide a smooth induction, sevoflurane appears to have a greater therapeutic index than halothane and is the preferred agent for inhaled induction in pediatric anesthesia.

Isoflurane and desflurane are airway irritants. Hence not used for induction of anesthesia as they can precipitate laryngospasm. These agents are used only during maintenance of anesthesia.

questions.text: A 70-year-old patient with a history of smoking presents with high-grade fever, cough, confusion, and diarrhea. Chest X-ray shows bilateral infiltrates in bilateral lower lung fields. On sputum gram stain, no organisms were detected. Laboratory results reveal Na: 126mEq/L, AST:62, ALT:56, RBS:112 mg/dl, serum bilirubin of 0.8mg%, and a positive HIV test. Which of the following organisms is responsible?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of the patient in the setting of an HIV infection, hyponatremia, and negative sputum gram stain is suggestive of legionnaire's disease. Legionnaire’s disease is caused by Legionella pneumophila.

They are found in lakes, streams, and other water bodies. Infection is mostly spread by inhalation of the bacteria from aerosols produced by contaminated air conditioners, humidifiers, nebulizers, etc.

It is mostly asymptomatic under the age of 40 years. Some risk factors for increasing the severity of the infection are smoking, older age and immunosuppression (as seen in this patient). It may present as a severe, rapidly progressive disease with high fever, chills, hypoxia, diarrhea, and delirium. On chest x-ray, patchy, often multilobar consolidation is seen. Pleural effusion may also occur. Initial lab findings include leukocytosis or leukopenia, thrombocytopenia, hyponatremia, elevated liver enzymes, and renal dysfunction.

A milder form of a clinical syndrome known as Pontiac fever, which is usually self-limiting and only has mild symptoms of fever, myalgia, and headache.

Microscopy of the sputum samples shows numerous leucocytes without any organism. Gram staining of the sterile sites like pleural fluid and lung tissues show faint gram-negative bacilli. They require a counterstain of basic fuschin as safranin stains the bacteria very poorly. They are a group of fastidious, aerobic gram-negative bacteria. They can be grown on a buffered charcoal yeast extract (BCYE) agar.

Diagnosis is established with the help of direct fluorescent antibody tests and BCYE culture specimens. Urine antigen tests and molecular assays may also be used.

The below image shows the Direct Fluorescent Antibody Test.

As L. pneumophila is an intracellular pathogen, antibiotics that reach high intracellular concentrations must be used.

Macrolides and quinolones are the antibiotics of choice and are effective as monotherapy. Alternatively, agents like doxycycline may also be used. B-lactams, monobactams, and aminoglycosides are not considered to be effective. The total duration of therapy is 10-14 days for immunocompetent hosts and up to 3 weeks for immunosuppressed patients. 

Other options:

The clinical scenario in the setting of hyponatremia and elevated liver enzymes, in the absence of sputum gram stain points more towards legionella as the underlying pathogen rather than Streptococcus, Pneumocystis, or Klebsiella.

questions.text: In which of the following cases is the drug given below contraindicated?
questions.solution:
The drug given in the image is Oxytocin, and it is contraindicated in the malpresentation of the fetus.

Uses of oxytocin:

  • To accelerate abortion and to stop bleeding following evacuation of the uterus
  • Used as an adjunct to induction of abortion along with other abortifacient agents (PGE1 or PGE2)
  • To induce labor by ripening the cervix before induction
  • Augmentation of labor
  • Following expulsion of the placenta as an alternative to ergometrine.
  • In active management of the third stage of labor
  • To minimize blood loss and control postpartum hemorrhage.
  • Oxytocin is involved in the regulation of preterm and term labor but the exact mechanisms are not fully understood.

Contraindications of Oxytocin-

  1. Hypersensitivity to the hormone itself or any part of its synthetic version 
  2. Vaginal deliveries that are in themselves contraindicated. These include:
  • Active genital herpes infection in the mother,
  • Vasa previa,
  • Complete placenta previa,
  • Invasive cervical cancer
  • Abnormal position (most notably including a transverse lie) 

Other options: 

Option B- Recent studies have shown that induction of labor with a modified oxytocin infusion is a safe and effective alternative for selected gravidas with heart disease where elective delivery is warranted. 

Option C- Oxytocin is used to induce or augment labor, including in some cases of premature labor when delivery is necessary. It's not contraindicated in this situation.

Option D- There's no specific contraindication for oxytocin use in hypothyroidism. Thyroid disorders don't typically interfere with oxytocin administration during labor.

questions.text: A cancer patient undergoing radiotherapy is given a dose of 1.8 to 2 Gy once daily for 5 days per week for a duration of 6 to 8 weeks. What is this type of brachytherapy called?
questions.solution:
Since the patient is given a dose of 1.8-2.0 Gy per day for 5 days a week, for 6 to 8 weeks, it is called Regular/Conventional Fractionated Radiotherapy.

Radiotherapy:

The total dose of radiation needed for a tumor is usually given as fractions over the entire treatment period as it maximizes the effects of the radiation on the malignant cells and minimizes the damage to the healthy cells.

The reasons for this are due to :

1. Re-distribution: Cells are more resistant to damage in the late S2 phase while sensitive in the M and G2 phase. Only some tumor cells will be in the sensitive phase of the cell cycle when the radiation is given. Hence, giving another dose at a later time helps in killing the other cells that were in the resistant part of the cell cycle, thus increasing the success rate of the therapy.

2. Re-oxygenation: Hypoxic cells are less sensitive to the indirect effects of radiation. The tumor cells which are closer to oxygen sources are killed first and in the intervening time, the other relatively hypoxic cells can improve their oxygenation so that the next fraction of radiation is effective on them. 

3. Repair: The ability to repair DNA is more for healthy cells than malignant cells and thus when a radiation dose has been received, the healthy cells repair their DNA faster than the malignant cells. The malignant cells whose DNA is not fully repaired are highly susceptible to the next dose of radiation.

Types of fractionation:

Standard Fractionation: Radiotherapy(RT) is given once daily for 5 days/week, not more than 2 Gy/fraction.

Accelerated Fractionation:(Option C) Any fractionation schedule that gives >10 Gy/week. Subtypes include:

  • Pure accelerated fractionation (2 Gy/fraction, 6–7 fractions/week)
  • Accelerated hypofractionation (>3 Gy/fraction)
  • Accelerated hyperfractionation (>1 fraction/day)

Hypofractionation: Increased fraction size, with or without a decreased number of fractions/week.

  • Stereotactic Radiation (SRS/SBRT/SABR): RT delivered with stereotactic localization techniques in five fractions or less.
  • Fractionated Stereotactic RT (FSRT): RT delivered with stereotactic techniques and more than five fractions.

Hyperfractionation: Decreased fraction size with more than one fraction per day (BID or TID). (Option B)

Concomitant Boost (CB): Two fractions per day with one fraction to a large field and the other to a boost volume.

Simultaneous Integrated Boost (SIB): One fraction per day with a higher dose to a boost volume and a lower dose to the large field.

Note: Brachytherapy(Option D) is a method of treatment in which sealed radioactive sources are used to deliver radiation at a short distance by interstitial, intracavitary, or surface application.

questions.text: Identify the type of homicide caused by smothering and traumatic asphyxia.
questions.solution:
Burking is a type of homicidal asphyxial death comprising of smothering and traumatic asphyxia. In burking, the assaulter throws the victim to the ground and kneels or sits on the chest of the victim preventing chest movements. He/she then covers the nose and mouth of the victim with his/her hands. 

Other options:

Option A: Mugging is a type of strangulation caused by holding the neck of the victim in the crook of the elbow.  Pressure is then exerted either on the front of the larynx or at one or both sides by the forearm and upper arm. In mugging, the attack is usually made from behind. Death occurs due to reflex cardiac arrest or asphyxia. 

The below image show strangulation by mugging.

Option B: Garrotting involves attacking the victim from behind using a ligature. The ligature is thrown around the unaware victim’s neck and then tightened by twisting it with a lever such as a rod or stick within the ligature. Earlier in Spain, garroting was an official method of judicial execution.

Option D: In bansdola, one strong bamboo or stick is placed across the back of the neck and another across the front. The victim is squeezed to death by tieing both ends of the stick with rope.

On examination, a bruise can be seen in the centre of the neck across the windpipe corresponding to the width of the stick or the substance used. A similar mark can be seen on the back of the neck if two sticks are used. 

Sometimes two sticks are used across the back and front of the upper part of the chest and squeezed forcibly. This causes laceration of the muscles, and rib fractures and interferes with respiration.

questions.text: An ICU patient who was already on endotracheal intubation now requires a tracheostomy. Which type of tube will you use?
questions.solution:
A cuffed tracheostomy tube is used in this patient for tracheostomy.

Cuffed tracheostomy is preferred in unconscious patients or patients on ventilators for a long time. When the cuff is inflated, it not only prevents the aspiration of pharyngeal secretions into the trachea but also prevents the leakage of air. The cuff should be deflated every 2 hours for 5 minutes to prevent pressure necrosis of the cartilage and trachea.

Metallic tubes(Option C) and uncuffed tracheostomy(Option A) tubes are not used too commonly because of the risk of displacement and aspiration of secretions into the trachea.

questions.text: All of the following changes occur in chronic starvation except?
questions.solution:
All of the following changes occur in chronic starvation except hyperthermia. Hypothermia is seen in chronic starvation.

The changes that occur in chronic starvation are as follows: loss of well-being, hunger, rapid weight loss, easy fatigue, lethargy, cachexia, anemia, hypotension, hypothermia, and polyuria. Edema of the lower limbs is seen due to hypoproteinemia. There is increased susceptibility to infections.

Blood sugar, cholesterol, protein, and chloride levels are decreased. Non-protein nitrogen and urea plasma free acids and ketone bodies are raised.

Death occurs due to exhaustion, brown atrophy of heart and intercurrent infection. Hypothermia and dehydartion may also play a role in  causing death.

Postmortem examination of internal organs reveals:

 Atrophied and darker muscles, brown atrophy of the heart, atrophy of the stomach and intestines, shrunken spleen, atrophied kidneys and decreased blood volume suggestive of anemia.  The gall bladder may be distended with bile.

Related Pearl: Internal Findings of Starvation

  • General – Fat is absent from subcutaneous tissues and muscles.
  • Brain – is pale and soft with congested meningeal vessels (at times).
  • Heart – is smaller due to brown atrophy. Heart chambers are usually empty, pale and collapsed, and show hypostatic congestion.
  • Gastro intestinal tract: Stomach is small, contracted, and empty. Mucous membrane of stomach and upper part of intestine is stained with bile. Large intestine has hard fecal matter.
  • Gall bladder - is unusually distended. It contains dark and filled with dry and inspissated bile.
  • Liver - shows necrosis
  • Spleen, kidneys and pancreas are small and shrunken
  • Urinary bladder - is empty

questions.text: Identify the part of the bowel in the barium study given below.
questions.solution:
The radiological image given above is barium follow-through of the small intestine and the portion marked is Jejunum.

On the supine radiological examinations, the jejunum characteristically occupies the upper part to the left of the midline, whereas the ileal loops tend to occupy the lower central or right part of the midline. This can be reversed in conditions like malrotation caused by small bowel obstruction.

Plica cirulares is most prominent in the jejunum and it gives the characteristic staked-up appearance of the jejunum in contrast X-ray, CT, or MRI.

The various parts of the bowel in barium follow-through is given in the image below.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presented with complaints of bone pain and abdominal cramps. Her family says she has a history of abnormal behavior. The consultant doctor arrived at a provisional diagnosis based on the clinical features. Which of the following would be the best investigation to arrive at a definitive diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of primary hyperparathyroidism. Parathyroid adenoma is the most common cause of primary hyperparathyroidism and the Tc99m sestamibi scan is used for diagnosis of parathyroid adenoma.

Clinical features of hyperparathyroidism:

  • Bones:
    • Pathological fractures
    • Subperiosteal bone resorption - 2nd and 3rd digits, most common in radial aspect
    • Salt and pepper skull
    • Osteitis fibrosa cystica or VonReckling Hausen’s disease
  • Stones
    • Multiple and recurrent renal stones - most common
    • Nephrocalcinosis
  • Abdominal groans - colicky due to pancreatitis
  • Psychiatric overtones - raised PTH causing CNS depression and psychiatric symptoms
  • Band keratopathy
  • Features of hypercalcemia - 
    • Vomiting
    • Confusion
    • ECG changes: increased PR interval, shortened QT interval

Nuclear medicine scanning with radiolabeled Sestamibi is a widely used technique. Sestamibi accumulates in parathyroid adenomas. This radionuclide is concentrated in the thyroid and parathyroid tissue but usually washes out of normal thyroid tissue in under an hour. It persists in abnormal parathyroid tissue. It is now regarded as the most accurate and reliable method for imaging the parathyroid glands.

Other options:

Option A: Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is not commonly used to image the parathyroid glands

Option B: Ultrasonography of the neck is a safe and widely used technique for the localization of abnormal parathyroid glands.

Option D: Multiphase CT imaging has become widely utilized to localize the disease. It gives both anatomical as well as functional information about the parathyroid glands. The disadvantage is the higher radiation dose when compared to others.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient underwent an emergency laparotomy for grossly contaminated peritonitis due to a perforated hollow viscus. On postoperative day 7, the patient developed signs of wound infection, including erythema, tenderness, and serosanguinous discharge. Subsequently, the wound showed evidence of dehiscence with exposure of underlying tissues. The patient's vital signs are stable, with no evidence of ongoing intra-abdominal sepsis. Considering the current wound status, what should be the most appropriate management strategy for the laparotomy wound?

choices.text: Vaccum assisted negative pressure wound therapy
Antibiotic irrigation of the wound followed by delayed primary closure
Initiating primary wound closure to reduce risk of further contamination

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of burst abdomen and the most appropriate management would be Vacuum-Assisted Closure (VAC) therapy.

Burst abdomen/Acute wound dehiscence is the mechanical wound failure causing separation of the closed abdominal wound associated with abdominal content evisceration. It usually occurs between the 5th and 8th postoperative days.

A sudden giving way feeling from the wound precipitated by bouts of cough, and pinkish serosanguinous discharge can be seen. Omentum or coils of the intestine are forced out of the wound.

Management includes delayed closure with initial mesh wrap or Bogota bag, placing a subcutaneous drain, suitable antibiotic therapy, and prevention of abdominal compartment syndrome as described above and VAC.

Vacuum-assisted closure (VAC) is a method of wound management, which uses negative pressure for spontaneous healing or by lesser reconstructive options. Negative pressure therapy stabilizes the wound environment by reducing wound edema and bacterial load,as well as improves tissue perfusion by angiogenesis and thereby stimulating granulation tissue formation. All this improves the possibility of primary closure of wounds and reduces the need for plastic procedures.The ideal pressure applied is 125 mm Hg. 

Indications of VAC therapy includes diabetic foot ulcers, bed sores,burn injuries,crush injuries, sternal/abdominal wound dehiscence, fasciotomy wounds and animal bites/frostbite wounds.

VAC therapy is contraindicated in patients with malignant wounds such as Marjolin’s ulcer,untreated osteomyelitis, presence of fistulae or necrotic tissue underneath the dressing.

Below is an image showing VAC.

Other Options:

Option B: Antibiotic irrigation followed by delayed primary closure is insufficient because it doesn't address the immediate need for ongoing drainage and decompression, and local antibiotics aren't effective for managing severe contamination.

Option C: Primary closure of the abdomen immediately after laparotomy would be dangerous in this scenario as it risks abdominal compartment syndrome due to ongoing edema and doesn't allow for adequate drainage of contamination; forced closure could lead to tissue necrosis and organ dysfunction.

Options D: Normal saline-soaked gauze dressing is inadequate because it doesn't provide active negative pressure, fails to effectively remove edema and inflammatory exudates, and requires frequent dressing changes that increase infection risk and nursing workload; additionally, it can lead to tissue maceration and doesn't promote wound edge approximation.

questions.text: An HIV-positive man presents with a high-grade fever. Examination reveals a positive Kernig's sign. CSF shows reduced glucose, increased protein, and increased leukocytes. A diagnosis of cryptococcal meningitis is made. What is the appropriate management for this patient?
questions.solution:
The appropriate management in this patient of cryptococcal meningitis is liposomal amphotericin B (LAMB)+ flucytosine

Cryptococcus is the leading infectious cause of meningitis in patients with AIDS. It generally occurs in untreated patients, with CD4+ T cell counts <100/μL. Most patients present with a picture of subacute meningoencephalitis. The CSF profile may show modest elevations in WBC or protein levels and a decrease in glucose. The CSF opening pressure is usually elevated (yeast colonies obstruct the free flow of CSF causing increased CSF pressure).

The diagnosis of cryptococcal meningitis is made by the identification of Cryptococcus neoformans yeast cells in CSF with India ink stain or by the detection of cryptococcal antigen using latex agglutination (CrAg).

Prophylaxis: Oral fluconazole when CD4+ T cell count is <100/μL.

Treatment:

  • Induction - Liposomal amphotericin B with flucytosine for at least 2 weeks, continuing with amphotericin alone ideally until the CSF culture turns negative.
  • Maintenance - Oral fluconazole until the CD4+ T cell count has increased to >200 cells/μL for 6 months in response to cART.

Other Options:

Option A: Vancomycin would be appropriate for bacterial meningitis caused by organisms like Streptococcus pneumoniae or methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus.

Option B: High dose fluconazole with flucytosine is used in cryptococcal meningitis, but they are not the first-line therapy for the induction phase. Fluconazole with flucytosine is typically used in the consolidation phase after initial treatment with amphotericin B, or in resource-limited settings where amphotericin B is not available.

Option C: Voriconazole while effective against many fungi, is not the drug of choice for cryptococcal meningitis. It's primarily indicated for invasive aspergillosis and other specific fungal infections.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presented with recurrent respiratory infections with thickened sputum. Chest X-ray showed bronchial wall thickening. He has been suffering from steatorrhea since birth. Which of the following is the first differential diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history suggests a diagnosis of cystic fibrosis. The gross image shows pus-filled bronchial air spaces and dilated bronchi extending into the periphery, typical of bronchiectasis. Therefore, the genetic defect and the associated complication are defective ATP-gated chloride channels and bronchiectasis respectively.

Cystic fibrosis (CF)/mucoviscidosis is an autosomal recessive disorder with a mutation in the cystic fibrosis transmembrane regulator (CFTR) gene on chromosome 7q. 

Following is the diagrammatic representation of the 6 categories of mutations seen in CFTR protein.

Systemic manifestations of CF:

Respiratory system:
1. Recurrent sino-pulmonary infections with pathogens including Staphylococcus aureus, Hemophilus influenzae, Pseudomonas aeroginosa, and Burkholderia cepacia.
2. Chronic cough with thick foul smelling/ sometimes bloody sputum
3. Lung manifestations like bronchiectasis, atelectasis, infiltrates, and hyperinflation.
4. Nasal polyps.
5. Clubbing.

Gastrointestinal system:
1. Intestinal abnormalities including meconium ileus, steatorrhea, and rectal prolapse.
2. Pancreatic insufficiency and pancreatitis.
3. Liver cirrhosis and prolonged neonatal jaundice.
4. Failure to thrive due to severe malnutrition.


Others:
1. Salt-loss syndromes.
2. Congenital absence of vas deferens leading to obstructive azoospermia.

Diagnostic tests:
1. Immunoreactive trypsinogen for newborn screening of cystic fibrosis.
2. Sweat chloride test: Increased chloride concentration >60 mEq/L is diagnostic.
3. Genetic testing for CFTR gene mutations is the gold standard and should be done for all cases.
4. Nasal transepithelial potential difference can be estimated in equivocal cases.

Diagnostic criteria:
Presence of

  • Clinical symptoms affecting at least one organ system (respiratory, gastrointestinal, or genitourinary) or
  • Positive newborn screening or
  • A sibling with cystic fibrosis.

Evidence of dysfunction of the CFTR gene by

  • Two positive sweat chloride test results obtained on separate days or
  • Identification of two CFTR mutations by genetic testing or
  • An abnormal measurement of nasal potential difference.

Management:

  • Mucus accummulation: Chest physiotherapy, aerosolized dornase alpha (recombinant DNase), N-acetyl cysteine, albuterol, corticosteroids, and hypertonic saline.
  • Respiratory infections: Antibiotics (oral for Staphylococcus and aerosolized for Pseudomonas).
  • Pancreatic insufficiency: Pancreative enzyme supplements.
  • Malabsorption: Nutritional supplementation along with fat-soluble vitamins (K, E, D, and A) and minerals.

Correction of the defect can be via:

  • Lumacaftor, an FDA approved drug that corrects the misfolding and reverts the Phe508del mutation defect
  • Ivacaftor potentiates CFTR channel opening and stimulates ion transport

End-stage pulmonary failure requires lung transplantation.

Other options:

Option A: Respiratory distress syndrome is also known as hyaline membrane disease. It occurs due to the decreased production and secretion of the lung surfactant. It is seen mainly in preterm babies. The radiograph will show the presence of low lung volumes, a diffuse reticular granularity of the parenchyma (ground-glass appearance), and air bronchograms.

Option C: Alpha-1 antitrypsin (α1AT) is a plasma glycoprotein synthesized predominantly by hepatocytes. α1AT deficiency is an autosomal-recessive disorder of protein misfolding. The liver is affected due to the accumulation of the misfolded protein within hepatocytes and presents as chronic hepatitis, cirrhosis, or hepatocellular carcinoma. Deficiency of α1AT protein results in excessive degradation of alveoli by neutrophil elastase, causing panacinar emphysema.

Option D: Malabsorption syndromes such as celiac disease, and tropical sprue present with diarrhea, steatorrhea, nutritional deficiencies, and weight loss. Histopathological examination of a duodenal biopsy would reveal villous atrophy, crypt hyperplasia, and increased intracellular lymphocytes.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of the stage of excitement in acute cocaine poisoning?

choices.text: Tingling and numbness in hands and feet
Dilated pupils , rapid pulse and sweating.

questions.solution:
Cocaine bugs are not a feature of the stage of excitement in acute cocaine poisoning.

Cocaine is obtained from the leaves of Erythroxylum coca. Cocaine can be administered by snorting, intravenous route, or smoking.

The manifestations of cocaine intoxication occur in two stages- the stage of excitement and the stage of depression.

In the stage of excitement, the features seen are dry mouth, dysphagia, tachycardia, tachypnea, hypertension, dilated pupils, and increased temperature. There may be a feeling of well-being, and the patient may be excited, restless, and talkative. This progresses into a calm, dull state. Neurological manifestations include exaggerated reflexes, tremors or convulsions, hallucinations, tingling, and numbness in the hands and feet.

The stage of depression is characterized by feeble respiration, excessive sweating, collapse, convulsions, and death. 

Chronic cocaine users may have the feeling of insects crawling on their skin or the presence of grains of sand under the skin giving rise to an itching sensation. This is known as cocaine bugs or Magnan's symptom. Ulceration of the nasal septum may be seen in chronic abusers who sniff cocaine. 

Treatment includes gastric lavage with warm water containing potassium permanganate, charcoal, or tannic acid if taken orally. When it is through the nose or throat, a wash with water is done. In case of intravenous intoxication, a ligature is applied above the site of the injection.

The antidote for cocaine intoxication is inhalational amyl nitrite. Other measures include control of convulsions, airway, and circulatory stabilization, administration of IV thiamine, and naloxone.
