questions.text: A patient presents with an endometrial thickness of 14mm with an adnexal mass. She has a history of complex endometrial hyperplasia with the presence of atypical cells. Which of the following is likely the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient with endometrial hyperplasia and an adnexal mass likely has endometrial cancer with metastasis to the ovaries.

For those who undergo TVUS (transvaginal USG) and have an EEC (endometrial echo complex) >4 mm, localized thickening, or an indistinct or nonvisible EEC, endometrial sampling is a reasonable next step.

Investigations for endometrial carcinoma include:

  • Endometrial aspiration biopsy is the first investigation for abnormal uterine bleeding, especially in females >35 years.
  • Dilatation and fractional curettage was the best diagnosis method, but now it is not used.
  • Hysteroscopy and biopsy: The investigation of choice for endometrial cancer.
  • Transvaginal USG is used as an adjunct to endometrial biopsy.
  • A Pap smear is not reliable to diagnose endometrial carcinoma. It is more useful as a screening tool rather than a diagnostic tool.

If symptoms of postmenopausal bleeding persist, imaging of the endometrial cavity should be performed with one or a combination of the following: TVUS, contrast sonography, or hysteroscopy.

Note: Surgical staging is the gold standard investigation for staging endometrial carcinoma.

Other options:

Option A: Struma ovarii is a type of highly specialized teratoma that contains only thyroid tissue. If it is functioning, it may lead to hyperthyroidism.

Option C: Polycystic ovarian disease is a disease characterized by menstrual abnormalities and hyperandrogenism in women of reproductive age. This condition has been linked to risk factors such as obesity and insulin resistance. Clinically these patients present with infertility and features of hyperandrogenism such as hirsutism and acne. On ultrasound, these patients have larger ovaries with an increased number of follicles. Multiple follicles that are peripherally located in the ovary can be seen on ultrasound. This is also called the string of pearls sign.

Option D: Immature teratomas such as solid teratomas of the ovary are solid and trabeculated. They also contain cartilage, bone, hair, and sebaceous material. There is no structural order. They are generally malignant. Grossly, they have a smooth external surface and are solid on sectioning. There may be areas of necrosis or hemorrhage.

questions.text: Which of the following airway devices helps in maintaining FiO2 of 0.25 to 0.60 irrespective of the patient's breathing effort?
questions.solution:
Venturi mask helps in maintaining FiO2 of 0.25 to 0.60 irrespective of patient's breathing effort.

Oxygen delivery devices can be broadly divided into low-flow oxygen devices (eg: nasal cannula, simple face mask, non-rebreathing mask) and high-flow oxygen devices (eg: venturi mask).

Venturi mask is a high-flow, fixed-performance oxygen delivery system and the highest oxygen concentration (FiO2) delivered is 60% at a flow rate of 15 L/min. It is useful with patients who require greater FiO2 such as COPD patients, where it is important to provide controlled oxygenation. It is available in different colors, with the green valve venturi mask providing 60% FiO2. 

Color of Venturi valve FiO2 (%) Flow rate 
(L/min)
Blue 24  2
White 28  4
Orange 31  6
Yellow 35  8
Red 40  10
Green 60  15
Oxygen delivery devices Flow rate (liter/min)  Approximate FiO2
Nasal cannula  1-6  0.24-0.44 
Simple face mask  6-10 0.40-0.60
Non-rebreathing mask 10-15 0.90-1.00 
Venturi mask  2-15  0.24-0.60

Other options:

Option A: The nasal cannula is a low-flow variable performance oxygen delivery system that can provide a maximum inspired oxygen concentration of 40% at flow rates greater than 10 L/ min for short periods. It is usually limited to a flow of 5-6 L/min to reduce the discomfort resulting from inadequate humidification and high flow into the nasal cavity. It may also cause drying and crusting of the nasal mucosa.

Option B: Hudson mask also known as a simple face mask is a Low-flow, variable-performance device. It provides an oxygen flow rate of up to 5-10 L/min and provides a variable FiO2. The body of the mask functions as a reservoir for both oxygen and expired carbon dioxide. It is used in patients who require oxygen therapy for shorter periods of time.

Option D: The non-rebreather mask is a low-flow variable device that can be used to deliver oxygen at higher concentrations (FiO2 80-95%). It uses a reservoir bag to let the oxygen get concentrated while a one-way valve doesn't allow it to breathe in expired air. This type of mask is used in patients with significant hypoxia, with relatively normal ventilation, such as victims of trauma or carbon monoxide exposure.

questions.text: What is the definition of a post-term neonate?

choices.text: Neonate born after 37 weeks of gestation
Neonate born between 37- 40 weeks of gestation
Neonate born after 40 weeks of gestation
Neonate born after 42 weeks of gestation

questions.solution:
Post-term infants are those born after 42 completed weeks of gestation, as calculated from the mother’s last menstrual period, regardless of weight at birth.

A term neonate is a neonate born any time after 37 completed weeks gestation and up until 42 completed weeks gestation.

questions.text: An 8 weeks pregnant woman, working in an industry consults a doctor.  According to the ESI act, what is the duration of maternity leave that she can get?

choices.text: 28 weeks, starting from 4 weeks after delivery
26 weeks, starting from 8 weeks before delivery

questions.solution:
According to ESI act, this pregnant woman is entitled to a leave of 26 weeks, starting 8 weeks preceding the expected date of delivery.

According to The Employees State Insurance Act and its amendments, pregnant ladies can receive benefits in cash for confinement/miscarriage or sickness arising out of the same or premature birth of a child or miscarriage. This includes maternity leave for

  • 26 weeks of which not more than 8 weeks shall be preceding the expected date of her delivery.
  • 6 weeks in case of miscarriage.
  • 30 days for sickness arising out of being in the family way, premature delivery or medical termination of pregnancy.
  • Women having 2 or more surviving children shall be allowed maternity leave of 12 weeks of which not more than 6 weeks should be before the expected date of her delivery.

Related Pearl: ESI ACT, 1948

Employees State Insurance Act, 1948 (Revised in 2019)

Scope: It is applicable to all factories in India excluding:

  • Defence 
  • Railway  
  • Mines 

Finance Contribution

  • It covers all employees getting income up to Rs.21,000/- per month.
  • Employee – 0.75% of his daily wage.
  • Employer – 3.25% of the employees' daily wage.
  • Medical benefit – 1/8th by the state government and 7/8th by the ESI Corporation.

Benefits

To the Employees

  • Medical Benefit- full medical care is provided free of cost in case of sickness, employment injury, and maternity.
  • Sickness Benefit- is given at 70% of average daily wages for a duration of 91 days in one year. In order to qualify for sickness benefit, the worker is required to contribute for 78 days in a period of 6 months.
    • Extended sickness benefit – 80% of the daily wages for a duration of 2 years, for 34 specified diseases such as TB, leprosy, malignant diseases, diabetes, Parkinson's, myasthenia gravis, glaucoma, coronary artery disease, etc.
    • Enhanced sickness benefit – at full wages for sterilization procedure; for a duration of 7 days post-vasectomy and 14 days post tubectomy. 
    • The total amount payable is double the standard sickness benefit rate, that is, equal to full wages.
  • Maternity Benefit – benefit is payable at full wages for 26 weeks (6.5 months) for pregnancy, 6 weeks following a miscarriage, and 30 days for sickness arising out of pregnancy. It also covers the premature birth of a child born to an insured woman.
  • Dependance Benefit– in case of death, as a result of employment injury, the dependents of an insured person are eligible for periodical payments. Pension at the rate of 90% of the wages is payable, shared by dependants in a fixed ratio, on monthly basis in accordance with the prescribed share. An eligible son or daughter is entitled to the dependant's benefit up to the age of 18; the benefit is withdrawn if the daughter marries earlier.
  • Disablement Benefits–
    • Temporary disability- at 90% daily wages as long as the person is disabled.
    • Permanent disability- lifetime pension. It also covers occupational diseases.
  • Funeral Benefit – a maximum of Rs.15,000/-.
  • Rehabilitation Benefit- on payment of Rs.10, the insured person and his/her family continue to get medical treatment after permanent disablement or retirement.

To the Employers

  • Exemption from Workman Compensation Act.
  • Exemption from Maternity Benefit Act.
  • Income tax rebate on the amount contributed towards the scheme.
  • Exemption from payment of medical allowance to employees and their dependants, or arranging for their medical care.
  • Healthy-work force.

Related Pearl: The Factories act, 1948 and The Maternity Act, 2017

The Factories act,1948

  • The act defines factory as an establishment employing 10 or more workers where power is used, and 20 or more workers where power is not used. 
  • Age of employment –  prohibition children of < 14 years from working.
  • Adolescents between 15 – 18 years
    • Can be employed  only in certain industries and  work between 6 AM – 7 PM
    • They should not be made to work for more than four and a half hours
    • They are allowed to take leave once in every 15 days and have an accumulated leave of up to 40 days
  • Hours of work for adults: maximum hours of work for an industrial worker should be not more than 48 hours per week, not exceeding 9 hours a day, if working overtime then it should be no more than 60 hrs per week
  • Per capita space availability: For factories established after 1948 – min 500cuft / person
  • Safety and Welfare measures:
    • > 1000 Workers – Safety officer
    • > 500 Workers – Welfare officer
    • > 250 Workers – Canteen
    • > 50 Workers- Crèche*

The Maternity Act, 2017 is a landmark law which has enhanced the duration of paid maternity leave:

  • Working mothers- 12 weeks to 26 weeks
  • Working mothers, already with 2 surviving children - 12 weeks
  • Adopting mother and commissioning mothers- 12 weeks from the date on which the child is being handed over to the mother.

 

*for fifty women worker after the 1976 amendment.

questions.text: A homosexual man complains of painful defecation and mass protruding from the anal canal. Biopsy reveals squamous cell carcinoma of anus. Correct management for this patient is ___________
questions.solution:
The management of choice for squamous cell carcinoma of the anal canal is combined chemotherapy and radiation therapy also called Nigro regimen.

Treatment of squamous cell carcinoma of the anal canal:

  • The primary treatment for squamous cell carcinoma is by chemoradiotherapy (Nigro regimen)
  • A combination of 5-fluorouracil (5-FU) with mitomycin C/ cisplatin is followed by external beam radiation to the pelvis with a minimum dose of 45 Gy.
  • Metastases are rare at presentation (5%), and treatment is aimed at local control.
  • Patients with T2 lesions and residual disease after 45 Gy, T3 or T4 tumors, or node-positive disease are usually treated with an additional 9 to 14 Gy for a total dose of 54 to 59 Gy.
  • Patients with persistent disease up to 6 months after treatment generally require APR. Those who have local recurrence are also recommended for APR.

 

Related Pearl: Chemotherapy for GI Tumours

GI malignancy

Chemotherapy

Esophageal carcinoma

ECF (Epirubicin + Cisplatin + 5-FU)

Gastric carcinoma

ECF (Epirubicin + Cisplatin + 5-FU)

Small intestine adenocarcinoma

5-FU

Colorectal carcinoma

FOLFOX-IV (5-FU + Leucovorin + Oxaliplatin)

Carcinoma of the anal canal

Nigro Regimen: Chemoradiation (5-FU + Mitomycin C) + Radiation

questions.text: A patient was brought to the OPD with the following deformity. Identify the condition.
questions.solution:
The given X-ray of a child with abnormally approximated knees, divergent ankles, and increased intermalleolar distances depicts genu valgum.

A normal knee has 5-7 degrees of physiological outward deviation (valgum). Any increase in angle can result in Genu valgum or knock knee where knees are abnormally approximated and the ankles are divergent.

Intermalleolar distance has been used to assess the degree of genu valgum. It is the distance between the medial malleoli in a standing patient with touching medial femoral condyles. Intermalleolar distances greater than 8 cm are considered pathologic.

Children start developing physiologic genu valgum by age 2, and it becomes most prominent between ages 3 to 4. After that, it typically decreases to a stable, slightly valgus position by age 7 years. Other causes include

  • Bilateral Genu Valgum: Physiologic genu valgum, skeletal dysplasia, metabolic bone diseases, osteoarthritis, and rheumatoid arthritis.
  • Unilateral Genu Valgum: Trauma, tumors, and infection.
Osteoarthritis of the knee Rheumatoid arthritis of the knee
Genu varum more common Genu valgum more common
Subchondral sclerosis  Periarticular osteopenia 
No soft tissue swelling  Soft tissue swelling (pannus)
Osteophytes No osteophytes 
Hard and bony joint Soft, warm, and tender joint
Rheumatoid factor negative Rheumatoid factor positive

Knee deformities are:

  • Genu valgus (valgum) or knock knee - Knees are abnormally approximated and the ankles are divergent.
  • Genu varus (varum) or bow knee - Knees are abnormally divergent and the ankles are approximated.
  • Windswept deformity - Abnormal valgus deformity of one knee with varus of the other.
  • Genu recurvatum - Hyperextension at the knee joint with backward bending.

Related Pearl: Important Clinical Features of Rickets

Related Pearl: Radiological features of rickets

Radiological features of rickets:

  • Loss of provisional zone of calcification: earliest radiological finding of rickets. 
  • Delayed appearance of the epiphysis
  • Widening of growth plate: normal width of growth is 2-4mm. It is increased in cases of rickets due to excessive accumulation of uncalcified osteoid at the growth plate.
  • Cupping of metaphysis: normally metaphysis meets epiphysis as a smooth line of sclerosis. But in rickets the line is absent and the metaphyseal ends appear irregular and the cartilage accumulating in the growth plate creates a depression in the metaphysis causing cupping.
  • Fraying: indistinct margins of the metaphysis
  • Bowing of diaphysis, with thinning of cortices
  • In healing rickets, zone of calcification becomes denser. 

The above features are prominent at the growth plates where growth is greatest:

  • Knee: distal femur, proximal tibia
  • Wrist: especially the ulna
  • Anterior rib ends: rachitic rosary

The below image shows bowing of legs in rickets.

questions.text: Inquest in a case of custodial death is handled by _______
questions.solution:
An inquest in a case of custodial death is handled by the Executive Magistrate. 

Magistrate inquest (Section 176 Cr. P.C) is an inquest conducted by a district magistrate, subdivisional magistrate, and magistrate of the first-class rank or any other magistrate as empowered by the state government, such as collector, deputy collector or Tehsildar (executive magistrate).

It is conducted in cases of:

  • Death under police custody
  • Death due to police firing
  • Death in prison, reformatories, borstal schools
  • Dowry death
  • Death in a psychiatric hospital
  • Exhumation
  • Death or disappearance of any person, or rape of a woman who is under the custody of police or any other person authorized by the court.

In the above-mentioned scenarios, a Magistrate can conduct the inquest independently or in addition to the police inquest.

questions.text: A diabetic patient developed DVT with a necrolytic migratory rash. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Necrolytic migratory erythema skin lesion along with a history of long standing diabetes and recurrent deep vein thrombosis is suggestive of glucagonoma.

Present as mass lesions as even high plasma levels of this hormone fail to cause symptoms
  • Islet hyperplasia (previously known as nesidioblastosis) is seen in maternal diabetes, Beckwith–Wiedemann syndrome , and rare mutations in the β-cell K+-channel protein or sulfonylurea receptor.
  • In maternal diabetes, the fetal islets respond to hyperglycemia by increasing their size and number. In the postnatal period, these hyperactive islets may be responsible for serious episodes of hypoglycemia.

questions.text: Which of the following is the process of breaking the clavicle during delivery?
questions.solution:
Cleidotomy is the process of fracturing the clavicle using an instrument to free the anterior shoulder. It is usually done for a dead fetus (shown below).

It is a method of management of labor in the case of shoulder dystocia. Shoulder dystocia occurs when either the anterior or the posterior (rare) fetal shoulder impacts on the maternal symphysis or on the sacral promontory respectively.

Management of labor in case of shoulder dystocia is as follows: 

  • First line: 
    • McRoberts maneuver (flexion and abduction of the thigh)
  • Second line:
    • Woods corkscrew maneuver (Rotate the posterior shoulder to 180o in a corkscrew fashion) 
  • Third line:
    • Zavanelli maneuver: It involves the replacement of the fetal head into the pelvis followed by cesarean delivery. (Option C)
    • Cleidotomy 
    • Symphysiotomy: The intervening symphyseal carti­lage and ligamentous supports are cut to widen the symphysis pubis. (Option B)

Option A: Craniotomy is not used in the management of shoulder dystocia. It is an operation in which a small hole is made in the skull or a piece of bone from the skull is removed to show part of the brain.

questions.text: Identify the given instrument.
questions.solution:
The above instrument is a linear stapler. 

A linear stapler is used to close the bowel completely or partially.

Option B: Cutaneous staplers give clean apposition. It is faster and technically easier. Disadvantages are removal requires specific instrument and costlier than sutures.

Below is an image of a skin stapler.

Option C: Circular staplers are also called as end to end anastomosis staplers. It is used for luminal anastomosis and the transection of hollow viscera. It is commonly used for colorectal anastomosis in anterior resection for carcinoma rectum, and oesophagogastric anastomosis after esophagogastric resection in case of carcinoma at the esophageal-gastric junction.

Below is an image of a circular stapler.

Option D: Curved or radial staplers were developed as an alternative to the standard linear stapler to facilitate the division of the distal rectum. This type of stapler has gently arched end effectors, and the final result is a curved staple line.

questions.text: A 55-year-old post-menopausal woman presents with knee pain. Join aspiration was done and it shows negatively birefringent needle-shaped crystals in a polarized microscope. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis based on the given clinical scenario is gout.

Gout is a metabolic disease that is characterized by the deposition of monosodium urate crystals in joints and connective tissue. It is more common in males and it usually presents as monoarthritis that may be acute and episodic or chronic. 

Clinical features include extreme pain of the joint(most commonly first metatarsophalangeal joint), stiff or swollen joint, deformity of the affected joint (ex: nodules), and subcutaneous nodules.

Diagnosis - Synovial fluid analysis shows negatively birefringent needle-shaped crystals under polarized light. The radiograph is normal in the initial stages while it shows erosions, punched-out lesions, and sclerosis with preservation of joint space in the late stages.

Treatment - NSAIDs, corticosteroids, colchicine, probenecid, and allopurinol.

 

Other options:

Option A- Osteoarthritis(OA) typically affects the weight-bearing joints like the knee, hip, and spine. It presents bilaterally with pain being the predominant symptom. The pain worsens with use. Other symptoms such as joint stiffness, swelling, giving away, or locking can be present.

Option B: Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is a chronic inflammatory disease of unknown etiology characterized by symmetric polyarthritis. A variation in the HLA-DRB1 gene is known to cause RA. Clinically, patients present with early morning joint pain and stiffness that relieves with activity. It mainly involves the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) and proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints. Other hallmark features include flexor tendon tenosynovitis, swan neck deformity, boutonniere deformity, Z-line deformity, and trigger finger. Methotrexate is the DMARD of choice

Management includes non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs for pain relief, along with disease-modifying anti-rheumatoid drugs (DMARD).

questions.text: Identify the given image of the placenta previa.
questions.solution:
The picture shown is of the Marginal placenta previa.

Placenta previa is used to describe a placenta implanted in the lower uterine segment. Painless bleeding towards the end of the second trimester or later is characteristic of the condition. It usually occurs without warning and resolves spontaneously only to recur. 

There are four types of placenta previa according to the degree of placental expansion to the lower uterine segment. 

  • Type-I: Low-lying- The lower margin of the placenta reaches the lower uterine segment but not the os. (Option B)
  • Type-II: Marginal- The placenta does not cover the internal os but reaches its margin. 
  • Type-III: Incomplete or partial central- The placenta covers the closed internal os but does not do so when fully dilated. (Option C)
  • Type-IV: Complete or central- The placenta covers the internal os even when fully dilated. (Option D)

questions.text: If the division in the zygote occurs between 9-12 days after fertilization, which of the following twin is expected?
questions.solution:
If the division in the zygote occurs between 9-12 days after fertilization, monochorionic monoamniotic twins are expected.

Time of division Type of twin
<3 days  Dichorionic diamniotic (DCDA) 
4-8 days Monochorionic diamniotic (MCDA)
>8 days Monochorionic monoamniotic (MCMA)
>13 days  Conjoint twins

The following radiological signs help in the determination of the chorionicity and the amnionicity of a twin gestation.

Lambda sign: In dichorionic gestation, the twins are separated by amniotic membranes and an intervening chorion. So, a thicker twin peak sign or lambda (λ) sign is formed at the point at which the amnions meet the placenta. It is best seen in the first trimester.

T sign: It is the sonographic image seen in a monochorionic twin pregnancy. It refers to the lack of chorion extending between the layers of the intertwin membrane.

  • In monochorionic diamniotic gestation, the twins are separated only by the two amniotic membranes, with no intervening chorion. So, a thin T sign is formed at the point at which the amnions meet the placenta. It is best seen in the latter part of the first trimester or the beginning of the second trimester.
  • In monochorionic monoamniotic gestation, there is an absence of a dividing membrane.

Related Pearl: Twinning

questions.text: How much per cent of GNP does WHO recommend being spent on the healthcare sector?
questions.solution:
The WHO has set the target of at least 5% expenditure of each country's GNP on healthcare

India spends about 1% of its GNP on health and family welfare. The National Health Policy, 2017 aims to increase public health expenditure from 1.15% of GDP to around 2.5% by 2025.

questions.text: A primigravida woman at  26 weeks gestation, presented with a BP of 150/90 mm Hg. Which test should be done next?
questions.solution:
Urine dipstick should be the test that should be done next.

The patient is found to have BP> 140/90mm/hg after 20 weeks of gestation. It can be either gestational hypertension or Preeclampsia.

Gestational hypertension: BP≥ 140/90 mm of hg for the first time in pregnancy after 20 weeks of gestation in a previously normotensive woman without proteinuria.

Pre-eclampsia: Gestational hypertension along with proteinuria.

Proteinuria is the presence of total protein in 24 hours of urine of 0.3 g or more OR urine protein/creatinine (P/C) ratio >0.3 OR equal to 1 + (persistent 30 mg/dL) protein in at least two random clean-catch urine samples tested 4 hours apart in the absence of urinary tract infection is considered significant.

Hence the test done next is a urine dipstick.

Other investigations in pre-eclampsia:

  • Ophthalmoscopic examination
  • Blood values: They are usually non-specific. Serum uric acid level and S. creatinine is done. A liver function test is also done. A coagulation profile is not necessary when platelet count and liver enzymes are normal.
  • Antenatal fetal monitoring

Gestational Hypertension

Pre-Eclampsia

Chronic Hypertension in pregnancy

Rise in BP >140/90 mmHg after 20 weeks of pregnancy

Rise in BP >140/90 mmHg after 20 weeks of pregnancy

Previously known hypertensive or BP  >140/90mmHg before 20 weeks of gestation

No Proteinuria

Proteinuria present(>300 mg in 24 hrs urine or >30 mg/dl in the random urine sample or urine dipstick 1+)

questions.text: A 26-year-old male presented with erythematous plaques covered with silvery scales over the extensor surfaces of both arms.  Punctate pitting was noted on examining the nails. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presentation of erythematous plaques with silvery scales over the extensor surfaces of arms and punctate pitting of the nails are suggestive of psoriasis.

Psoriasis is a chronic inflammatory condition of the skin with systemic manifestations. Plaque psoriasis is the most common type.

  • The peak occurrence is between 16 to 22 years and between 57 to 62 years. They usually present with itching and a papulosquamous rash.
  • The lesions are red, and scaly, and have well demarcation from the normal skin.
  • They can also be encircled by a clear peripheral zone which is called the Woronoff ring.
  • They commonly appear in the scalp, trunk, and extensor surfaces of the limbs.
  • Koebner or isomorphic phenomenon- describes the appearance of new lesions along the site of trauma (linear lesions)

Nail findings are commonly seen across all types of psoriasis. Patients present with pits, ridges, and grooves of the nail plate. In the case of nail bed involvement subungual oil drops, subungual hyperkeratosis, and distal onycholysis can be seen.

The characteristic histopathological finding in psoriasis consists of multiple neutrophilic foci in the parakeratotic stratum corneum i.e Munro’s microabscesses and spongiform neutrophils in the spinous layer of the epidermis i.e spongiform pustules of Kogoj.

The topical application of steroids, retinoids, vitamin D, and emollients is the mainstay of management. Phototherapy and oral methotrexate, acitretin, and cyclosporine can also be used.

Other options:

Option B: Lichen planus is an inflammatory disorder affecting the skin and mucosal membranes. The lesions of Lichen planus can be described as 5Ps — purple, polygonal, pruritic, plane-topped (flat), papules and are shown in the image below. White streaks forming a lacework in buccal mucosa is a characteristic feature and are known as Wickham’s striae. Nail involvement includes hyperpigmentation, subungual hyperkeratosis, onycholysis, and pterygium unguis due to adhesion between the dorsal nail fold and the nail bed.

Option C: Atopic dermatitis or eczema is a relapsing chronic inflammatory skin disease. Patients present with itchy erythematous papules/ papulovesicular lesions in flexural regions as shown below. Nail involvement is in the form of coarse pitting and ridging. 

Option D: Pityriasis rosea is an acute self-limiting papulosquamous disorder. It is commonly seen in children and young adults. The first manifestation of the disease is usually the appearance of the herald patch, which is larger and more conspicuous than the lesions of the later eruption covered by fine scales. Later the center tends to clear and assumes a wrinkled, atrophic appearance and a tawny color, with a marginal collarette of scale attached peripherally, with the free edge of the scale internally - called a Hanging curtain sign.

Related Pearl: Nail changes in psoriasis

Nail changes in psoriasis are present in about 40% of the cases at any point in time. Nail psoriasis is associated with more extensive psoriasis, longer disease duration, family history of psoriasis, and the presence of psoriatic arthritis.

Subungal oil drop sign or Salmon Patch is a highly specific pathognomonic sign seen in Nail psoriasis. It is a yellow-red discoloration in the nail bed resembling a drop of oil.

Nail pitting however is the most frequent sign. Individual pits are uniformly sized, deep and irregular in nature. These nail pits are also known as Thimble pits and are due to the involvement of the proximal nail matrix.

Nail Bed disease also causes subungual hyperkeratosis, splinter hemorrhages, and distal onycholysis.

Leuconychia may also be present.

Trachonychia or Twenty Nail dystrophy may be present in severe cases.

Image :  Pitting is the commonest manifestation of nail psoriasis.

Image: oil drops visible in the nail bed.

Image: pitting and salmon patches in fingernails.

Image: Leukonychia in a patient with psoriasis.

 

Features of Nail Psoriasis – Mnemonic

“Nail – POLISH”

  • P – Pitting
  • O – Oil drop sign, Onycholysis
  • L – Leuconychia
  • I – Irregular pitting pattern
  • S – Splinter Hemorrhage
  • H – Hyperkeratosis (Subungual)

Related Pearl: Treatment Ladder for Psoriasis

Treatment Ladder for Psoriasis

I. In Mild Psoriasis Without Arthritis

First line

  • Coal tar
  • Dithranol
  • Potent topical steroid
  • Vitamin D analogue

Second line

  • Local NB-UVB or PUVA
  • Excimer laser

II. In Moderate or Severe Psoriasis Without Arthritis

First line

  • NB-UVB or PUVA

Second line

  • Acitretin
  • Apremilast
  • Ciclosporin
  • Fumaric acid esters (where available)
  • Methotrexate

Third line

  • Adalimumab
  • Etanercept
  • Infliximab
  • Secukinumab
  • Ustekinumab

III. In Moderate or Severe Psoriasis with Psoriatic Arthritis

First line

  • Apremilast
  • Methotrexate

Second line

  • Adalimumab
  • Etanercept
  • Infliximab
  • Ustekinumab

Third line

  • Combination therapy

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in all kinds of shock?
questions.solution:
Shock is defined as a systemic state of low tissue perfusion that is inadequate for normal cellular respiration.

The classification of shock and its features are as follows:

  Cardiac output Venous pressure Vascular resistance Mixed venous saturation Base deficit
Hypovolemic Low Low High Low High
Obstructive Low High High Low High
Cardiogenic Low High High Low High
Distributive High Low Low High High

Hypovolemic shock: It is due to reduced circulating volume. Causes include hemorrhage, dehydration, vomiting, and third spacing.

 

Obstructive Shock: This leads to a reduction in preload due to mechanical obstruction of cardiac filling. Causes include cardiac tamponade, tension pneumothorax, massive pulmonary embolus, or air embolus.

 

Cardiogenic shock: Due to the failure of the heart to pump blood to tissues. Causes include myocardial infarction, cardiac dysrhythmias, valvular heart disease, blunt myocardial injury, and cardiomyopathy.

 

Distributive shock: Distributive shock is the condition of reduced oxygen delivery where the primary physiologic disturbance is a reduction in systemic vascular resistance leading to vasodilation. It is unique among the types of shock in that there is a compensatory increase in cardiac output. Causes include spinal shock, anaphylaxis, and septic shock.

questions.text: Which of the following tests cannot be used to detect blood stains?
questions.solution:
Barberio's test is not used for detecting blood stains. It helps in the identification of semen.

Barberio's test is used to detect the presence of spermine picrate, a component of prostatic secretion. A drop of the stain of spermatic fluid taken in a glass slide is charged with a saturated aqueous or alcoholic solution of picric acid. Under microscopic examination, the needle-shaped yellowish spermine picrate crystals indicate the presence of semen.

Option B: Takayama's test- It is also known as the hemochromogen crystal test. It is a more reliable test to detect old blood stains. 2-3 drops of Takayama's reagent are added to the suspected material on the glass slide. A positive test result is indicated by the presence of pink feathery crystals of reduced hemochromogen or reduced alkaline hematin in clusters.

Option C: Teichman's test- This test is also used to detect blood stains. It is also called as hemin crystal test. A small crystal of sodium chloride and glacial acetic acid is used for the test. Faint yellowish-red to brownish crystals of hemin or hematin chloride in clusters are seen if the suspected material is stained with blood. Teichman's test may be negative if the blood stain is old. 

Option D: Spectroscopy-  It is the most reliable test to detect the presence of both old and recent blood stains. Characteristic dark bands are produced depending on the type of blood pigment when the blood solution is examined under a spectroscope. 

Related Pearl: Tests to detect seminal and blood stains

Tests for seminal stains

  • Barberio's test
  • Florence test
  • Acid phosphatase test
  • Creatine phosphokinase test
  • Immunological test to detect Prostate Specific Antigen

Tests for blood stains  

  • Benzidine test
  • Phenophthalein (Kastle Meyer) test
  • Takayama hemochromogen crystal test
  • Teichmann’s hemin crystal test
  • Spectroscopic test

questions.text: The shelf life of copper T 380 A is
questions.solution:
Copper T-380A has a life span of 10 years.

Copper T-380A (Paraguard) is a second-generation intrauterine device(IUD) having 380 sq. mm of surface area of copper on the device. A higher surface area of copper results in higher contraceptive efficacy. It has a plastic T-shaped core with copper placed around the vertical stem and horizontal arms. The frame of the Copper T-380A is connected to a monofilament thread that protrudes into the upper vagina. This facilitates easy removal and allows the user to ensure that the IUD remains in the uterus.

It functions mainly by causing an inflammatory response within the uterus that impair the viability of the sperms and reduce its chances of fertilization. The same response also makes it difficult for blastocyst implantation.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of thrombocytopenia in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
The most common cause of thrombocytopenia in pregnancy is gestational thrombocytopenia. This may be due to hemodilution and increased platelet consumption in pregnancy.

Pregnancy is a hypercoagulable state. Hematological changes in pregnancy include:

  • All clotting factors are increased (except factor 11,13) and fibrinogen levels are also increased.
  • Clotting time and bleeding time are unaffected.
  • The viscosity of blood doesn’t increase since plasma volume increases more in comparison to red cell volume, it merely decreases whole blood viscosity.
  • Anticoagulants Protein C, Protein S and antithrombin decrease during pregnancy.
  • Fibrinolytic activity remains depressed till about 15 minutes after pregnancy

questions.text:
Elective splenectomy is preferred in which of the following conditions?

G6PD deficiency- Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency
questions.solution:
Elective splenectomy is done in case of hereditary spherocytosis.

Hereditary spherocytosis is a type of hereditary hemolytic anemia that is passed down in an autosomal dominant pattern. Mutations of the red blood cell surface proteins spectrin and ankyrin can result in unstable cell membranes, leading to hemolysis.

This disorder can present at a young age with severe jaundice and fatigue. The unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia predisposes the patient to develop gallstones.

Laboratory findings include normocytic anemia with unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. The peripheral smear will show large spherical red blood cells without central pallor. The diagnosis can be confirmed by the acid glycerol lysis test and the eosin-5′-maleimide (EMA)–binding test. 

There is no specific treatment available besides splenectomy. However, due to the possible adverse effects, it is only indicated in severe cases and after the child attains puberty in moderate cases. It should be followed up with the appropriate antibiotic and vaccine prophylaxis.

Other options:

Option (A): Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency is a type of inherited hemolytic anemia. It is associated with exacerbations after consuming anti-malarial drugs and in periods of oxidative stress. The peripheral smear shows characteristic "bite cells". In G6PD deficiency, uncontrolled oxidative stress causes hemoglobin to denature and form Heinz bodies. G6PD deficiency is largely preventable by avoiding exposure to triggering factors.

Option (B): Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria is a hemolytic disorder that also presents with pancytopenia and a tendency to form venous thrombi. It occurs due to defective GPI anchors on the red blood cell surface which are normally used to anchor CD 59 (cell-protective proteins) to the surface. These patients can present with episodes of dark brown urine in the morning, anemia, pancytopenia, and recurrent abdominal pain due to thrombosis of abdominal veins. 

Bone marrow transplantation is done for the treatment. Recently humanized monoclonal antibody eculizumab is used.

Option (D): Hairy cell leukemia is a distinctive B cell neoplasm, that predominantly affects middle-aged males. Tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase is the cytochemical stain characteristically shown by leukemic hairy cells. Patients commonly present with massive splenomegaly due to infiltration of the leukemic cells. Pancytopenia due to marrow involvement can also be seen. These tumors respond well to chemotherapy and BRAF (B-type Raf proto-oncogene) inhibitors, and they have an excellent prognosis.

questions.text: A man came with complaints of recurrent discharge and pain due to lesions around the anus for 3 years. A diagnosis of fistula-in-ano is made. What is the gold standard investigation for this condition?
questions.solution:
In cases of fistula-in-ano, MRI is the gold standard investigation.

A fistula-in-ano is an abnormal connection between the anal canal and the perianal skin, lined with granulation tissue. It may follow the drainage of a perianal abscess or may be seen in association with diseases like tuberculosis or Crohn's disease.

Clinical features are perianal pain, swelling, and intermittent purulent discharge, which might be blood-stained. On examination, one or more external openings may be visible.

Goodsall’s rule can be used as a guide in determining the location of the internal opening of the fistula. Fistulas with an external opening anteriorly connect to the internal opening by a short, radial tract. Fistulas with an external opening posteriorly track in a curvilinear fashion to the posterior midline.

However, exceptions to this rule often occur. Fistulas with an anterior external opening greater than 3 cm from the anal margin usually track to the posterior midline.

 

 

The investigations done for fistula-in-ano can include a fistulogram, endoanal ultrasound with hydrogen peroxide, MRI, and computed tomography (CT) scan. An MRI is the gold standard investigation for fistula imaging. It helps us to identify the secondary extensions of the track, which when missed may cause persistence of the fistula. 

Surgical management includes fistulotomy, fistulectomy, ligation of the intersphincteric fistula tract (LIFT), setons, or advancement flaps.

questions.text: What is the level of the uterus immediately after delivery?
questions.solution:
The level of the uterus immediately after delivery is below the umbilicus.

The rate of involution of the uterus can be assessed clinically by noting the height of the fundus of the uterus in relation to the symphysis pubis.

  • The uterus is to be centralized and the fundal height is measured above the symphysis pubis with a measuring tape. Following delivery, the fundus lies about 13.5 cm above the symphysis pubis(which is best referred to as below the umbilicus).
  • During the first 24 hours, the level remains constant. Thereafter, there is a steady decrease in height by 1.25 cm in 24 hours. By the end of 2nd week, the uterus becomes a pelvic organ.
  • The rate of involution thereafter slows down until by 6 weeks when the uterus becomes almost normal in size.

questions.text: Which of the following is most suitable for intravenous regional anesthesia?
questions.solution:
Lidocaine is the most preferred drug for intravenous regional anesthesia.

Intravenous Regional Anesthesia or Bier’s block:

  • Intravenous administration of LA into a tourniquet-occluded limb.
  • Anesthesia for short surgical procedures (<45-60 minutes) on the limbs(such as the excision of soft tissue masses or carpal tunnel release)
  • LA commonly used are Lidocaine (most common), followed by Prilocaine, Mepivacaine, Chloroprocaine, Procaine, and Etidocaine.
  • For upper limbs, 40 mL of 0.5% lidocaine without epinephrine is used.
  • For lower limbs, 50 to 100 mL of 0.25% lidocaine without epinephrine is used.

Complications following Bier's block are postoperative pain, difficulty in providing bloodless field, and in rare cases may lead to compartment syndrome due to increased pressure applied. Premature deflation of the tourniquet or increased dose of local anesthesia may lead to systemic toxicity.

Bupivacaine (Option A) is no longer used for Biers block. This is because Bupivacaine is the most cardiotoxic local anesthetic (LA). Accidental early deflation of the tourniquet can lead to massive systemic doses of bupivacaine resulting in cardiac arrhythmias and cardiovascular collapse.

The image below shows Bier's block/ IVRA.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indication for cesarean section?
questions.solution:
Previous history of macrosomia is not an indication of a cesarean section(CS).

Cesarean is needed even with a dead fetus when vaginal delivery is not possible.
The following are the absolute indication:

  • Central placenta previa (Option C)
  • Contracted pelvis or cephalopelvic disproportion (absolute)(Option A)
  • Pelvic mass causing an obstruction (cervical or broad ligament fibroid)
  • Advanced carcinoma cervix (Option D)
  • Vaginal atresia or stenosis

Relative indications for cesarean section are those where vaginal delivery may be possible but risks to the mother and/or baby are high. They are as follows:

  • Nonreassuring FHR
  • Dystocia- It may be due to a relatively large fetus (passenger), small pelvis (passage), or inefficient uterine contractions (power)
  • Antepartum hemorrhage: Placenta previa and abruptio placenta
  • Malpresentation: Breech, shoulder (transverse lie), brow
  • Previous cesarean delivery-a) When primary CS was due to recurrent indication (contracted pelvis), (b) Previous two CS,(c) Features of scar dehiscence, (d) Previous classical CS
  • Cephalopelvic disproportion (relative)
  • Failure to progress in labor
  • Hypertensive disorders: Severe pre-eclampsia, eclampsia— uncontrolled fits even with antiseizure therapy.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female patient, who is a known case of ovarian cancer, presents with difficulty in activities like climbing stairs, getting up from the chair, combing hair, etc. The following characteristic sign was found on examination. The most probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis is dermatomyositis.

The given image shows upper eyelid lilac erythema or heliotrope rash which is pathognomonic of dermatomyositis. The clinical presentation of proximal myopathy with a rash in an elderly female, with a history of internal malignancy, is also suggestive of dermatomyositis. 

Other classic cutaneous signs in dermatomyositis:

  • Heliotrope rash/ eyelid erythema- Violaceous erythema of the upper eyelids
  • V sign- Confluent macular erythema over the lower anterior neck and upper anterior chest
  • Shawl sign- Confluent macular erythema over the upper back and lateral aspect of arms
  • Gottron’s papules- Erythematous papules and plaques over extensor surface of the metacarpophalangeal and interphalangeal joints
  • Gottron's sign- Erythematous rash over the extensor surfaces of joints such as the knuckles, elbows, knees, and ankles. 
  • Mechanic’s hands- Rough, hyperkeratotic lines on the lateral and palmer areas of the fingers

Facial rash in dermatomyositis-

Shawl sign in dermatomyositis-

Flagellate erythema in dermatomyositis-

Poikilodermatous changes in dermatomyositis-

Other options:

Option A: Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) presents with a malar rash as visualized in the image in the image below. It is characterized by a well-demarcated erythematous butterfly rash over the malar eminences with sparing of the nasolabial folds.

Option C: Scleroderma or systemic sclerosis has findings of mask-like facies with stretched, shiny skin, loss of normal facial lines, microstomia, and resorption of distal phalanges of the fingers.

Option D: Cushing's syndrome presents with easy bruisability and multiple purple striae over the abdomen. They may also have rounding, puffiness, fat deposition, and plethora in the face collectively called the moon facies.

questions.text: How long should a couple use contraception post-vasectomy?
questions.solution:
The couple need to take contraceptive measures for 12-16 weeks or 3 months after the male partner undergoes vasectomy.

Vasectomy is a permanent sterilization procedure done in males, where a segment of the vas deferens is resected and ligated bilaterally.

This procedure is done under local anesthesia. A small incision is made in the scrotum. The vas deferens are divided into both sides, disrupting the passage of sperms. The no-scalpel technique has been now adopted. One single incision is made with special forceps and a skin stitch is not required. Clips and plugs can be applied over the vas instead of cutting. The failure rate of vasectomy is 0.15%.

It is a relatively simple procedure with low rates of complications. A patient who had a vasectomy is not sterile immediately after the procedure as semen is stored in distal channels of the vas deferens for varying periods.

Hence, for this reason, it is estimated that at least 20 ejaculations or 3 months are required to empty the stored semen.

questions.text: In a primigravida what is a satisfactory dilation rate?
questions.solution:
In a primigravida, the satisfactory rate of dilation is 1.2cm/hr.

Latent phase Active phase
The onset of true labour pain up to 5cm cervical dilatation  From ≥ 6cm cervical dilatation with regular uterine contractions

questions.text: You see a middle-aged man presenting to the psychiatry OPD who reports aliens have been speaking to him and telling him to kill his relatives over the past 7 months. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient has had auditory hallucinations for the past 7 months, which makes the diagnosis of schizophrenia more likely of the given options.

Diagnostic criteria for schizophrenia (DSM-5):

1. The DSM-5 criteria to diagnose schizophrenia require a total duration of 6 months.

2. Within this 6-month period, there must be at least 1-month overt psychotic symptoms where 2 or more of the following have to be present. And at least one must be delusion, hallucination or disorganised speech.

  1. Delusion
  2. Hallucination
  3. Disorganized speech (or formal thought disorder)
  4. Disorganized behaviour
  5. Affective flattening or other negative symptoms

A mood disorder & substance abuse should be excluded first.

This person has come to seek medical care for hearing voices of aliens (not thoughts or beliefs)which is telling him to kill his relatives, causing impairment. These are consistent with schizophrenia.

Other options:

Option A: Mania: Mania is a key feature of bipolar disorder, characterized by an elevated mood, increased energy levels, and racing thoughts. Persistent auditory hallucinations commanding the individual to harm others is not typically seen in mania alone. Additionally, the duration of 7 months suggests a more chronic and enduring condition, which is not consistent with a typical manic episode.

Option B: Delusional disorder: Delusional disorder involves the presence of one or more persistent delusions without the significant impairment of other cognitive functions or the presence of hallucinations. 

Option D: Brief psychotic disorder: Brief psychotic disorder is characterized by the sudden onset of psychotic symptoms, such as hallucinations, delusions, disorganized speech, or behavior, that last for less than one month. 

Related Pearl: Psychotic disorders

Differential diagnosis of DSM-5 psychotic disorders

Psychotic disorder

Sudden onset and a full return to function

Duration: > 1 day and < 1 month
Schizophreniform disorder

Same symptoms as schizophrenia and functional decline not required

Duration: > 1 month & < 6 months
Schizophrenia

Requires functional decline

At least 6 months (includes at least 1 month of active symptoms, can include prodromal and residual periods)

Delusional disorder

Shared psychotic disorder (folie a deux)

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of qSOFA score?
questions.solution:
Lactate dehydrogenase is not a component of the qSOFA score. 

qSOFA scoring is a simplified derivative of SOFA for bedside assessment that is particularly useful outside the ICU setting as it does not require laboratory values.

The qSOFA assigns one point for each component and suggests potentially life-threatening sepsis when at least two of the following parameters are met.

  • Altered mental status (GCS <15)
  • Systolic blood pressure ≤ 100 mmHg
  • Respiratory rate ≥ 22 breaths/min.

A qSOFA score of ≥2 is associated with a significant risk of death or prolonged ICU stay.

SOFA is a more comprehensive and accurate scoring system which is particularly superior to qSOFA in the ICU setting. This includes:

  • Circulation - Systolic BP & need for vasopressors and platelet count
  • Respiration - PaO2/FiO2 & need for mechanical ventilation
  • Mentation - Glasgow coma score
  • Hepatic function - Bilirubin
  • Renal function - Creatinine

Organ dysfunction is identified by a SOFA score of ≥ 2

questions.text: Which class of ovarian tumor does clear cell carcinoma of the ovary belong to?
questions.solution:
Clear cell carcinoma of the ovary is a type of epithelial cell tumor.

Epithelial ovarian tumors arise from the mesoepithelial cells present on the ovarian surface. 80% of all ovarian cancers are epithelial cancers.

Clear cell carcinoma is also known as mesonephroid tumor. The histopathology of clear cell carcinoma reveals large cuboidal epithelial cells with abundant clear cytoplasm characteristically forming tubules, glands, and small cystic spaces. These cystic spaces are lined by hobnail cells. They are clear cells showing large dark nuclei protruding into the lumen. It is a highly malignant tumor. 

Malignant epithelial tumors can spread widely via transcoelomic spread. It can spread through the capsule onto the peritoneal surface, omentum, intestinal viscera, and sub-diaphragmatic space. An ascitic tap will reveal blood-stained fluid with tumor cells. It may also spread to the para-aortic nodes and cause metastasis in the other ovary, liver, lungs, and gastrointestinal tract. 

Other options:

Option B: Teratomas are germ cell tumors. They contain embryonic tissues leading to the differentiation of cells along these pathways. There are three classes of teratomas:

  • Mature (benign) teratomas (eg: Dermoid cyst)
  • Immature (essentially malignant) teratomas (eg: solid teratoma)
  • Monodermal (highly specialized) tumors (eg: Struma ovarii)

Option C: Sex cord stromal tumors

  • Androgen-secreting tumors: Sertoli cell, Leydig, Hilus cell tumor
  • Estrogen-secreting tumors: Granulosa cell, Thecoma, Fibroma

Option D: Granulosa cell tumors arise from the sex cords of the gonads. They are solid and generally produce estrogen. They can cause precocious puberty in children, hyperestrogenism in adults, and post-menopausal bleeding. They vary in appearance and range from microscopic to large, solid and cystic, encapsulated masses. If hormonally active, they may be yellow due to intracellular lipids.

questions.text: Identify the following instrument used by obstetricians:
questions.solution:
The image shows Wrigley's forceps, which is an outlet forceps.

The instrument is light, about a third of the weight of ordinary long-curved forceps. The instrument is short which is due to a reduction in the length of the shanks and handles. It has a marked cephalic curve with a slight pelvic curve.

Criteria for outlet forceps delivery:

  1. Scalp at introitus without separating labia
  2. Skull at the pelvic floor
  3. Sagittal suture in anterioposterior diameter, right or left occiput anterior, occiput anterior
  4. Fetal head on the perineum
  5. Rotation less than 45 degrees

Related Pearl: Obstetrics forceps

Commonly used forceps: 

1) Simpson forceps

  • The most commonly used types of forceps in outlet delivery.
  • Has elongated cephalic curve.
  • These are used when there is substantial molding of the fetal head.

2) Elliot forceps

  • Has an adjustable pin for regulating the lateral pressure on the handles.
  • They are used most often when there is minimal molding.
  • More suitable for outlet delivery.

3) Kielland forceps

  • Has small pelvic curve and a sliding lock.
  • Suitable for head with little molding.
  • The most common forceps used for rotational delivery.
  • Helps correct asynclitism.

4) Piper forceps

  • Distinct perineal curve.
  • Allows for application to the after-coming head in breech delivery.

5) Tucker-McLane forceps

  • Suitable for fetal head with little molding.
  • Used in rotational delivery.

6) Barton forceps and traction handle

  • Used in rotational delivery.
  • Most importantly used for delivery of occipitotransverse positions in a platypelloid pelvis.
  • It is an obsolete procedure.

Related Pearl: Criteria for forceps delivery

Procedure Criteria
Outlet forceps
  • Scalp is visible at the introitus without separating the labia
  • Fetal skull has reached pelvic floor
  • Fetal head is at or on perineum
  • Sagittal suture is in anteroposteriordiameter or right or left occiput anterior or posterior position
  • Rotation does not exceed 45 degrees
Low forceps Leading point of fetal skull is at station > +2 cm and not on the pelvic floor:
a) Rotation is 45 degrees or less, or
b) Rotation is greater than 45 degrees
Mid forceps Station of fetal head is between 0 and +2 cm.

High forceps

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy presents to the clinic with complaints of a painless lump on the lateral aspect of his left knee. The radiograph of the patient is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given radiograph and clinical vignette suggest the diagnosis of osteochondroma. 

Osteochondromas are benign bone tumors that present commonly in the adolescent age group. They usually present as painless masses in long bones like the femur or humerus. They are seen as well-defined bony protuberances which may be pedunculated or sessile. Pedunculated osteochondromas point away from the joint, towards the diaphysis. The cortex and cancellous bone of osteochondroma blend with that of the host bone. MRI shows a classical cartilaginous cap.

Osteochondromas usually grow with skeletal maturity and stop once growth stops. They rarely undergo malignant transformation.

Treatment is not indicated if the lesion does not produce symptoms. Excision can be done for large lesions with local pressure effects.

Other options:

Option A: Enchondroma is an intramedullary tumor of hyaline cartilage. They are asymptomatic and discovered incidentally. They are usually seen in individuals aged 20 to 50 years, in the tubular bones of the hands and feet. Radiographically, it appears as a central lesion with well-defined, rounded, edges and a thin rind of reactive sclerosis.

Option B: Chondroblastoma is a benign tumor and presents as a painful mass that causes effusion or stiffness. On x-ray, they are seen as round or oval lytic lesions in the epiphysis. The bony cortex is not breached but can appear expanded. The common sites are the ends of long bones. Microscopically, chondroblastoma consists of a sheet of chondroblasts embedded in the chondroid matrix. The calcification is often present and surrounds individual cells giving the appearance of ‘chicken wire.’

Option D: Giant cell tumor or osteoclastoma is a benign but locally aggressive tumor. It usually affects young adults with a peak incidence in the age group of 20–45 years. It presents as a painful mass. A plain radiograph reveals an eccentric, expansile, lobulated lytic lesion(Soap bubble appearance) in the epiphysis. There is minimal calcification within the tumor. Biopsy reveals osteoclast-like giant cells scattered among round or spindle-shaped mononuclear cells.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presented with difficulty in activities like climbing stairs, getting up from a chair, and combing hair.  Violaceous erythema of the upper eyelids was noted. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presence of upper eyelid lilac erythema is suggestive of heliotrope rash. This along with the clinical presentation suggestive of proximal myopathy points toward a diagnosis of dermatomyositis. Dermatomyositis has a predilection for proximal > distal muscle involvement.

Classic cutaneous signs in dermatomyositis:

  • Heliotrope rash/ eyelid erythema- violaceous erythema of the upper eyelids. Pathognomonic of dermatomyositis.
  • V sign- confluent macular erythema over the lower anterior neck and upper anterior chest
  • Shawl sign- confluent macular erythema over the upper back and lateral aspect of arms
  • Gottron’s papules- erythematous papules and plaques over the extensor surface of the metacarpophalangeal and interphalangeal joints. Pathognomonic of dermatomyositis.
  • Gottron's sign- erythematous rash over the extensor surfaces of joints such as the knuckles, elbows, knees, and ankles
  • Mechanic’s hands- rough, hyperkeratotic lines on the lateral and palmer areas of the fingers
  • Scalp erythema and hair loss
  • Facial rash- confluent erythema in the malar distribution involving the cheeks, nasal bridge, and nasolabial folds
  • Nail fold changes
  • Flagellate erythema- linear erythema on the upper back with pruritus
  • Poikiloderma- mottled pattern of hyperpigmented and hypopigmented macules with telangiectasias
  • Cutaneous calcinosis- accumulation of calcium deposits in the skin

Facial rash in dermatomyositis-

Eyelid erythema/ heliotrope rash in dermatomyositis-

V- sign in dermatomyositis-

Shawl sign in dermatomyositis-

Flagellate erythema in dermatomyositis-

Gottron papules in dermatomyositis-

Poikilodermatous changes in dermatomyositis-

 

Option A: Inclusion body myositis involves both proximal and distal muscles with a predilection for finger/wrist flexors/knee extensors. It is characterized by asymmetric weakness of wrist and finger flexors in arms and quadriceps in legs. Dysphagia is also commonly seen. It is common in adults >50 years of age. Creatinine kinase levels are normal or slightly elevated. Antibodies against 5' nucleotidase are seen in the blood. 

Option C: Polymyositis is one of the inflammatory myopathies characterized by symmetric and proximal muscle weakness. This weakness usually worsens over several weeks to months. It is more common in women. Most patients improve with immunotherapies, but they require lifelong treatment. Elevated levels of creatinine kinase (CK) and muscle biopsy showing non-specific inflammatory cells in perimysium locations are seen.

Option D: Thickened and indurated skin, called scleroderma, is the distinguishing hallmark of systemic sclerosis. Systemic sclerosis is an autoimmune disease of unknown etiology, complex pathogenesis, and variable clinical presentations. The skin manifestation is described salt-and-pepper appearance. Other features include Raynaud's phenomenon, sclerodactyly, vasculopathic ulcers over the bony prominences, severe flexion contractures, and expressionless facies.

questions.text: A soldier presents to a referral hospital one day after sustaining a high-velocity shrapnel injury to his right thigh. He complains of severe pain at the wound site. On examination, crepitus is present. Which of the following organisms is the most likely cause of his condition?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in the given clinical scenario is gas gangrene/ clostridial myonecrosis, which is caused by clostridium perfringens.

Military wounds provide an ideal environment for gas gangrene as the kinetic energy of high-velocity missiles or shrapnel causes extensive tissue damage. Patients who are immunocompromised, diabetic, or have malignant disease are also at greater risk. The usual incubation period is <24 hours of injury.

Gas gangrene wound infections are associated with severe local wound pain and crepitus (gas in the tissues). The wound produces a thin, brown, sweet-smelling exudate, in which Gram staining will reveal bacteria. Edema and spreading gangrene occur due to the release of collagenase, hyaluronidase, other proteases, and alpha-toxin. Early systemic complications like circulatory collapse and organ failure can occur without adequate treatment.

Management includes high doses of intravenous penicillin and aggressive debridement of affected tissues. Amputations should be performed under antibiotic prophylaxis.

Other options:

C. difficile, a gram-positive anaerobic bacillus, causes Clostridioides (formerly Clostridium) difficile infection (CDI) after ingestion of spores of the organism. The more severe form of the condition is known as pseudomembranous colitis (PMC). It is most commonly associated with prolonged antimicrobial use which interferes with the commensal colonic microflora. The most commonly implicated antibiotics are cephalosporins, ampicillin, and clindamycin.

questions.text: Which of the following will not have bilateral hydronephrosis?
questions.solution:
Retrocaval ureter does not lead to bilateral hydronephrosis.

Circumcaval or retrocaval ureter is a developmental anomaly of the inferior vena cava (IVC). It is due to abnormal development of the right supracardinal system. There is a persistent right posterior cardinal vein that ends up passing in front of the ureter. The anomaly always occurs on the right side, as this is the side of the normal IVC.

The given image shows a right-sided fish hook or S-shaped ureter. It describes the appearance of a retrocaval ureter as the right ureter hooks behind the IVC.

Related Pearl: Causes of Hydronephrosis

Unilateral hydronephrosis

Extramural obstruction

  • Tumor from adjacent structures, e.g., cervix, prostate, rectum, colon, or cecum
  • Retrocaval ureter

Intramural obstruction

  • Congenital stenosis
  • Ureterocele
  • PUJ obstruction
  • Congenital small ureteric orifice
  • Inflammatory stricture following removal of ureteric calculus, repair of a damaged ureter, or tuberculous infection
  • Neoplasm of the ureter or bladder cancer involving the ureteric orifice

Intraluminal obstruction

  • Calculus in the pelvis or ureter
  • Sloughed papilla in papillary necrosis (especially, in patients with diabetes, analgesic abuse, or sickle cell disease)

Bilateral hydronephrosis

Congenital:

  • Posterior urethral valves (associated with pulmonary hypoplasia)
  • Urethral atresia
  • PUJ obstruction

Acquired:     

  • Benign prostatic hypertrophy or carcinoma of the prostate
  • Idiopathic retroperitoneal fibrosis (Ormond's disease)
  • Postoperative bladder neck scarring
  • Urethral stricture
  • Phimosis

questions.text: An 80-year-old female patient was brought to the casualty with a history of slip and fall in the bathroom. She is having pain in the left hip and is unable to walk. She has no history of osteoarthritis. On examination, the left lower limb is shortened and externally rotated. X-ray findings are shown below.  How will you manage this patient?
questions.solution:
The above clinical vignette along with with the X-ray is suggestive of a fracture of the neck of the femur and hemiarthroplasty is the best way to manage this patient.

Clinical features of a fracture of the neck of the femur:

  • Painful movements of the hip joint
  • Shortening and external rotation of the affected limb
  • Tenderness in the hip 
  • Active straight leg raising is not possible

A plain radiograph of a fracture of the neck of the femur may show the following features:

  • Fracture line in the neck of the femur
  • External rotation of the femur with the lesser trochanter appearing more prominent
  • Displacement of the greater trochanter
  • Break in the trabecular stream
  • Break in Shenton's line

Management:

  • If the age is <65 years and if the patient presents within 3 weeks, then closed reduction with internal fixation with cancellous screws(Option A) is done.
  • If a patient <65 years of age presents after 3 weeks, the vascular supply of the femur head is assessed by bone scanning or MRI. If it is vascular, the hip should be reconstructed by either osteotomy (McMurray's or Pauwel's)(Option D), or reconstruction procedures such as Meyers' operation(option B). If the head is not vascular, and the patient is young, the bipolar prosthesis(Hemiarthroplasty) is preferred.
  • If the age of the patient is >65 years, then hemiarthroplasty(bipolar prosthesis) is preferred only if the acetabulum is normal(no osteoarthritis), otherwise, total hip replacement is done.

Related Pearl: Treatment of fracture neck of femur

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presented with unexplained fever and prolonged respiratory distress despite appropriate treatment. A diagnosis of cryptic tuberculosis was made. Which of the following is the correct statement related to this condition?

choices.text: Negative skin tuberculin test and negative chest X-ray
Positive skin tuberculin test and positive chest X-ray
Positive skin tuberculin test and negative chest X-ray
Negative skin tuberculin test and positive chest X-ray

questions.solution:
The true statement about cryptic tuberculosis is a negative skin tuberculin test and a negative chest X-ray.

Cryptic disseminated TB refers to patients who have disseminated TB with less “typical” chest radiographic abnormalities, including normal and non-miliary patterns. It has an insidious onset that mainly affects the middle-aged and elderly. There are no localizing signs, absence of choroidal tubercles, normal chest x-rays, and negative tuberculin skin test.

It was found that the presence of underlying diseases such as HIV infection, chronic renal disease, diabetes, immunosuppression, and endocrine disorders alter the typical presentation, which often delays or leads to a missed diagnosis of cryptic tuberculosis.

questions.text: A chronic smoker presented with bilateral pitting pedal edema, and abdominal distension. On examination, he had ascites and auscultation revealed an S3.  Which of the following defects can be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of bilateral pedal edema, abdominal distention, S3 heart sound are suggestive of right ventricular (RV) failure. The history of chronic smoking suggests that the patient is suffering from chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)which results in cor pulmonale. Tricuspid regurgitation may be the underlying valvular defect in this patient.

The main pathophysiology behind cor pulmonale is pulmonary hypertension and increased right ventricular (RV) afterload which is sufficient to cause RV dilation with or without hypertrophy. This alters both the structure and function of the RV. In parenchymal lung diseases, primary pulmonary vascular disorders, or chronic hypoxia, the pulmonary vessels undergo vascular remodeling, vasoconstriction, and destruction leading to increased pulmonary artery pressures and increased RV afterload.

Anatomically, the right ventricle is thin-walled, compliant, and can handle volume overload better than pressure overload. Sustained pressure overload eventually leads to RV dysfunction and failure.

Dyspnea is the most common symptom. Other symptoms include pedal edema, abdominal distension due to ascites, the murmur of tricuspid regurgitation, an S3 gallop, and a palpable RV heave along the left sternal border. The jugular venous pressures (JVP) are elevated with prominent v waves indicative of tricuspid regurgitation. Other features include hepatomegaly, pulsatile liver, tenderness in the right upper quadrant, and pitting pedal edema.

The ECG in severe pulmonary hypertension shows P-pulmonale, right axis deviation, and RV hypertrophy. Spirometry and lung volumes show obstructive and/or restrictive defects seen in parenchymal lung diseases. Echo can be used to measure RV wall thickness and chamber dimensions, while doppler ECHO can be used to assess pulmonary artery pressures. Cardiac catheterization confirms the diagnosis of pulmonary hypertension and can exclude elevated left-sided pressures as a cause of heart failure.

questions.text: An elderly male on bed rest for many months presented with breathlessness and chest pain. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of acute pulmonary embolism (PE) most likely due to deep vein thrombosis(DVT). This patient's immobility puts him at an increased risk of DVT. Pulmonary angiogram is the principal imaging test for diagnosis.

Clinically, patients present with sudden onset of dyspnea, syncope, chest pain, and hypotension. Associated clinical features are tachycardia, and tachypnea.

Investigations: 

CT of the chest with intravenous contrast(CT pulmonary angiogram) is the principal imaging test for the diagnosis of PE. It also helps to visualize the chambers of the heart. It can also help in identifying alternative diagnoses like emphysema, pulmonary fibrosis, pulmonary mass, etc.

Lung scanning is the second-line diagnostic test for PE, used in patients who cannot tolerate intravenous contrast. Perfusion scan defect indicates absent or decreased blood flow.

ECG changes in acute PE are characterized by the classic S1Q3T3 changes, due to right ventricular strain and ischemia:

  • A prominent S wave in lead I 
  • Q wave in lead III 
  • An inverted T wave in lead III

It is an insensitive sign but specific.

Echocardiography- It is a non-reliable diagnostic imaging tool. Most patients with PE have a normal echocardiogram, therefore, it is not a reliable test. However, it can be used to detect other conditions that commonly mimic PE like acute myocardial infarction, pericardial tamponade, and aortic dissection. McConnell's sign is one of the indirect findings on echo. It is hypokinesis of the right ventricular free wall with the hyperkinetic or normal motion of the right ventricular apex.

Treatment includes anticoagulation: parenteral unfractionated heparin, low molecular weight heparin, or fondaparinux with bridging to warfarin or parenteral therapy switched to a direct thrombin inhibitor such as dabigatran or oral anticoagulants(anti-Xa agents) such as rivaroxaban or apixaban followed by maintenance therapy.

Related Pearl: Investigation of Choice in Respiratory Diseases

Disease Investigation of choice
Interstitial lung disease HRCT
Bronchiectasis HRCT
Pulmonary embolism CT Pulmonary Angiography > Ventilation-Perfusion Scan
Calcification CT
Solitary pulmonary nodule CT > PET
Lung Malignancy CT scan
Superior sulcus tumor MRI scan > CT scan

Related Pearl: Clinical prediction for pulmonary embolism: Well’s and Modified Well’s criteria and PERC

 

Variable Points
Clinical symptoms and signs of DVT (leg swelling and pain with palpation of deep veins) 3.0
Alternative diagnosis less likely than PE 3.0
Heart rate > 100 beats/min 1.5

High > 6.0

Modified Wells criteria Score
PE likely > 4.0
PE unlikely < or = 4.0

In cases where, modified Well's criteria <4, in order to rule out pulmonary embolism the following criteria must be met.

Pulmonary embolism rule out criteria (PERC):

  • Age < 50 years
  • Heart rate < 100 bpm
  • Oxyhemoglobin saturation on room air ≥ 95%
  • No prior history of venous thromboembolism
  • No recent (within 4 weeks) trauma or surgery requiring hospitalization
  • No presenting hemoptysis
  • No estrogen therapy
  • No unilateral leg swelling

Related Pearl: Chest X Ray signs in pulmonary embolism

Westermark's sign- Area of focal oligemia

Chest radiograph reveals an engorged pulmonary trunk with an abrupt cutoff of pulmonary vascularity in the distal portions bilaterally, indicative of the "Westermark sign" (arrows).

 

 

 

Hampton's hump- A peripheral wedged-shaped density above the diaphragm with convexity towards hilum.

 

 

 

 

Palla's sign- enlarged right descending pulmonary artery

Chest x-ray on a PA projection that shows focal relative oligemia of the right upper lung (Westermark's sign, circle), in contrast to significantly dilated right descending pulmonary artery, with a “sausage-like” appearance (Palla's sign, arrow)

 

 

 

Remember- A normal or nearly normal chest x-ray often occurs in PE.

questions.text: What is the most common symptom of cannabis intake?
questions.solution:
The most common symptom of cannabis intake is a dream-like state.

After cannabis intake users have feelings of mild euphoria, relaxation, and perceptual alterations. Cognitive changes include impaired short-term memory and attention. The user feels lost in a pleasant dreamy state and has difficulty sustaining goal-directed mental activity.

Anxiety, decreased appetite, and depressed mood are the symptoms seen in cannabis withdrawal symptoms. Other withdrawal symptoms include irritability, insomnia, nervousness, and weight loss.
