questions.text: A young patient presents with a severe headache. He has never experienced a headache of this severity before. He has hypertension and nuchal rigidity on examination. Which of the following could be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical manifestations of neck stiffness and severe headache (like never before) suggests a diagnosis of subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH).

Subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) is the bleeding into the subarachnoid space, which is the area between the arachnoid membrane and the pia mater surrounding the brain. The diagnosis is suspected when a hyperattenuating material is seen filling the subarachnoid space. Most commonly this is apparent around the circle of Willis, on account of the majority of berry aneurysms occurring in this region, or in the Sylvian fissure.

Young males with a history of spontaneous sudden onset severe headaches with seizures should raise suspicion for subarachnoid hemorrhage (aneurysmal). The most common cause of SAH is head trauma and the second common cause is the rupture of a saccular aneurysm.

Symptoms include:

  • Severe headache (thunderclap headache)
  • Rapid onset vomiting
  • Confusion or a lowered level of consciousness
  • Seizures
  • Neck stiffness or neck pain

 

Other options:

Cluster headache is a rare form of primary headache. It is characterized by deep excruciating pain that is usually retroorbital, and unilateral. It usually lasts for short duration of 8-10 weeks a year followed by a pain-free interval. It is associated with lacrimation, rhinorrhoea, and ptosis. In acute cases, oxygen therapy is useful. Subcutaneous and nasal sumatriptan can be used.

The classic clinical triad of fever, headache, and neck rigidity is suggestive of meningitis. Other common complaints are nausea, vomiting, and photophobia. Nuchal rigidity (“stiff neck”) is the pathognomonic sign of meningitis. Hip and knee flexion on passive flexion of the neck is called Brudzinsky's sign.

Encephalitis presents similar to meningitis with fever, altered mental status, and focal or diffuse neurological symptoms.

Related Pearl: Intracranial haemorrhage

questions.text: All of the following are true about nephroblastoma except:

choices.text: Treatment is chemotherapy followed by surgery
Most common intraabdominal malignancy in children

questions.solution:
Neuroblastoma, not nephroblastoma, is the most common intraabdominal malignancy in children.

Wilms tumor/nephroblastoma is an embryonal renal neoplasm. It is usually diagnosed before the age of five. Wilms tumor is caused by abnormal renal development, resulting in the proliferation of the metanephric blastema.

Children may present with a mass abdomen, fever, and hematuria, which is indicative of the extension of the tumor into the renal pelvis. Hypertension is also observed in a considerable percentage of patients.

Prognostic factors for Wilms tumor:

  • Histology
  • Stage
  • Age
  • Tumor weight
  • Response to therapy
  • Loss of heterozygosity at 1p and 16q 

The two most important factors are the histology and the stage of the tumor.

Most of the tumors have favorable histology and are characterized as the “classic” type that consists of three components—blastemal, stromal, and epithelial (tubules) tissues. 

Unfavorable tumors are those with focal or diffuse anaplasia. Two principal staging systems are used:

  • The COG system is based on findings prior to the initiation of treatment. There exists a local stage and a disease stage. The local stage defines the extent of abdominal disease while the disease stage considers both local disease and metastasis. Metastasis commonly occurs in the lungs.
  • The SIOP classification is based on the histologic appearance of the tumors at resection and the outcomes. They are classified as completely necrotic (low risk), blastemal (high risk) and other histological types.

Imaging with USG abdomen and pelvis, CT scan, MRI etc., shows a solid space-occupying lesion in the kidney.

Management is mainly by chemotherapy and nephrectomy. 

                 Neuroblastoma               Nephroblastoma (Wilm’s tumor) 
In children Most common abdominal malignancy  Most common renal malignancy (2nd most common abdominal malignancy) 
Origin Neural crest cells arising from an adrenal gland or paravertebral sympathetic ganglia (extrarenal)  Intrarenal origin is seen due to undifferentiated mesoderm 
Gene mutation N-myc amplification WT-1, WT-2; Associated with WAGR syndrome, Beckwith Weidman syndrome
Age  Peak at 5 years of age Seen around 2-4 years of age
C/F Painful, fixed abdominal mass - crossing the midline Painless, mobile abdomen mass that does not cross the midline along with hematuria
Constitutional symptoms Present like raccoon eyes, blueberry muffin lesion, opsoclonus-myoclonus syndrome Absent
Tumor margin Poorly marginated mass; Homer-Wright rosettes seen on HPE; Drooping lily sign on IVP Well-circumscribed mass - 'claw sign' seen on IVP/CECT
Intratumor calcification Common  Rare, seen along the peripheries
Vascular involvement It encases the vessels but do not invade them - elevates the aorta from the vertebral column  Dispaces the adjacent structures with vascular invasion along renal veins/ IVC (not considered metastasis) 
Metastasis Long bones, skull, liver. Lung mets are rarely seen.  Lungs > lymph nodes

questions.text: Identify the structure marked in the image given below.
questions.solution:
The structure marked in the MRI of the brain is the Internal capsule.

The image below shows parts of the brain in an axial section of an MRI.

The internal capsule is a component of the white matter of the brain. They contain projection fibers. It can be divided into the following parts:

  • Anterior limb
  • Genu
  • Posterior limb
  • Retrolenticular/retrolentiform portion
  • Sublenticular/sublentiform portion

The anterior limb of the internal capsule carries the fronto-pontine fibers, a lesion here produces confusion, impaired attention, agitation, and dysarthria.

Genu carries fibers of the corticonuclear tract. 

The posterior limb of the internal capsule carries cortico-spinal motor fibers in the anterior part and the lesion here produces contralateral hemiparesis. The posterior part of the posterior limb carries sensory fibers and lesions here may produce contralateral hemi-sensory deficits.

The retro-lenticular part carries fibers mainly from optic radiation. A lesion here produces homonymous hemianopia, superior quadrantanopia, or inferior quadrantanopia.

The sub-lenticular part contains temporopontine and some parietopontine fibers.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presents with painless hematuria. He is diagnosed with bladder cancer involving the muscle layer. What is the next best step in the treatment of this patient?
questions.solution:
Radical cystectomy is the preferred mode of management for a patient with bladder cancer involving the muscle layer.

Smoking and exposure to chemicals are strongly associated with the development of bladder cancer. 

Activation of oncogenes such as ras, c-erbB, E2F3, and inactivation of tumor-suppressor genes such as p53, p21, p16, and Rb gene is implicated in the cancer formation of the bladder.

Clinical features of bladder carcinoma include:

  • Painless gross haematuria - Most common symptom and is indicative of a bladder carcinoma until proven otherwise
  • Urinary retention
  • Constant pelvic pain
  • Increased urinary frequency
  • Discomfort while urinating
  • If there is nerve involvement, pain is referred to the suprapubic region, groins, perineum, and thighs.

Investigations done for bladder cancer are:

  • Urine cytology - Low sensitivity
  • Intravenous urography, non-contrast CT, and MRI show a filling defect.
  • Cystourethroscopy and biopsy - Mainstay for diagnosis.

 The most important prognostic factor in bladder carcinoma is the depth of invasion. 

Management:

  • Non-muscle invasive bladder cancer:
    • ​​Intravesical instillations of a chemotherapeutic agent such as mitomycin C or epirubicin
    • Regular cystoscopic check-ups and repeat biopsy if required
    • Immunotherapy with regular intravesical instillations of Bacille Calmette Guerin (BCG)
  • Muscle invasive bladder cancer:
  • Systemic chemotherapy with a combination of drugs – cisplatin, methotrexate, doxorubicin, and vinblastine (M-VAC) or cisplatin along with gemcitabine is given before radical cystectomy(neoadjuvant).
  • Radical cystectomy along with urinary diversion procedure and lymph node dissection +/- neoadjuvant chemotherapy.
  • Radical beam external radiotherapy is also used for invasive bladder cancer.

questions.text: A male patient presented with complaints of hematuria and recurrent urinary tract infection. You notice the following finding in his CECT.  What is the likely condition indicated by the arrow in the image?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a horseshoe kidney. It is prone to obstruction, reflux, and stone formation.

Horseshoe kidney is the most common congenital anomaly of the kidneys. Horseshoe kidneys are a type of renal fusion anomaly. They are formed when the lower poles of the two kidneys fuse during organogenesis to form an isthmus. They are typically low-lying as the inferior mesenteric artery interferes with its ascent due to its size and the presence of an isthmus. 

It presents as a fixed, nonmobile, firm mass in the midline at the level of the 4th lumbar vertebra and is resonant on percussion. It is associated with an increased risk of infection, stone formation, hydronephrosis, and tuberculosis.

It has a 2:1 male preponderance. Individuals with horseshoe kidneys are prone to reflux, obstruction, and stone formation.

Other options:

Option A: The image of polycystic kidney disease on CT abdomen is shown below: Multiple bilateral cysts are seen.

Option C: Hydronephrosis is aseptic dilatation of the pelvicalyceal system due to partial or intermittent obstruction to urinary outflow.

Option D: Pancake kidney (also known as discoid kidney, disc kidney, lump kidney, fused pelvic kidney, or cake kidney) is a rare renal fusion anomaly where both the upper and lower poles of the kidney are fused giving it an appearance of a pancake. The MRI image of the pancake kidney is shown below: 

Related Pearl: IVU signs and associated conditions

Medullary sponge kidney 

  • Bouquet of flowers/ paintbrush appearance
  • It refers to the cystic dilatation of the distal collecting tubules

Duplex kidney

  • Drooping lily sign
  • It refers to the inferolateral displacement of the lower pole due to an obstructed upper pole in a duplicated collecting system

Horseshoe kidney

  • Handshake sign - due to the position of the lower poles closer to the spine, and the lower calyces closer to each other
  • Flower vase sign - due to medially rotated calyces

Retroperitoneal fibrosis

  • Maiden waist deformity 
  • It refers to the medially drawn ureters caused by fibrosis at the lumbosacral junction

Retrocaval ureter 

  • Fish hook / Reverse J deformity 
  • Right ureter hooks behind the IVC as it passes posterior to it

Ureterocele

  • Cobra/ Adder head appearance
  • It refers to the dilation of the distal ureter

Transitional cell carcinoma of the ureter

  • Goblet sign
  • It is due to the focal dilation of the ureter by an intraluminal mass

questions.text: Confidentiality is maintained in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Confidentiality is always maintained during counselling.

Confidentiality is defined as the state of being private- maintaining the patients’ privacy by restricting access to personal and confidential information. It is always implied between the doctor and his patient. The doctor is obliged to keep secret, all that he comes to know concerning the patient in the course of his professional work.

It assumes that without confidentiality, patients will not reveal everything during a consultation, especially intimate details, due to which the clinical history may be deficient or even misleading. The responsibility of the attending physician in this regard is very great because he has the confidence of the patient. The patient will discuss and listen more readily, making counselling more easier if they are assured that the conversations will be kept confidential.

An example of this is counselling individuals with HIV/ AIDS. With a confidential dialogue between a person and a counsellor enables the person to explore the risk of HIV infection, cope with stress and make personal decisions to deal with the disease.

Group discussions, panel discussions and seminars are group approaches to health education and would not involve the question of confidentiality.

questions.text: According to the law, nothing is an offence if a person is of an unsound mind and is not able to understand that the nature and consequences of his/her act are wrong. Which rule of insanity applies in this case?
questions.solution:
Mc Naughten’s rule is the correct answer. Mc Naughten’s rule states “Nothing is an offence which is done by a person who at the time of doing it by reason of unsoundness of mind is incapable of knowing the nature of the act, or that he is doing what is either wrong or contrary to law”.

  • The rules are:
    • McNaughten's rule states that every man is to be presumed to be sane, and possesses a sufficient degree of reason to be responsible for his crimes until the contrary is proved.
    • To establish an insanity defense, it must be clearly proved that, at the time of the committing of the act, the accused was laboring under ‘such a defect of reason, from a disease of the mind, as not to know the nature and quality of the act he was doing; or if he did know it, that he did not know he was doing what was wrong’.

Other options:

Options A and C: Durham's rule and Curren's rule are the other tests for insanity.

Durhams's rule states that an accused person is not criminally responsible if his unlawful act is the product of mental disease or mental defect.

Curren’s rule states that an accused person is not criminally responsible if, at the time of committing the act, he did not have the capacity to regulate his conduct to the requirements of the law as a result of mental disease or defect.

Option D: Irresistible impulse test- This rule is similar to Curren's rule. 

Related Pearl: IPC Sec 84, McNaughten's rule

McNaughten's rule, Section 84 IPC:  Criminal responsibility of the insane.

It states that an accused is not criminally responsible if he was suffering from:

  • Defect of reason and unsoundness of mind: the law recognizes only those diseases which impair the thinking abilities of the mind. So, not all medically insane people are legally insane, as emotional disturbances that affect the mind are not considered if they do not directly affect cognition.
  • That he did not know the nature and the quality of the act he is doing:  the law needs the unsoundness of mind to exist at the time of the act to such a degree that the person is not aware of what he is doing and whether it is right or wrong to do. Absence of a motive or forethought is also considered as a criteria for determining unsoundness of mind.

McNaughten’s rule now comes under Section 22 of the Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita, 2023.

questions.text: Resistance of the tube shown below is primarily because of :
questions.solution:
The airway device shown in the image is an endotracheal tube and the resistance to the airflow through it primarily depends on diameter(Internal diameter).

  • The size of an endotracheal tube usually refers to the internal diameter in mm. Rarely the French scale is used where the size corresponds to the external diameter multiplied by 3.
  • For adults, usually, a 7-mm is used for women and a 7.5 or 8-mm ETT is used for men.
  • Generally, high-volume, low-pressure cuffed tubes are used in adults, and cuffless tubes are used in neonates and infants.
  • Besides age, the choice of an endotracheal tube also depends on the presence of airway pathologies and the reason behind the placement of the tube.
  • Smaller-sized tubes lead to increase airway resistance and increased work breathing.
  • Larger tubes have a higher risk of laryngeal and tracheal trauma and sore throat.
Age Internal diameter (mm) Length (cm)
Full term infant 3.5 12
Child 4  + (Age/4)    12 + (Age/2)
Adult female 7.0–7.5

questions.text: Bell's palsy involves_______

choices.text: Ipsilateral upper and lower halves of the face.
Contralateral upper and lower halves of the face.
Ipsilateral lower half of the face.
Contralateral lower half of the face.

questions.solution:
Bell's palsy involves the ipsilateral upper and lower halves of the face.

Bell's palsy is a lower motor neuron lesion of the facial nerve and involves the ipsilateral side of the upper and lower halves of the face. Bell's palsy is an idiopathic, peripheral facial paralysis, or paresis of acute onset.

If the patient attempts to close the eye, the eyeball would turn up and out - this is known as the Bell's phenomenon. Decreased tearing, hyperacusis, taste disturbances, otalgia, weakness of the facial muscles, poor eyelid closure, etc can be seen. When the patient smiles, the face becomes distorted and lateralizes to the side opposite the palsy. Flattening of the forehead and nasolabial fold on the side affected by palsy. 

Treatment of Bell's palsy involves prednisone 60-80 mg daily during the first 5 days and then tapered over the next 5 days. The use of artificial tears and covering the eye at night prevents corneal drying.

The image below shows that the right half of this patient's face is weak and the right facial nerve is affected.

questions.text: Which of the following is a first-line antitubercular drug prescribed in the initial 2 months of treatment?
questions.solution:
The first-line antitubercular drug prescribed in the initial 2 months of treatment among the following is ethambutol.

All newly diagnosed cases are treated for a total duration of 6 months given in 2 phases. This includes 2 months of intensive phase and 4 months of continuation phase.

  • Intensive phase- 8 weeks of isoniazid (H), rifampicin (R), pyrazinamide (Z) and ethambutol (E) given under direct observation in daily dosages.
  • Continuation phase- 16 weeks of isoniazid, rifampicin and ethambutol in daily dosages. This phase may be extended by 12-24 weeks in certain forms of TB like CNS TB, skeletal TB, disseminated TB etc.

Related Pearl: ATT Regimen for TB Patients

As per the latest recommendations from National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme (NTEP), treatment of TB is now based primarily on drug susceptibility testing. This is irrespective of new cases, previously treated cases or recurrent TB cases. 
All cases of TB are treated with Drug Sensitive TB Regimen, as long as the patient is sensitive to isoniazid and rifampicin. (No classification into category I or II)

Type of TB Case Intensive Phase Continuation Phase
New and previously treated cases (H and R sensitive) 2 months H R Z E 4 months H R E

Classification based on drug resistance. 

The cases are classified as:

  • Mono-resistant (MR): A TB patient, who is resistant to one 1st line anti-TB drug only.
  • Poly-Drug Resistant (PDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to more than one 1st line anti-TB drug, other than Rifampicin. 
  • Rifampicin Resistant (RR): A TB patient, who is resistant to rifampicin with or without resistance to other drugs. Patients, who have rifampicin resistance, should be managed as if they are an MDR TB case.
  • Multi-Drug Resistant (MDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to both isoniazid and rifampicin.
  • Extensively Drug-Resistant (XDR): A MDR TB patient who is additionally resistant to a fluoroquinolone (ofloxacin, levofloxacin, or moxifloxacin) and at least one additional group A drug (as of 2021, these are bedaquiline and linezolid)

Standard DR TB regimen

Regimen class Drugs Comments
H mono-resistant/ poly-drug resistant TB regimen Lfx R E Z for 6 months

6 months long

Oral drugs only
Shorter MDR TB regimen

Intensive Phase:

Mfx Bdq(6 months) Cfz Z Hh E Eto for 4-6 months

Continuation phase:

Mfx Cfz Z E for 5 months

9-11 months long totally

Injectables used in Intensive phase.
Longer MDR TB regimen Bdq(6 months or longer) Lfx Lzd Cfz Cs 

18-20 months long

Oral drugs only

This regimen is used for XDR TB patients for 20 months.

 

Criteria for patients to receive standard Drug Resistant TB regimen:

Standard Drug Resistant TB regimen Inclusion criteria Exclusion criteria
H mono-resistant/poly-drug resistant TB regimen Isoniazid resistant TB with rifampicin sensitive No specific criteria
Shorter MDR TB regimen Patient with rifampicin resistant pulmonary or extra pulmonary TB Non drug sensitivity test based criteria:
  • Pregnancy
  • Any extra pulmonary disease in PLHIV
  • Disseminated meningeal or central nervous system TB
  • Intolerance to any drug in the shorter MDR TB regimen
Drug sensitivity test based criteria:
  • If DST/DRT result for FQ or SLI is resistant (XDR TB)
  • Presence of InhA mutation
  • Resistant to Z

Legend

Related Pearl: Key points on the first line drugs used in the treatment of TB

Drugs Isoniazid Rifamycins Pyrazinamide Ethambutol
Mechanism of action Blocks mycolic acid synthesis. Inhibition of RNA polymerase, leading to the inhibition of RNA synthesis. Inhibition of fatty acid synthase-I, leading to the inhibition of the cell membrane. Inhibition of arabinosyl transferase, leading to a reduction in arabinogalactan needed for the cell wall.
Unique side effects

Shoulder hand syndrome and CNS side effects.

 Orange urine, sweat, and tears. Flu-like symptoms with intermittent dosing.

The most hepatotoxic drug. It also causes hyperuricemia.

Optic neuritis and hence, not preferred in children.
Mechanism of resistance

Kat G mutation- the most severe form of resistance.

Inh a gene overexpression-  confers cross-resistance with ethionamide.

Mutation in rpoB- the gene coding for the β subunit of RNA polymerase.

 Mutation of the Pnca gene.

Mutations in the embB gene.

questions.text: Involvement of which of the following structures leads to the clinical presentation as shown in the image?
questions.solution:
The peau d'orange appearance of the breast occurs due to the blockade of superficial lymphatics.

The dermal lymphatic blockade gives rise to edema in the breast. The sweat glands and hair follicles get buried due to the edema resulting in a typical orange peel appearance. Infiltration of the ligaments of Cooper results in dimpling of the skin. Infiltration of the lactiferous glands gives rise to retraction of the nipple. Spread into the chest wall results in fixation of the breast into the chest wall. This leads to restricted mobility of the breast.  

Spread to the axillary lymph nodes can give rise to lymphedema. Venous edema of the upper limb develops due to the compression of the axillary vein on lymph nodes. 

Related Pearl: Hormonal therapy in breast carcinoma given for ER/PR-positive cases

Role:

  • Reduce risk of recurrence
  • Reduce risk of contralateral breast cancer
  • Reduce risk of progression of in situ to invasive carcinoma

  • Tamoxifen

  • Arzoxifen
  • Fenoxifen
  • Anastrazole
  • Letrozole
  • Exemestane

  • GnRH analogues

questions.text: You are administering an 8-month-old infant with vitamin A supplements over the course of 2 consecutive days. What is the recommended dose?
questions.solution:
This 8-month-old infant should receive 1,00,000 IU of vitamin A orally for 2 consecutive days.

Vitamin A stores in the body last 6-9 months. So a preventive strategy involves administering it to children to prevent the development of its deficiency.

  • For infants between 6-12 months - 100,000 IU orally
  • For a child above 12 months - 200,000 IU orally is given every 6 months.

The same dose of Vitamin A is repeated the next day in case of deficiency.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presented with excessive fatiguability towards the end of the day that improved with rest. He also gives a history of ptosis and difficulty in speech and swallowing. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features are suggestive of myasthenia gravis.

Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune neuromuscular junction disorder that is characterized by weakness and fatigability of skeletal muscles. It is due to the autoantibody-mediated destruction of the acetylcholine receptors (AChRs) at the post-synaptic membrane. This consequentially leads to a decreased transmission at the neuromuscular junction. Failure of transmission results in muscle weakness. Females are more commonly affected than males and the disease tends to occur in middle age.

Clinical features of myasthenia gravis:

  • Muscle weakness and fatiguability increase with repeated use or late in the day and may improve following rest or sleep. Limb weakness is proximal and asymmetrical
  • Cranial muscles particularly the lids and extraocular muscles are involved early in the course - diplopia, ptosis
  • Facial weakness - snarling expression on smiling
  • Weakness in chewing
  • Speech with nasal timbre due to the weakness of the palate and tongue
  • Difficulty in swallowing
  • Deep tendon reflexes are intact
  • Myasthenic crisis - acute exacerbation of muscle weakness especially intercostal and diaphragmatic muscles resulting in ventilatory failure. It is most commonly due to infection and anticholinesterase medication overuse.

Myasthenia gravis is associated with thymoma and other autoimmune diseases such as Hashimoto's thyroiditis, Graves' disease, neuromyelitis optics, and systemic lupus erythematosus.

Diagnosis:

  • Ice-pack test - application of ice pack over the eyes improves ptosis (decreases the activity of acetylcholinesterase, this increases the amount of acetylcholine in the synaptic cleft and increases transmission)
  • Antibodies associated with myasthenia gravis: Anti-AChR antibodies.
  • Repetitive nerve stimulation test shows a decremental response.
  • Edrophonium chloride or Tensilon test - improvement of symptoms occurs on injecting edrophonium. Edrophonium is an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor. This increases the amount of acetylcholine in the synaptic cleft and improves transmission.

Treatment:

  • Anticholinesterase drugs - Pyridostigmine, neostigmine, and ambenonium are the standard anticholinesterase drugs used in the symptomatic treatment of myasthenia gravis. All can increase the response of myasthenic muscle to repetitive nerve impulses, primarily by the preservation of endogenous acetylcholine.
  • Thymectomy
  • Immunosuppression therapy with glucocorticoids, azathioprine, tacrolimus, rituximab, etc.
  • Plasmapheresis and intravenous immunoglobulin
 Other options:

Option A: Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) is X-linked muscular dystrophy due to mutations in the dystrophin gene. It most commonly affects boys in their childhood. Patients initially present with proximal muscle weakness predominantly in the lower limbs. Calf muscle hypertrophy is a cardinal feature. Other features include mental retardation, cardiac failure, and myoglobinuria. Elevated serum creatinine kinase levels and genetic testing are diagnostic of DMD.

Option B: Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS) is an autoimmune disorder affecting the presynaptic membrane at the neuromuscular junction. Patients present with proximal muscle weakness of the lower limbs, ptosis, and diplopia. However, symptoms might improve after brief exercise. Deep tendon reflexes are absent or reduced. They also experience autonomic dysfunction and present with dry mouth and impotence. The repetitive nerve stimulation test shows an incremental response at higher rates. Treatment involves plasmapheresis, immunotherapy, and drugs such as 3,4-diamino pyridine (3,4-DAP) and pyridostigmine.
 
Option D: Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is an autoimmune disease that most commonly presents with arthralgia with early morning stiffness. It predominantly occurs in middle-aged women. Other important features of SLE include malar rash, discoid rash, photosensitivity, oral ulcers, pleuritis, pericarditis, and lupus nephritis. Anti-nuclear antibodies, Anti-dsDNA antibodies, and anti-Smith antibodies are positive in SLE.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common location of implantation in ectopic pregnancy?
questions.solution:
The most common location of implantation in ectopic pregnancy is the tubal ampulla, which is labeled as A in the image.

Almost 95% of ectopic pregnancies implant within the fallopian tube. Within the fallopian tube, the ampulla is the most commonly affected location in 70% of the cases. The remaining implant is in the isthmus (12%), fimbria (11%), and interstitial tube (2%). 

The other sites of implantations are the ovary (Option A), peritoneal cavity, cervix (Option B), or prior cesarean scar (Option C). 

Patients usually present with rupture of ectopic pregnancy with the triad of the delayed menstrual cycle, abdominal pain, and vaginal bleeding. 

The examination may reveal abdominal tenderness, pain in cervical motion, a bulging posterior vaginal fornix, boggy mass next to the uterus. Vaginal bleeding or spotting may be present. Ruptured ectopic will lead to intraabdominal hemorrhage leading to reciprocal changes in vital signs. 

Investigations used to diagnose ectopic pregnancy include a positive beta-human chorionic gonadotropin to diagnose a pregnancy. Transvaginal ultrasound can be used to identify the gestational sac or determine if the case is a pregnancy of an unknown location. In an ectopic pregnancy, the endometrial stripe will appear as a trilaminar pattern and anechoic fluid collections may be present. 

Medical management of ectopic pregnancy involves the use of methotrexate. Surgical management depends on whether the patient is hemodynamically stable, and whether she desires future fertility (salpingectomy versus salpingostomy). For a ruptured ectopic, only salpingectomy can be done.

  • Hemodynamically stable - laparoscopically done
  • Hemodynamically unstable - laparotomy is done

Related Pearl: Fallopian tube

Gross anatomy:

The fallopian tube is divided into the following parts:

  • Intramural/Interstitial portion:  
    • Intrauterine
    • The narrowest and shortest part
  • Isthmus:
    • The most common site for tubectomy
  • Ampulla:
    • The longest part
    • The most common site for - fertilization and ectopic pregnancy
  • Infundibulum:
    • The widest part

Histology:

The ampulla, isthmus and infundibulum are extrauterine. They're covered by three layers: 

  • Mesosalpinx - It is the peritoneal layer. Also called serosa.
  • Myosalpinx - It contains smooth muscle and has 2 layers:
    • Inner circular 
    • Outer longitudinal
  • Endosalpinx - It is the mucosal layer. It has the following features:
    • Numerous branching folds, filling the entire lumen
    • Basement membrane
    • Ciliated, columnar epithelium 
    • Peg cells - non-ciliated epithelium. They help in the capacitation of sperms.

questions.text: Which of the following does not suggest a medical cause of mental illness?
questions.solution:
Auditory hallucination is not suggestive of a medical cause of mental illness.

Hallucinations are perceptions in the absence of stimuli to account for them.

Auditory hallucinations are the hallucinations most commonly seen in the psychiatric setting. Nonauditory hallucinations often suggest that there is a neurologic, medical, or substance withdrawal issue rather than a primary psychiatric issue.

Features of the medical cause of mental illness:

  • Acute onset (within hours or minutes, with prevailing symptoms) First episode
  • Older age 
  • Current medical illness or injury
  • Significant substance abuse
  • Nonauditory disturbances of perception
  • Neurologic symptoms—loss of consciousness, seizures, head injury, change in headache pattern, change in vision
  • Classic mental status signs—diminished alertness, disorientation, memory impairment, impairment in concentration and attention, dyscalculia, concreteness
  • Other mental status signs—speech, movement, or gait disorders
  • Constructional apraxia—difficulties in drawing clocks, cubes, intersecting pentagons, Bender–Gestalt test

questions.text: A 51-year-old lady presents with complaints of a mass in the right breast. On examination, the mass was larger than 2cm and ipsilateral mobile axillary lymph nodes were present. What is the staging, considering the mass is malignant?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a 51-year-old lady with a breast mass >2cm, lymph node involvement (N1), and the image showing an ulcerative mass near the nipple of the right breast (T4), is clinically suggestive of inflammatory breast carcinoma. Its likely staging is cT4N1M0

Inflammatory breast carcinoma (stage T4) is an aggressive form of locally advanced breast cancer (LABC) and is associated with the worst prognosis among all subtypes of breast cancer. It accounts for <3% of breast cancers. It is characterized by skin changes of brawny induration, erythema, and edema (peau d’orange). The term peau d’orange describes the orange-peel appearance of the skin resulting from edema and dimpling at sites of hair follicles.

In order to determine the best course of treatment for a patient with IBC, it is important to stage cancer. Staging is the process of determining the extent to which cancer has spread within the breast and to other parts of the body. Some prefixes and suffixes are used with the cTNM (clinical) and pTNM (pathologic) staging systems to designate special cases. These do not affect the stage group but indicate that they must be analyzed separately. The “y” prefix, denotes patients who have received systemic therapy before surgery. In this patient, since the staging is being done clinically, "c" is added as a prefix. 

The diagnostic criteria for inflammatory breast cancer are - 

  • Rapid onset of breast erythema, edema and/or peau d’orange, and/or warm breast (with or without an underlying palpable mass)

  • Duration of history no more than six months

  • Erythema occupies at least one-third of the breast

  • Pathologic confirmation of invasive carcinoma

The pathologic hallmark is the presence of tumor cells within dermal lymphatics in skin biopsy specimens, but it is not a prerequisite for diagnosis.

Mammography may be normal or show skin thickening. A PET-CT scan should be considered at the time of diagnosis to rule out concurrent metastatic disease.

Axillary nodal metastases are common, and there is a significant risk for distant metastases.

Combined-modality treatment is used, which includes

  • Neoadjuvant chemo­therapy
  • Modified radical mastectomy
  • Radiation therapy
  • Hormonal therapy (for ER-positive tumors)
  • Trastuzumab (for HER-2-positive tumors)

 

Related Pearl: TNM Staging of carcinoma breast

questions.text: Ovarian drilling is done in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Laparoscopic Ovarian drilling is a surgical management procedure done for Polycystic ovarian syndrome(PCOS).  

PCOS is an endocrinopathy seen in women of reproductive age, affecting multiple systems. The Rotterdam criteria is used to diagnose PCOS. The presence of any two of the three components of this criteria establishes the diagnosis of PCOS.

  • Clinical/biochemical hyperandrogenism (hirsutism, acne)
  • Menstrual abnormalities (Oligo/amenorrhoea), anovulation, infertility
  • Polycystic ovaries on ultrasound.

Sonographic criteria for polycystic ovaries include ≥ 20 follicles and/or an increased ovarian volume (> 10 mL) or both. 

The ultrasound image given below shows an enlarged ovary seen in PCOS with multiple follicles in the periphery.

Management of PCOS:

  • Weight reduction and lifestyle changes (like smoking cessation).
  • Oral contraceptive pills (OCP) are used to treat menstrual abnormalities. It also reduces acne and further hirsutism.
  • Anti-androgens are useful in treating hirsutism. OCP with cyproterone acetate is prescribed for PCOS patients with hirsutism. 
  • Patients with PCOD are more prone to developing insulin resistance which can be controlled with metformin. Acarbose can be used if metformin is contraindicated
  • Patients presenting with infertility are treated by inducing ovulation using clomiphene as a first-line drug, along with dexamethasone and letrozole.

Laparoscopic ovarian drilling or puncture of the ovarian capsule. This is done either by laser or by unipolar electrocautery. The procedure's end goal is to reduce the amount of androgen-producing tissue.

Disadvantages include the risks of pelvic adhesion formation and concerns regarding long-term effects on ovarian reserve.

It can be useful in patients:

  • fail to ovulate with clomiphene citrate,
  • who are at risk for ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome, 
  • who desire to minimize their risk for multifetal gestation. 

Related Pearl: Endocrinological changes of PCOD

  1. Elevated Estrone/E1 levels.
  2. LH level is raised over 10 IU/mL. FSH level remains normal to low, but FSH/LH ratio falls.
  3. Testosterone and epi-androstenedione levels rise.
    • Testosterone elevated but < 200 ng/dL (normal range 20 - 70 ng/dL)
    • Testosterone > 200 ng/dL suggests androgen-secreting ovarian tumor
    • DHEA-S values may be normal or slightly elevated
    • DHEA >700 ng/mL suggests adrenal tumour
  4. Serum SHBG is reduced.
  5. Triglyceride level >150 mg/dL-hyperlipidaemia HDL <50 mg/dL.
  6. Fasting blood glucose/fasting insulin <4.5 suggests insulin resistance
  7. Prolactin is mildly raised in 15% cases
  8. Fasting insulin is more than 10 mIU/L in PCOS in 50–70%cases
  9. Thyroid function tests may be abnormal (hypothyroidism)
  10. 17-a-hydroxyprogesterone in the follicular phase >300 ng/dL suggests adrenal hyperplasia due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency.
  11. Urinary cortisol <50 μg/24 h.

questions.text: All of the following are true about audit in obstetrics except:

choices.text: Change in hospital administration and practices
Should be done before analyzing outcomes

questions.solution:
A clinical audit is done to ascertain if healthcare is being provided in line with set standards and lets care providers and patients know where their service is doing well, and where there could be improvements. As it is done to analyze the current level of care against standard practices, it is usually studied after analyzing data and selecting a topic that requires quality improvement and not before analyzing outcomes.
 
In audits or quality improvement initiatives, collecting data related to patient care and outcomes (like fetal death) can help improve treatment practices by making changes to hospital administration and current practice.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female patient involved in a road traffic accident had nausea and vomiting. She was brought unconscious to the emergency room. NCCT brain reveals the following findings. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given history and CT image showing a typical biconvex hyperdense lesion are characteristic of an extradural hemorrhage (EDH), and it is most commonly due to bleeding from the middle meningeal artery.

EDH refers to the accumulation of blood in the potential space between the inner table of the skull and the dura mater. The hematoma arises from arterial disruption, especially of the middle meningeal artery. The middle meningeal vein and diploic veins may also be implicated.

Patients present with head injury with lucid interval, ipsilateral mydriasis, and ipsilateral hemiparesis. There is a transient loss of consciousness after injury; 6-12 hours later the condition of the patient deteriorates. The time period between which the patient appears normal is known as the lucid interval. The patient presents with features of raised intracranial pressure such as high blood pressure, vomiting, bradycardia, and convulsions. Cushing's triad involves bradycardia, respiratory irregularities, and hypertension.

On head CT, the blood clot is biconvex or lentiform in shape and has a well-defined border. An EDH is typically associated with a fracture of the temporoparietal region.

Immediate surgical intervention is necesary to save life. A craniotomy is indicated for EDH.

 

Related Pearl: Intracranial Hemorrhage (ICH)

Extradural hemorrhage (EDH): 

  • Source: Arterial bleed
  • MC- Middle meningeal artery 
  • Cause- Trauma 
  • Clinical features: Lucid interval is characteristic 
  • CT – Lentiform opacity 
  • Treatment: A large or rapidly evolving EDH requires surgical evacuation

 

Subdural hemorrhage (SDH)

  • Source: Venous bleed 
  • Bridging dural veins 
  • Causes: Trauma, anticoagulants, antiplatelets, alcohol abuse, shaken baby syndrome 
  • Clinical features
    • Acute SDH: may be associated with lucid interval
    • Chronic SDH: drowsiness, headache
  • CT- crescentic opacity
  • Treatment: May resolve spontaneously or require surgical drainage

 

Subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH)

  • Source: Arterial bleed 
  • Causes:
    • MC – Trauma
    • 2nd MC – Rupture of berry aneurysm
  • MC sites: Terminal ICA, MCA bifurcation, top of basilar artery 
  • Clinical features: Thunderclap headache with neck stiffness +/- FND 
  • Investigations:
    • Non-contrast CT brain,
    • CSF xanthochromia (peaks in 2 days and subsides in 2 weeks) 
  • Treatment:
    • Clipping/coiling of berry aneurysm,
    • Triple H therapy – hypertension, hypervolemia, and hemodilution to prevent vasospasm 

 

Intraparenchymal hemorrhage- (MC type of ICH)

  • Source- Arterial bleed 
  • Causes:
    • MC – hypertension
    • Trauma, cerebral amyloid angiopathy, bleeding disorders, neoplasms, vascular malformations 
  • MC sites:
    • Putamen (basal ganglia)
    • Thalamus
    • Cerebellum
    • Pons 
  • Treatment:
    • Correction of any identified coagulopathy by infusing prothrombin complex concentrates, FFP or fresh platelets as required
    • Surgical evacuation for cerebellar hematoms >3 cm in size

Related Pearl: Intracranial haemorrhage

questions.text: A young male patient presents with ptosis and muscle weakness which reportedly worsens in the evening and improves in the morning. This is relieved by neostigmine. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
From the given clinical picture, myasthenia gravis is the most likely diagnosis. This patient has symptoms of ptosis, progressive weakness, and excessive fatiguability which improves with rest. 

Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune neuromuscular junction disorder that is characterized by weakness and fatigability of skeletal muscles. It is due to the autoantibody-mediated destruction of the acetylcholine receptors (AChRs) at the post-synaptic membrane. This consequentially leads to a decreased transmission at the neuromuscular junction. Failure of transmission results in muscle weakness.

Females are more commonly affected than males and the disease tends to occur in middle age.

Clinical features of myasthenia gravis:

  • Muscle weakness and fatiguability increase with repeated use or late in the day and may improve following rest or sleep. Limb weakness is proximal and asymmetrical
  • Cranial muscles particularly the lids and extraocular muscles are involved early in the course - diplopia, ptosis
  • Facial weakness - snarling expression on smiling
  • Weakness in chewing
  • Speech with nasal timbre due to the weakness of the palate and tongue
  • Difficulty in swallowing
  • Deep tendon reflexes are intact
  • Myasthenic crisis - acute exacerbation of muscle weakness especially intercostal and diaphragmatic muscles resulting in ventilatory failure. It is most commonly due to infection and anticholinesterase medication overuse.

Myasthenia gravis is associated with thymoma and other autoimmune diseases such as Hashimoto's thyroiditis, Grave's disease, neuromyelitis optics, systemic lupus erythematosus, etc.

Diagnosis:

  • Ice-pack test - application of ice pack over the eyes improves ptosis (decreases activity of acetylcholinesterase, this increases the amount of acetylcholine in the synaptic cleft and increases transmission)
  • Antibodies associated with myasthenia gravis: Anti-AChR antibodies, Anti-MuSK antibodies, Anti-LRP4 antibodies
  • Repetitive nerve stimulation test shows a decremental response.
  • Edrophonium chloride or Tensilon test - improvement of symptoms occurs on injecting edrophonium. Edrophonium is an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor. This increases the amount of acetylcholine in the synaptic cleft and improves transmission.

Treatment:

  • Anticholinesterase drugs - Pyridostigmine.
  • Thymectomy.
  • Immunosuppression therapy with glucocorticoids, azathioprine, tacrolimus, rituximab, etc.
  • Plasmapheresis and intravenous immunoglobulin.

Other options:

Option B: Huntington's disease (HD) also known as Huntington chorea is associated with CAG repeats and anticipation. It has an adult-onset and is associated with the degeneration of striatal neurons. Features such as chorea and dementia are commonly seen in these patients. The characteristic features of HD include involuntary movements, dementia, and behavioral changes.

Option C: ALS is the most common progressive motor neuron disease. The pathologic hallmark of ALS includes the involvement of lower motor neurons of the ventral/ anterior horn of the spinal cord, cranial nerves innervating the bulbar muscles, and the afferent corticospinal upper motor neurons in layer five of the motor cortex. Progressive upper motor neuron (UMN) palsy (exaggerated reflexes, extensor plantar), lower motor neuron (LMN) palsy (muscle weakness, atrophy, fasciculations), and pseudobulbar palsy (dysarthria, tongue spasticity), with normal bladder, bowel and sensory function are suggestive of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS).

Option D: The classical presentation of ptosis with progressively declining ocular movement is characteristic of chronic progressive external ophthalmoplegia (CPEO). CPEO may occur in isolation, in association with Kearns-Sayre syndrome (mitochondrial myopathy associated with mitochondrial DNA deletions), or oculopharyngeal dystrophy.

questions.text: Which is the least commonly used graft for coronary artery bypass graft (CABG)?
questions.solution:
The intercostal artery is the least likely to be used as a graft in CABG.

The left internal mammary artery (LIMA) provides long-lasting results in a coronary artery bypass graft (CABG). The conduit with the highest patency rate is the left internal mammary artery or internal thoracic artery. Long patency rates of >98 percent have been reported.

Venous grafts:

  • The long saphenous vein is the most common vein used as a conduit as it is straightforward to harvest, provides good length, and is easy to handle.
  • The ten-year patency rate for long saphenous vein grafts is reported to be 50–60 percent.

Arterial grafts:

  • The Left internal mammary artery (LIMA) or internal thoracic artery has become the conduit of choice for the left anterior descending (LAD) coronary artery. The radial artery can be used as a second or alternative arterial bypass graft. Other arterial bypass grafts include the gastroepiploic artery and the inferior epigastric artery.

Related Pearl: Indications for Coronary Artery Bypass Grafting (CABG)

Class I indications for CABG from the American College of Cardiology(ACC) and American Heart Association(AHA).

  • Left main disease
  • Three-vessel disease with or without proximal LAD disease
  • Two vessel disease with proximal LAD disease
  • Survivors of sudden cardiac death with presumed ischemia-mediated VT  

Other indications for CABG include the following:

  • Disabling angina
  • Ongoing ischemia in the setting of a non–ST-segment elevation (MI) that is unresponsive to medical therapy
  • Poor LV function but with viable, nonfunctioning myocardium above the anatomic defect that can be revascularized

questions.text: Study of death in all aspects is known as _________________
questions.solution:
Thanatology is the study of death in all aspects.

Other options: 

Option B: Forensic anthropology is the study of physical anthropology for forensic purposes that deal with the identification and analysis of skeletonized remains known to be or suspected of a human being.

Option C: Forensic toxicology deals with medical and legal aspects of toxic chemicals on human beings.

Option D: Molecular death is the death of cells and tissues individually after death. It usually occurs after 1-2 hours of death. The changes are due to metabolic dysfunction and structural disintegration.

questions.text: Genetic testing for BRCA 1/BRCA 2 is indicated for all of the following except:

choices.text: Breast cancer diagnosed in a post menopausal female >50 years of age

questions.solution:
Genetic testing is not recommended in post-menopausal females >50 years of age. 

Genetic counselling is the process of discussing various genetic testing such as BRCA testing and multiple gene panel testing.

Genetic counselling and testing for genetic mutations (BRCA 1, BRCA 2 and others such as TP53, PTEN) are recommended for high-risk women with:

  • Breast cancer diagnosed before age 50
  • Triple-negative breast cancer
  • Bilateral breast cancer
  • Breast and ovarian cancer in the same individual
  • Breast cancer in men
  • Family history (maternal or paternal) of two or more individuals with breast and ovarian cancer
  • A close male relative with breast cancer
  • A close relative with early-onset (<50 years) breast or ovarian cancer
  • Known BRCA1 or BRCA2 mutation in the family

 

Related Pearl: Risk factors and protective factors for breast carcinoma

Risk factors

  • Age: Incidence increases with increasing age.
  • Sex: more common in females.
  • Family history of breast cancer
  • Race, ethnicity (white women have increased risk compared to women of other races)
  • History of radiation exposure
  • Mammographically dense breast
  • Genetic factors:
  • Mutations in tumor suppressor genes
    • BRCA 1
    • BRCA 2
    • TP53
    • CHEK2
  • Hereditary syndromes
    • Li Fraumeni syndrome
    • Cowden’s syndrome
    • HNPCC syndrome
    • Peutz-Jegher’s syndrome
    • Ataxia telangiectasia
  • Hormonal factors (hyperestrogenemia is the risk factor)
    • Early menarche
    • Late menopause
    • First full-term pregnancy >30 years
    • Nulliparity
    • Obesity (postmenopausal)
  • Higher socioeconomic status, high fat diet, alcohol intake

 

Protective factors

  • Early age at first pregnancy
  • Multiparity
  • Breastfeeding
  • Oophorectomy
  • Exercise
  • Tamoxifen and Aromatase inhibitors

Related Pearl: Comparison between BRCA 1 and BRCA 2:

Both BRCA1 and BRCA2 are tumor suppressor genes.

Carcinoma breast occurs at an earlier age and is bilateral and multicentric in inherited forms compared to sporadic cases.

  BRCA 1 BRCA 2
Location Long arm of chromosome 17  Long arm of chromosome 13
Differentiation Poorly differentiated Well-differentiated
Hormone receptor status ER/PR- Negative, Her-2 negative – triple negative ER/PR- Positive
Associated Cancers Breast, ovarian, colon, and prostate (lesser extent), Pancreas (lesser extent)  cancers Breast, ovarian, colon, prostate, pancreas, gall bladder, stomach cancers, and melanoma
Male breast carcinoma  Low association Increased risk
Fanconi’s anemia  Associated Associated
Medullary carcinoma Associated No association

questions.text: A patient presents with dyspnea and distended neck veins that increase on inspiration. There is no murmur. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient presenting with dyspnea and Kussmauls signs as evidenced by the distended neck veins that increase on inspiration, likely has underlying constrictive pericarditis.

Constrictive pericarditis: It is a condition where a thickened, fibrotic, and often calcified pericardium restricts the diastolic filling of the heart.

In developing countries, infectious etiologies like tuberculosis or viral infections are the most common cause of this condition. Cardiac surgery and radiation therapy are also common causes. Other causes include connective tissue disease, uremia, neoplasm, or idiopathic.

Clinically the patients may present with dyspnea, orthopnea, fatigue, ascites. On examination neck veins may be distended and will show a positive Kussmauls sign. On auscultation, heart sound smay be distant and a pericardial knock at the cardiac apex may be heard. This occurs due to the abrubt cessation of ventricular filling.

JVP findings - There is a rapid 'x' and 'y' descent. The rapid 'y' descent is more prominent and reflects rapid early ventricular diastolic filling. This occurs due to the constricting pericardium, increasing the atrial pressures.

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is difficult and is confirmed by multiple investigations

  • Hallmark findings of pericardial constriction are pericardial thickening, calcification, and abnormal ventricular diastolic function.
  • The X-ray can be normal or there may be non-specific cardiac enlargement, calcification, and roughened cardiac outline.
  • CT and MRI are more sensitive investigations.

Constrictive pericarditis will have prominent y descent, prominent x descent, and Kussmaul's sign. Normally, the venous pressure should fall by at least 3 mmHg with inspiration. Kussmaul’s sign is defined by either a rise or a lack of fall of the JVP with inspiration.

 

Other options:

Option B: Aortic regurgitation would present with a diastolic murmur.

Option C: Tricuspid stenosis may also present similarly with congestive hepatomegaly, and venous distention, however, in this patient the absence of a murmur makes the diagnosis unlikely. Tricuspid stenosis will have prolonged y wave on JVP.

Option D: Pulmonary arterial hypertension would present with a prominent jugular "a" wave, palpable left parasternal lift, and loud S2 which are not seen in this patient.

questions.text: A  public witness of the incident is asked to attend the court and record his evidence. Which type of evidence is provided by the witness to the court?
questions.solution:
The evidence provided by a public witness of the incident to the court is oral evidence.

Oral evidence is given by a person who has personal knowledge of the facts associated with a particular incident. It is the evidence given by an eyewitness. The oral evidence should be direct whenever possible according to Section 60 of the Indian Evidence Act(IEA). It includes all the statements made by the witness in relation to the inquiry which is permitted by the court. 

Other options: 

Option B: Hearsay evidence is a type of evidence given by a person who has no personal knowledge of the facts in relation to the incident but only repeats what he heard others saying. 

Option C: Subpnea is also known as summons. It is an authoritative call to appear in court. It is a document compelling the attendance of a witness in a Court of law under penalty, on a particular day, time, and place, for the purpose of giving evidence. It is issued by the Court. Section 61 to 69 of CrPc deals with the summons. 

Option D: Circumstantial evidence is also known as indirect evidence. It is not the direct testimony of an eye witness but has a bearing upon the fact of the other and subsidiary facts which are relied upon as consistent. This type of evidence needs the Court of Law to make reasonable inferences based on the information presented.

IPC section

Section it deals with

191

Giving false evidence (perjury)

192

Fabricating false evidence

193

Punishment for false evidence

  • Judicial proceedings: up to 7 yrs of imprisonment and fine
  • Any other case: up to 3 yrs of imprisonment and fine

196

Using evidence known to be false

197

Issuing or signing false certificate

201

Causing disappearance of evidence of offence or giving false information to screen offender

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of mortality in diabetic ketoacidosis?
questions.solution:
Cerebral edema is the leading cause of mortality in diabetic ketoacidosis.

The osmolar gradient generated due to the high blood glucose level results in water shift from the intracellular fluid (ICF) to the extracellular fluid (ECF) space and leads to the contraction of cell volume. Correction with insulin and intravenous fluids can result in a rapid reduction in effective osmolarity, reversal of the fluid shift, and result in cerebral edema.

Complications of diabetic ketoacidosis include:

  • Cerebral edema – especially in children
  • Cardiac arrhythmia - due to electrolyte imbalance
  • Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)
  • Venous thrombosis
  • Acute gastric dilation
  • Acute kidney injury 
  • Intestinal necrosis
  • Acute pancreatitis
  • Mucormycosis

questions.text: A patient who was diagnosed with prostate cancer is being investigated. The bone scan is reported as a super scan with increased uptake in the bones and reduced activity in the spleen. What is the reason for this super scan appearance?

choices.text: Increased uptake due to diffuse metastasis
Decreased uptake by adrenal glands and kidney

questions.solution:
The super scan appearance is due to increased uptake due to diffuse metastasis. 

Diffuse osteoblastic metastatic diseases such as carcinoma breast and prostate carcinoma lead to a generalized increase in the skeletal uptake relative to soft tissue and absent or faint renal activity on a bone scan. This is known as a super scan. It may also be seen in generalized bone diseases such as hyperparathyroidism.

Carcinoma of the prostate is the most common malignant tumor in men over the age of 65 years. Most cancers are clinically silent and are detected on routine rectal examination or PSA measurements. Grossly, malignant tissue is gritty and firm in consistency (in contrast to the spongy appearance of benign tissue) and thus more readily palpable on digital rectal examination. They usually arise in the peripheral zone of the gland.

Local extension most commonly involves the periprostatic tissue, seminal vesicles, and the base of the urinary bladder. Metastasis spreads via the lymphatics to the obturator nodes and the para-aortic nodes. Hematogenous spread occurs chiefly through the bones to the axial skeleton and rarely to the viscera. The bony metastasis is blastic in origin and involves the lumbar spine, proximal femur, pelvis, thoracic spine, and ribs in decreasing order of frequency. 

Prognosis and staging: The Gleason grading system correlates with the pathological stage, spread, and prognosis. Measurement of serum PSA levels may be useful to assist with the diagnosis and management.

Related Pearl: Types of metastasis(osteoblastic or osteolytic) and their primary:

Predominantly osteoblastic:

  • Prostate cancer
  • Osteosarcoma 
  • Medullary carcinoma thyroid

Mixed osteoblastic and osteolytic:

  • Breast cancer(preponderance toward osteolytic)
  • Lymphoma
  • Urothelial carcinoma 
  • Lung cancer

Predominantly osteolytic:

  • Renal cell carcinoma
  • Multiple myeloma 
  • Thyroid carcinoma(except medullary carcinoma thyroid)
  • Gastrointestinal tract carcinoma
  • Malignant melanoma

questions.text: A 38-year-old professor with depression requests you to prescribe an antidepressant that would be least likely to cause sexual dysfunction. Which of the following drugs would you prescribe?
questions.solution:
Bupropion can be prescribed as it decreases the chance of causing sexual dysfunction.

  • It enhances both noradrenergic and dopaminergic neurotransmission by inhibiting reuptake.
  • Used for aiding smoking cessation and for the treatment of depression in combination with SSRIs.
  • Adverse effects of bupropion include stimulant side effects like tachycardia, insomnia, headache, and seizures in anorexic/bulimic patients. 
  • It decreases the risk of sexual dysfunction and weight gain compared to other antidepressants.

Venlafaxine is a serotonin noradrenaline reuptake inhibitor used in the treatment of major depression, generalized anxiety disorder, and panic disorder. Adverse effects are nausea, sexual dysfunction, and sustained elevation of blood pressure.

Escitalopram and fluoxetine are selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors used in the treatment of major depression, obsessive-compulsive disorder, post-traumatic stress disorder, bulimia and anorexia nervosa, and generalized anxiety disorders. Adverse effects are dry mouth, urinary retention, and sexual dysfunction.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best parameter for estimation of fetal age by ultrasound in 1st trimester?
questions.solution:
Crown-rump length (CRL) is the most accurate parameter used for the sonographic estimation of gestational age in the first trimester. It has an accuracy range of ± 5 days.

Parameters for estimation of fetal age

Trimester

Parameter

First

Crown-rump length (CRL)

Second
  • Biparietal diameter (BPD)
  • Abdominal Circumference (AC)
  • Head Circumference (HC)
  • Femur Length. (FL) 

Third

Femur length

 

Related Pearl: Fetal Monitoring using Ultrasound

  • The first definitive USG finding to suggest pregnancy is the visualization of the gestational sac.
  • The first sign of intrauterine pregnancy is the presence of a yolk sac within the gestational sac.
  • Best time to assess the gestational age by USG is 9-12 weeks(by CRL)
  • CRL(mm)+42 = Days of pregnancy
  • CRL(cm)+6.5 = Gestational age in weeks.
  • The best indicator of fetal growth is the abdominal circumference. Abdominal circumference is the transverse measurement at the level of the stomach with the confluence of the umbilical vein and right portal vein.

Thymoma is not a superior mediastinal tumour.

questions.text: What disorder occurs if the marked region of the adrenal gland is affected?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a cross-section of the adrenal gland. Cushing's disease occurs as if there is an oversecretion of adrenocorticoids by the adrenal cortex.

Cushing's syndrome is a group of clinical features that occur due to chronic exposure to excess glucocorticoids of any etiology. Cushing's disease is specifically Cushing's syndrome that occurs due to pituitary corticotrope adenoma. 

Typical features include

System Clinical features
Body fat
  • Central or truncal obesity (most common)
  • Buffalo hump (fat deposition behind the neck)
  • Moon facies  
Skin
  • Purple striae (over abdomen & flanks)
  • Acne and Hirsutism 
  • Easy bruising 
  • Facial plethora
  • Hyperpigmentation 
Musculoskeletal
  • Proximal myopathy
  • Osteoporosis
Metabolic
  • Poorly controlled hyperglycemia
  • Dyslipidemia
Reproductive
  • Low libido
  • Amenorrhea
Renal
  • Hypokalemic alkalosis
CVS
  • Atherosclerosis 
  • Diastolic hypertension 
  • Edema 
Hematologic
  • Hypercoagulable state 
  • Neutrophilia
  • Eosinopenia
CNS
  • Depression, anxiety
  • Psychosis 
  • Irritability

Related Pearl: Initial Tests for Diagnosing Cushing's Syndrome

These include two steps:

1. Tests to detect hypercortisolism

  • Midnight salivary or serum cortisol (highly sensitive test): The presence of cortisol in the saliva or serum at midnight signifies loss of diurnal variation of cortisol
  • 24-hour urinary free cortisol excretion: Increased three times the normal value
  • Overnight dexamethasone suppression test (DST): Plasma cortisol >1.8 μg/dL at 8 a.m after overnight exposure to dexamethasone (1 mg given at 11 p.m)
  • Low dose DST (highly specific test): Plasma cortisol >1.8 μg/dL at 8 a.m. on the third day after giving 0.5 mg dexamethasone every 6 hours for 2 days

2. Test to rule out pseudo Cushing's syndrome

  • Low-dose DST + CRH stimulation test: Plasma cortisol levels are increased in true Cushing’s but remain unaffected in pseudo Cushing's. Dexa-induced negative feedback is overcome by CRH in true Cushing’s.

Related Pearl: Causes of Cushing's Syndrome

Iatrogenic (Most common cause)

  • Exogenous administration of glucocorticoids

Endogenous Causes

  • ACTH Dependent – (90 % of endogenous causes)
  • Cushing’s disease – ACTH-producing pituitary adenoma
  • Ectopic ACTH syndrome – Due to ACTH secretion by
  • Bronchial or pancreatic carcinoid tumors
  • Small-cell lung cancer
  • Medullary thyroid carcinoma
  • Pheochromocytoma
  • ACTH Independent – (10% )
  • Adrenocortical adenoma
  • Adrenocortical carcinoma

Rare causes

  • Macronodular adrenal hyperplasia
  • Primary pigmented nodular adrenal disease
  • McCune – Albright syndrome

questions.text: Whole-body CT scan protocol for a trauma patient includes all, except ______.
questions.solution:
The whole-body CT of a trauma patient does not include CT limbs.

Whole-body CT or trauma CT or pans can is increasingly being used in the context of trauma patients with a dangerous mechanism of injury:

  1. Non-contrast CT of head
  2. Non-contrast CT of neck
  3. Contrast-enhanced CT of chest (arterial phase)
  4. Contrast-enhanced CT of abdomen (portal venous phase)

The purpose of the scan is to rapidly evaluate life-threatening injuries and accurately diagnose known and unknown injuries.

While limb injuries can certainly occur in trauma cases, they are usually assessed through physical examination, X-rays, or targeted CT scans if there is suspicion of a specific injury. Including limb imaging as part of the standard whole-body CT scan protocol would increase the scan time and radiation exposure for the patient without significantly impacting the detection of life-threatening injuries.

Therefore, CT limbs is the exception and is not typically included in the whole-body CT scan protocol for trauma patients.

questions.text: Four patients were brought to the casualty after sustaining trauma. Which of the following is the correct match of injuries and signs among the following?

choices.text: Extra dural hemorrhage (EDH)- Pin point pupil
Penetrating injury to eustachian tube- CSF otorrhea
Penetrating injury to eye- Battle sign

questions.solution:
Gaze paresis- Mid-brain lesion, is the correctly matched pair among the given options.

Traumatic injury to the brain affecting the mid-brain or brainstem dysfunction produces:

  • Gaze paresis - Inability of the eye to look across beyond the midline.
  • Dysconjugate gaze - Inability of the eyes to work together.
  • Roving eye movements.

Battle sign and CSF rhinorrhea are features of a middle cranial fossa fracture.

Middle cranial fossa fracture is associated with:

  • CSF otorrhea or rhinorrhea
  • Hemotympanum
  • Ossicular disruption
  • Battle sign: Bruising behind the ear
  • 7th and 8th cranial nerve palsies

A double target sign is seen in patients with CSF rhinorrhea. The nasal discharge in a patient with CSF rhinorrhea after head trauma is mixed with blood. When this discharge is collected on a filter paper, it shows a double target sign with a central red spot and a peripheral lighter halo as seen in the image below. 

The image below shows the 'battle' sign.

Anterior cranial fossa fracture is associated with:

  • Subconjunctival hematoma
  • CSF rhinorrhea
  • Periorbital hematoma or “Raccoon eyes”

Periorbital ecchymosis (raccoon eyes): Pooling of blood surrounding the eyes, associated with fractures of the anterior cranial fossa (given below). 

The pinpoint pupil is seen in patients with pontine hemorrhage and opioid overdose.

questions.text: A 28-year-old mother presents with pain in her left breast. Which of the following is the most likely cause of acute mastitis?
questions.solution:
Acute mastitis is caused by a local bacterial infection when the breast is most vulnerable due to cracks and fissures in the nipples.

Mastitis occurs due to a combination of factors such as inadequate milk drainage and the introduction of bacteria present on the skin. The cracks in the nipple serve as an entry point, thus resulting in infection. The most common organism causing acute mastitis is Staphylococcus aureus.

Acute bacterial mastitis typically occurs during the 1st month of breastfeeding (lactational breast abscess). 

Staphylococcal acute mastitis typically results in localized abscesses. Signs and symptoms of this condition involve:

  • Fever and malaise
  • Localized pain and tenderness 
  • Redness and swelling of the affected breast
  • Fluctuation test positive due to pus in the abscess. It is a late sign.

Management includes analgesia, continued expression from the breast, antibiotics such as amoxiclav, and repeated aspiration of pus. In case of aspiration and antibiotics failure, incision and drainage can be done.

questions.text: In which poisoning is cherry red hypostasis seen on postmortem examination?
questions.solution:
Cherry red hypostasis seen on postmortem examination is seen in CO poisoning.

Postmortem appearance in CO poisoning:

  • Bright cherry red discoloration of the skin, mucosa, blood, tissues, and internal organs.
  • Congestion of the lungs with pink fluid blood. 
  • Pleural and pericardial hemorrhages are commonly seen.
  • Bilateral symmetrical necrosis and cavitation of basal ganglia (globus pallidus and putamen) is the most characteristic feature of delayed deaths.
  • Punctiform and ring form hemorrhages in the white matter of the brain.

Other options:

Option B: In hydrogen sulfide poisoning, postmortem hypostasis is bluish-green in color.

Option C: In yellow phosphorus poisoning, postmortem hypostasis is dark brown or yellow in color 

Option D: In hydrogen cyanide poisoning, postmortem hypostasis is bright red in color.

questions.text: Which of the following is the recommended treatment for the condition shown in the image?
questions.solution:
The given X-ray image shows a lower/distal ureteric stone. Ureteroscopic removal is generally preferred for stones <6mm and specifically those present in the distal ureter. Ureteric calculi are directly visualized through semi-rigid ureteroscopes. Stones are then fragmented and extracted using a dormia basket. Complications are related to injury to the ureteric mucosa such as ureteric perforation and extravasation, avulsion of the ureter, and ureteric stricture.

Ureteroscopic stone removal using a dormia basket is depicted in the image below.  

Option A: Percutaneous nephrolithotomy (PCNL) - Endoscopic instruments are passed into the kidney by percutaneous technique and stones are fragmented and removed. It is mainly used in treating large stones in the renal pelvis and calyces and stones in the proximal ureter.

Indications of PCNL:

  • Obstructions caused by anatomical abnormalities like pelviureteric junction obstruction, calyceal diverticula or ureteric obstruction
  • Staghorn calculi
  • Stones >2.5 cm in size
  • Stone composition - struvite, calcium oxalate monohydrate , and cystine stones
  • Multiple stones
  • Obese patients in whom ESWL is contraindicated
  • Lower calyceal stones 
  • Stones not responding to EWSL

 Other options:

Option C: Extracorporeal shockwave lithotripsy (ESWL) is a non-invasive method that generates shockwaves outside the body, which are focused on stones. It is the commonest method of treating renal calculi nowadays. 

Stones up to approximately 1.5 cm in size are suitable for this form of treatment. Cystine stones which are often multiple, and very hard are relatively resistant to ESWL due to their hardness. Contraindications for ESWL include obese patients, pregnant patients, and patients taking oral anticoagulants.

Option D: Wait and watch is done for small stones <5mm as they are more likely to pass spontaneously.

Related Pearl: Management of renal and ureteric calculi

    • Dihydrate: Octahedral or envelope shaped
  • Struvite stones: Rectangular or coffin lid

questions.text: A 44-year-old lady presents to the hospital with a flank mass that is ballotable. On CT imaging, the mass measures 4cm. Urine examination shows malignant cells. What is the most appropriate management for her condition?
questions.solution:
Partial nephrectomy (also known as nephron-sparing surgery) is performed for renal cell carcinoma(RCC) tumors less than 4 cm in size. It is also performed for:

Indications for partial nephrectomy:

  • Tumors < 4cm
  • Well-selected tumors between 4-7 cm
  • Bilateral tumors
  • Tumor in solitary kidneys
  • Patients with pre-existing renal dysfunction.

Recently, partial nephrectomy is also increasingly being performed for stage T1b tumors. 

Treatment of renal cell carcinoma: 

RCC is a radio and chemoresistant tumor.

Staging  Description  Management 
Stage 1  Tumor <7 cm, confined to the kidney Partial nephrectomy 
Stage 2 Tumor >7 cm, confined to the kidney Radical nephrectomy 
Stage 3 Tumor extends into the major veins or adrenal gland with intact Gerota’s fascia or regional lymph nodes involved.  Radical nephrectomy 
Stage 4 Tumor invades beyond Gerota fascia (including contiguous extension into the ipsilateral adrenal gland) 
  • Debulking surgery
  • mTOR inhibitors such as everolimus, sirolimus
  • Tyrosine kinase inhibitors: sunitinib, sorafenib

Radical nephrectomy consists of the removal of the kidney, perirenal fat, adrenal gland, and regional lymph nodes. The adrenal gland is no longer removed except in cases of obvious tumor involvement. Lymphadenectomy is indicated only in high-risk patients with large primary tumors and enlarged lymph nodes.

Cryoablation is indicated in the T1a stage of RCC if surgery cannot be performed. It is also indicated in advanced/metastatic tumors. 

Note: Sunitinib and sorafenib are also used in GIST and hepatocellular carcinoma.

Related Pearl: Histologic subtypes of renal cell carcinoma

Clear-cell Type

  • Most common type
  • Originate from proximal tubule
  • Associated with von Hippel–Lindau (VHL) disease

Papillary Type

  • Psammoma bodies are seen in histology
  • Originates from proximal convoluted tubules, can be multifocal and bilateral.

  • Are unique in having multiple losses of entire chromosomes
  • Originates from intercalated cells of collecting duct
  • Good prognosis

  • Poor prognosis

Renal medullary carcinoma

  • Rare 
  • Associated with sickle cell trait
  • Originates from collecting duct

Note:

Sarcomatoid change can occur infrequently in all types of renal cell carcinoma (RCC) and is an ominous feature.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs reduce mortality in a patient with heart failure?
questions.solution:
Metoprolol is a beta-blocker that is found to reduce mortality in a patient with heart failure.

Beta-blockers have been shown to prolong survival, prevent arrhythmia, and improve symptoms of heart failure and left ventricular ejection fraction, especially in patients with chronic heart failure.

The drugs which reduce mortality in patients with heart failure are :

  • ACE inhibitors
  • Angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs)
  • Angiotensin receptor neprilysin inhibitor (ARNI)
  • Beta-blockers
  • Mineralocorticoid receptor antagonists
    • Spironolactone
    • Eplerenone
  • Hydralazine + isosorbide dinitrate.
