questions.text: Which lymph node is most commonly involved in prostate cancer?
questions.solution:
The most common lymph node of metastatic disease in prostate cancer is the pelvic or retroperitoneal lymph nodes.

Carcinoma of the prostate is the most common malignant tumor in men over the age of 65 years. Most cancers are clinically silent and are detected on routine rectal examination or PSA measurements. Grossly, malignant tissue is gritty and firm in consistency (in contrast to the spongy appearance of benign tissue) and thus more readily palpable on digital rectal examination. They usually arise in the peripheral zone of the gland.

Local extension most commonly involves the periprostatic tissue, seminal vesicles, and the base of the urinary bladder. Metastasis spreads via the lymphatics to the pelvic, obturator, and retroperitoneal lymph nodes. Hematogenous spread occurs chiefly through the bones to the axial skeleton and rarely to the viscera. The bony metastasis is blastic in origin and involves the lumbar spine, proximal femur, pelvis, thoracic spine, and ribs in decreasing order of frequency. 

Prognosis and staging: The Gleason grading system correlates with the pathological stage, spread, and prognosis. Measurement of serum PSA levels may be useful to assist with the diagnosis and management.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman after thyroidectomy comes to you for 2nd opinion for further treatment of papillary thyroid cancer. What would you recommend for this patient?
questions.solution:
A radioiodine scan will be recommended to this patient following the thyroidectomy, to look for residual or metastatic disease.

Papillary thyroid carcinoma is the most common thyroid malignancy. It is more commonly seen in women between the ages of 30 and 50. Radiation exposure and a family history of thyroid malignancies are the common etiologies. Genetic abnormalities in either the RET gene or the BRAF gene can be seen in papillary thyroid carcinoma.

Clinical features include an asymptomatic thyroid swelling with cervical lymph node enlargement. In advanced disease, there may be features like hoarseness, dysphagia, cough, or dyspnea. 

An ultrasound scan accurately assesses the size and number of nodules, as well as categorizes the lesions as benign, indeterminate, or malignant. Fine needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) is a diagnostic test, helpful in investigating an indeterminate or malignant lesion.

Histopathology shows the following features:

  • Branching papillae
  • Orphan Annie eye nuclei: optically clear nuclei with fine nuclear chromatin
  • Pseudo inclusions: invaginations of the nuclear membrane
  • Psammoma bodies: concentric calcifications in the core of the papillae.

Below is the histopathological image of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid with characteristic Orphan Annie eye nuclei.

 

Papillary thyroid carcinoma is known to spread via lymphatics, hence lymph node metastasis is commonly seen.

Treatment of Papillary thyroid carcinoma is as follows:

Total thyroidectomy is the treatment of choice. Routine central neck dissection is not recommended. Neck dissection is indicated in higher-risk situations, such as

  • Tumor size > 4 cm (T3 stage) or gross extrathyroidal extension (T4 stage) or enlarged central lymph nodes - Total thyroidectomy + Central Neck Dissection
  • Lateral Aberrant Thyroid - Total thyroidectomy + Modified Radical Neck Dissection + Central Neck Dissection

For occult papillary cancer (<1 cm tumor size, with no lymphatic, vascular or capsular invasion) - Lobectomy can be sufficient.

Radio-iodine ablation is undertaken when a whole-body iodine scan is positive after a total thyroidectomy for any differentiated thyroid cancer (papillary or follicular carcinoma). 

The presence of any metastatic or residual thyroid tissue after total thyroidectomy can be detected by observing the uptake of radio-iodine in the entire body. To achieve effective uptake of radio-iodine, TSH levels need to be greatly increased, for example, by withdrawing thyroxine after the surgery for 4-6 weeks.

A positive whole-body iodine scan after total thyroidectomy indicates that there is either a metastatic or residual disease present. These patients are treated with I131 for radio-iodine ablation. 

A negative scan means there is no metastasis or residual thyroid tissue. They are followed up regularly with serum thyroglobulin, TSH and USG-neck.

questions.text: A woman presents with complaints of greenish-frothy vaginal discharge for 1 month. On examination vulvovaginal erythema is noticed. On saline microscopy, motile organisms are seen. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette and microscopic findings are suggestive of trichomoniasis.

The clinical features include vaginal discharge which is profuse, thin, slightly green in color, and frothy. It may be associated with vaginal irritation, dysuria, and increased frequency. Cervical inflammation with punctate hemorrhagic spots known as the strawberry cervix is typically seen in trichomoniasis, caused by Trichomonas vaginalis. It is a sexually transmitted infection. Motile trichomonads are seen on wet mount examination.

The below image shows the strawberry cervix seen in trichomoniasis.

Other options:

Option B: Bacterial vaginosis is caused by an alteration in the normal vaginal flora and presents a malodorous grey-white discharge. It is diagnosed using Amsel's criteria, where at least three of the four following criteria should be present to confirm the diagnosis:

  • Homogenous vaginal discharge
  • Vaginal pH > 4.5
  • Amine-like odor on adding KOH (Whiff test positive)
  • Clue cells (>20% of cells)

Option C: Chlamydial cervicitis may present with severe abdominal pain with high fever, dyspareunia, prolonged menstrual cycles, and intermenstrual bleeding can be elicited. On examination, cervicitis with a yellow, cloudy, mucoid discharge can be seen from the os. The cervix tends to bleed easily when scraped. 

Option D: Candidiasis is caused by infection with Candida albicans and presents with pruritus, burning, and dysuria with vulvar erythema, edema, and excoriations. A curdy white discharge will be present.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with a history of smoking a pack of cigarettes for the past 15 years presents with hemoptysis. Chest X-ray shows a 3cm upper lobe mass near the apex of the lung, What is the next best step for the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
In this patient who is a chronic smoker, presenting with hemoptysis and a 5cm mass in the apex of the lung, there is a high concern for bronchogenic carcinoma. Among the given options CT guided biopsy is the best next step in evaluating the mass.

Focal pulmonary lesions that are >3cm in diameter are called lung masses and are presumed to be bronchogenic carcinoma. Nodules that have a high probability of being malignant, should undergo biopsy, and CT-guided biopsy is commonly preferred.

To summarize :

  • Investigation of choice - Plain CT  > PET 
  • Gold standard investigation - CT guided Biopsy.

Other options:

Option A: As this patient requires a biopsy of the mass, just a bronchoscopy without a biopsy would not be sufficient for evaluation.

Options C and D: Sputum cytology may help diagnose lung cancer but has lower specificity and sensitivity than CT guided biopsy. Sputum cytology and sputum AFB would rather be preferred for infective conditions.

questions.text: A  chronic alcoholic presents to the emergency room with acute pain abdomen in the epigastric region radiating to the back with nausea, anorexia, and occasional vomiting. Investigations showed elevated amylase levels and total count. Likely diagnosis is__________
questions.solution:
History of epigastric pain radiating to the back in a chronic alcoholic patient with elevated serum amylase levels are most consistent with the diagnosis of acute pancreatitis.

Related Pearl: Clinical features of acute pancreatitis

Symptoms:

  • Acute onset of epigastric pain, which is severe, constant, and refractory to usual doses of analgesics.
  • Typically radiates to back
  • Relieved in the sitting forward position
  • Nausea, repeated vomiting, retching, and hiccups

Signs:

  • Hypotension, tachycardia, and tachypnea
  • Grey Turner sign (A): bluish discoloration of the flanks
  • Cullen’s sign (B): bluish discoloration around the umbilicus
  • Fox sign: discoloration below the inguinal ligament
  • Pleural effusion (left > right): dullness on percussion, decreased breath sounds

Related Pearl: Laboratory findings in acute pancreatitis

  • Elevated serum amylase and serum lipase
    • Serum amylase level rises immediately and peaks in few hours and returns to normal in 3–5 days
    • Serum amylase level lacks specificity.
    • Serum amylase levels do not correlate with the severity of pancreatitis.
    • Serum lipase is more specific, and it is more useful when the patient presents 24–48 hours later.
  • Hyperglycemia
  • Hypocalcemia, hypoalbuminemia
  • Leukocytosis
  • Elevated serum levels of hepatic enzymes like alanine aminotransferase (ALT).
  • Azotemia, due to prerenal acute renal failure in case of severe fluid loss

Related Pearl: X-Ray Findings in Acute Pancreatitis

Radiographic findings of acute pancreatitis are non-specific.

Sentinel loop sign: Generalized or local ileus, with isolated dilation of a segment of the gut (sentinel loop) consisting of jejunum, transverse colon, or duodenum adjacent to the pancreas

Colon cut-off sign: Functional spasm at the splenic flexure due to the extension of inflammation to phrenicocolic ligament via transverse mesocolon.

 

Renal halo sign: Edema around the kidney due to the involvement of paranephric fat resulting in:

  • Obliteration of psoas shadow
  • Localised ground-glass appearance

questions.text: Which of the following is the best imaging modality to diagnose neuroendocrine tumours (NETs)?
questions.solution:
Positron emission tomography (PET) is the best modality to diagnose Neuroendocrine tumors(NETs).

The initial imaging investigation is standard cross-sectional imaging with computed tomography (CT) or magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). In patients of suspected NETs, CTs of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis are done for staging, and consideration of an MRI of the liver or pancreas in cases where further definition is required.

PET scans with 111In (indium) labeled pentetreotide somatostatin and 68Ga (gallium) linked somatostatin analogues take advantage of the overexpression of somatostatin receptors commonly seen in NETs. These radiolabeled somatostatin analogues localized with PET scan are the best imaging modality for NETs.

questions.text: Eligible couple registers are maintained at which of the following centres?
questions.solution:

1 FHW in type A and 2 FHWs in type B along with 1 Male health worker(MHW) are essential to provide services at the sub-centre level.

questions.text: A 17-year-old woman with no comorbidities presents with numbness and paraesthesia of the fingers along with the characteristic finding as shown in the image below. She has no history of smoking or history of other illnesses. She mentions the episodes occur when she is under excess stress or during cold temperatures. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image along with the history of no previous illness in a young female is most likely of Raynaud's phenomenon.

Raynaud's phenomenon:

  • Episodic digital ischemia due to the vasospasm of digital arteries.
  • Cold exposure or emotional stress can trigger it.
  • The blanching/ischemic phase of the phenomenon with pallor/cyanosis is often accompanied by numbness and paraesthesia.
  • Capillaries and venules dilate and cyanosis results from the deoxygenated blood that is present in these vessels.
  • Color changes are usually well-demarcated and are confined to the fingers or toes.
  • In the rewarming phase, digital vasospasm resolves and blood flows into the dilated arterioles and capillaries increase dramatically causing reactive hyperemia which imparts bright red color to the digits.
  • Some may experience only pallor cyanosis while others experience both pallor and cyanosis.

Types of Raynaud's:
     1.Primary/idiopathic 

     2. Secondary associated with other diseases like: 

  • Collagen vascular diseases: scleroderma, systemic lupus erythematosus, rheumatoid arthritis, dermatomyositis, polymyositis
  • Arterial occlusive diseases: atherosclerosis of the extremities, thromboangiitis
    obliterans, acute arterial occlusion
  • Neurologic disorders: intervertebral disk disease, syringomyelia
  • Blood dyscrasias: cold agglutinins, cryoglobulinemia, cryofibrinogenemia,
  • Trauma: vibration injury, electric shock, cold injury, typing, piano playing
  • Drugs and toxins: ergot derivatives, methysergide, β-adrenergic receptor
    blockers

Management:

  • Reassurance, warm clothing, and avoiding cold exposures.
    exposure.
  • Reduce or abstain from smoking and reduce stress levels.
  • Drug treatments such as CCB's(nifedipine, amlodipine), alpha 1 blockers ( prazosin) are used only for advanced cases.
  • In secondary Raynauds's Phosphodiesterase type 5 inhibitors like sildenafil, tadalafil may improve symptoms.

Other options:

Buerger's disease or thromboangiitis obliterans involves occlusive disease of small- and medium-sized arteries, thrombophlebitis of the superficial or deep veins, and Raynaud’s syndrome. It occurs in male smokers, usually under the age of 30 years. It is an arterial occlusive disorder, so compression stockings will have no therapeutic effect.

Peripheral arterial disease (PAD) presents as intermittent claudication, which is pain that increases with walking and may sometimes present with rest pain. It is generally caused by atherosclerosis but may also be due to trauma. The initial investigation done is an ABPI. Physical exam findings include atrophied skin, pallor on raising leg (Buerger's test), nail changes, and decreased peripheral pulses.

questions.text: While doing an endoscopy, constriction is felt at the oesophageal junction at 25 cm from the incisor. This is due to?
questions.solution:
The arch of aorta and left bronchus crosses the esophagus at 25 cm from the upper incisor teeth.

Normally esophagus shows 3 constrictions at the following levels measured from upper incisors:

  • Junction of the esophagus with cricopharynx (15 cm from the incisor teeth)
  • Crossed by arch of aorta and left bronchus (25 cm from the incisor teeth)
  • It pierces the diaphragm (40 cm from the incisor teeth)

questions.text:
The most common cause of Cushing's disease in a 60-year-old male is ______

ACTH - Adrenocorticotropic hormone
questions.solution:
The most common cause of Cushing's disease in a 60-year-old male is pituitary microadenoma.

Cortisol production is increased by adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) released from the pituitary gland in the brain. Hypercortisolemia (cortisol overproduction) causes Cushing syndrome, most often when a pituitary adenoma (a benign tumor) produces an excess of ACTH, resulting in Cushing's disease. The increased ACTH causes increased cortisol production, about three times more than the normal level.

The illustration given below shows the clinical features of Cushing syndrome.

Administration of large doses of dexamethasone can be used to differentiate between ACTH-dependent and ACTH-independent Cushing’s syndrome.

The illustration given below shows the diagnostic algorithm to determine the cause of Cushing syndrome.

In normal physiologic states, the ACTH levels are higher in the early morning as compared to the rest of the day. However, they are not as high as those in Cushing's disease.

Related Pearl: Causes of Cushing's Syndrome

Iatrogenic (Most common cause)

  • Exogenous administration of glucocorticoids

Endogenous Causes

  • ACTH Dependent – (90 % of endogenous causes)
  • Cushing’s disease – ACTH-producing pituitary adenoma
  • Ectopic ACTH syndrome – Due to ACTH secretion by
  • Bronchial or pancreatic carcinoid tumors
  • Small-cell lung cancer
  • Medullary thyroid carcinoma
  • Pheochromocytoma
  • ACTH Independent – (10% )
  • Adrenocortical adenoma
  • Adrenocortical carcinoma

Rare causes

  • Macronodular adrenal hyperplasia
  • Primary pigmented nodular adrenal disease
  • McCune – Albright syndrome

Related Pearl: Screening/Confirmatory Test for Diagnosing Cushing's Syndrome

  • 24-h urinary free cortisol excretion increased above normal (3x)
  • Dexamethasone overnight test
    • Plasma cortisol >50 nmol/L at 8–9 a.m. after 1 mg dexamethasone at 11 p.m.
  • Midnight plasma cortisol >130 nmol/L
  • Midnight salivary cortisol >5 nmol/L
  • Low dose Dexamethasone test – Best initial test
    • Plasma cortisol >50 nmol/L after 0.5 mg dexamethasone q6h for 2 days

If a number of these tests are positive then a diagnosis of Cushing’s syndrome is confirmed.

questions.text: A 73 old male smoker with a past history of coronary artery disease presents with blackening of the toes. An image of the foot is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of an elderly smoker with past history of coronary artery disease and gangrene of the first three toes is likely to have atherosclerosis. 

Atherosclerosis is a chronic inflammatory disease in which there is a build-up of plaques inside arteries.  It is common after 50 years.These plaques are principally composed of lipids that induce an inflammatory reaction causing turbulent flow leading to atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease(ASCVD). This results in atheroma formation in arteries throughout the body hampering the blood flow and leading to ischemia. 

Risk factors include smoking, hypertension, diabetes, and elevated cholesterol. The infrarenal part of the abdominal aorta, coronary arteries, iliofemoral vessels, carotid bifurcation, and popliteal arteries are the common arteries involved. The presence of atherosclerotic disease in one part of the body suggests there could be blockade in other parts as well. 

Patients with chronic limb ischemia present with rest pain and tissue loss such as gangrene and ulceration. An ischemic ulcer is painful, pale, and cyanotic in appearance with absent pulsations. It may be associated with transient ischemic attacks, chest pain, eye problems, mesenteric ischemia, and altered renal function.

Doppler or angiogram can be done to identify the block. It is important to evaluate these patients for intercurrent cardiac disorders.

Management involves cessation of smoking and modification of other risk factors such as hypertension, diabetes, and hypercholesterolemia. High-intensity statins should be given irrespective of cholesterol levels in ASCVD. Other drugs that can be used include pentoxifylline, aspirin, clopidogrel, and cilostazol. Surgical options include thrombectomy, endarterectomy, bypass grafting, and amputations if the limb is gangrenous. 

Complications of atherosclerosis include

  • Narrowing of the arteries: Coronary, cerebral, renal, mesenteric, iliofemoral. > 70% narrowing (severe) causes reduced blood flow.
  • lschaemia, ulcerations, gangrene 
  • Embolism: From atheromatous plaques
  • Aneurysm formation: Mainly abdominal aorta and also in peripheral arteries

Option A: Buerger’s disease is a progressive nonatherosclerotic segmental inflammatory disease that most often affects small- and medium-sized arteries, veins, and nerves of the upper and lower extremities.

  • Typically presents in young male smokers, with symptoms beginning prior to age 40.
  • Patients initially present with the foot, leg, arm, or hand.
  • Claudication may progress to rest pain to calf claudication and eventually ischemic rest pain and ulcerations on the toes, feet, or fingers and even gangrene.

If the patient continues to smoke, the disease progresses into the collaterals, blocking them eventually, leading to severe ischemia which is called decompensatory peripheral vascular disease/ critical limb ischemia which presents as rest pain, ulceration, and gangrene.

Option C: Raynaud's disease usually occurs in females and affects bilateral upper limbs. Patients present with pallor/blanching (syncope), dusky cyanosis (asphyxia), and rubor/painful red de-engorgement (recovery). Peripheral pulses are normal.

Option D: Giant cell arteritis is characterized by giant cell infiltration of the arterial wall (giant cell arteritis) involving superficial temporal, facial, retinal, upper limb, coronary and vertebral arteries. Patients present with severe headaches, visual abnormalities, jaw claudication, and a tender superficial temporal artery.

Related Pearl: Ankle–brachial Pressure Index (ABPI)

The ankle-brachial Pressure Index (ABPI) is the ratio of systolic pressure at the ankle to that in the arm.

The numerator is the highest pressure in the dorsalis pedis, posterior tibial, or peroneal artery and the denominator is the highest brachial systolic pressure.

ABPI Reading Interpretation
>0.91 < 1.3 Normal
<0.9 Diagnostic of occlusive arterial disease in patients with symptoms of claudication or other signs of ischemia
0.5 to 0.9 Arterial obstruction often associated with claudication
<0.3 Critical limb ischemia (multilevel obstruction i.e any combination of iliac, femoral or tibial vessel disease and may be associated with non-healing ulcerations, ischemic rest pain, or pedal gangrene.
>1.4 Signifies poor compressibility of the arteries. Mostly due to calcification because of increased age, diabetes etc.

Note: A fall in the resting ABPI of more than 20% after exercise is indicative of arterial disease.

questions.text: A patient presented with itchy lesions as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image showing pruritic, purple, polygonal, papules are characteristic of lichen planus.

Lichen planus is a type of lichenoid disorder affecting the papillary dermis. It is a T-cell-mediated autoimmune disease against the basal keratinocytes. It is a chronic disease with a number of relapses and remissions.

The most common presentation of lichen planus is a well-defined area of purple-colored, itchy, flat-topped papules. This description is known as the characteristic "6 P"s of lichen planus: planar (flat-topped), purple, polygonal, pruritic, papules, and plaques.

Clinically, oral lichen planus can present as Wickham striae (image below), white papules, white plaque, erythema, erosion, or blisters. They may be symmetrical and bilateral. Buccal mucosa, dorsum of the tongue, and gingivae are commonly affected. Early diagnosis and management play an important role in the prevention of progression to malignancy.

Complications of lichen planus include:

  • Hair: Patches of cicatricial scarring alopecia
  • Nails: Various nail changes are seen associated with lichen planus. 
    • Dorsal Nail Pterygium: The most specific nail change in lichen planus where the fusion of dorsal nail fold and nail bed leads to pterygium formation.
    • Thinning of the nail plate: The most common nail change is the exaggeration of longitudinal lines and linear depressions.
    • Pup-tent sign: Elevation of the nail in the shape of a tent
    • Trachonychia: All 20 nails of hands and feet undergo dystrophy
    • Subungual hyperkeratosis and onycholysis
    • Longitudinal melanonychia in lichen planus of the nail bed
    • Permanent destruction of several toenails with ulceration of soles (rare variant)
  • Mucous membranes: Squamous cell carcinoma may occur on the lip, buccal mucosa, or gum margin.

Other options: 

Option A: Scabies is an ectoparasitic infestation caused in humans by the Sarcoptes scabiei var. Hominis. The characteristic symptoms of a scabies infection include intense itching and superficial burrows usually in the area of the finger webs, feet, ventral wrists, elbows, back, breasts, buttocks, and external genitals. Burrows presents as slightly raised brownish linear or s-shaped tracks in the skin created by the excavation of the adult mite in the epidermis as depicted below.


Option C: Psoriasis is characterized by erythematous plaques covered with silver scales. It generally affects the extensor surfaces.


Option D: Warts are verrucous growths that may appear discrete or coalesce to form large cauliflower-like growths (as shown in the image below). Human papillomaviruses are implicated in causing this condition.

questions.text: Postmortem examination of a dead body reveals contraction of the hands with absent primary relaxation. What is this suggestive of?
questions.solution:
Postmortem examination of a dead body with contraction of the hands and the absence of primary relaxation is suggestive of cadaveric spasm.

Cadaveric spasm/Instantaneous rigor is a phenomenon where a group of muscles that are in a state of contraction at the time of death remains contracted after death till molecular death occurs. It occurs immediately after death. There is no stage of primary relaxation. 

It is most commonly seen in voluntary muscles, especially hands. It is seen in cases of death associated with emotional disturbances like cases of excitement, fear, severe pain, and exhaustion at the time of death. It is an antemortem phenomenon and it indicates the manner of death and not the time since death.

 

Other options: 

Option A: Rigor mortis (cadaveric rigidity or death stiffening) refers to the stiffening and shortening of muscles following death. The order of appearance of rigor mortis: Myocardium of the heart is affected first. Nysten's rule describes the sequential onset of rigor mortis in the various muscle groups. It starts in the eyelids, neck, lower jaw, and muscles of the face and progresses downwards to involve the muscles of the chest, upper limbs, abdomen, and lower limbs. The fingers and toes are affected last.

Option B: Livor mortis/Postmortem hypostasis/Postmortem staining/Postmortem lividity/Suggilation refers to bluish-purple or reddish-purple discoloration of the superficial layers of the dermis. It is an early postmortem change that occurs due to the stagnation of blood in the vessels of the dependent parts due to the effect of gravity. 

Option D: Algor mortis/postmortem cooling is one of the early changes occurring after death. The body loses heat mainly by conduction and convection after death. 

Related Pearl: Difference between Cadaveric Rigidity (Rigor mortis) and Cadaveric Spasm (Instantaneous rigor)

Trait Cadaveric rigidity Cadaveric spasm
Production Freezing and exposure to temperature above 650C will produce rigor Cannot be produced by any method after death
Mechanism Reduction of ATP Not clear
Predisposing factors Nil Sudden death, excitement, fear etc
Time of onset 1 – 2 hours after death Instantaneous
Muscles involved All muscles – both voluntary and involuntary Single group of voluntary muscles
Muscle stiffening Not marked: can be overcome by moderate force Marked: Great force is required to overcome
Molecular death Occurs Doesn't occur
Body heat Cold Warm
Electrical stimuli Muscles do not respond Muscles respond
Muscular reaction Acidic Alkaline
Medicolegal importance Indicates time of death Indicates manner of death

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding single exposure point source epidemic ?

choices.text: Has more than one incubation period
Occurs due to prolonged exposure to an agent

questions.solution:
The true statement regarding single exposure point source epidemic is that it is explosive in nature.

Single exposure point source epidemics occur due to a brief and simultaneous exposure to an agent. It has the following characteristics:

  • It has a single peak with no secondary waves.
  • The epidemic tends to be explosive, there is a clustering of cases within a narrow interval of time.
  • The epidemic curve has a sharp, rapid rise and fall as all cases are clustered within one incubation period.

The exposure can be an infectious agent or contaminant in the environment (air, water, food, soil) by industrial chemicals or pollutants. Examples are food poisoning and the Bhopal gas tragedy in India due to methyl isocyanate.

The following graph represents single exposure point source epidemic.

Related Pearl: Epidemics and its Types

Epidemics and its Types

An epidemic is an occurrence in a community or region of cases of an illness that is clearly in excess of normal expectancy.

Types

Common source epidemics

  • Single exposure or 'point source' epidemics
  • Multiple or continuous exposure epidemics

Propagated epidemics

  • Person to person
  • Arthropod vector
  • Animal reservoir

Slow or modern epidemics

  • Non-communicable diseases

questions.text: In the sagittal section of the brain given below the colored area represents the paracentral lobule. Which of the following structures are affected in a lesion to this area?
questions.solution:
The area marked in the picture is the paracentral lobule. The structures affected in a lesion to this area are the perineum and leg.

The paracentral lobule is supplied by the A2 segment of the anterior cerebral artery. Lesions in the paracentral lobule lead to :

  • Weakness and loss of sensation in the contralateral lower limb (paraplegia).
  • Urinary incontinence
  • Fecal incontinence

questions.text: A 20-year-old patient presents with painful swelling in the middle finger around the proximal phalanx. An X-ray was done and it is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical vignette and X-ray findings point toward the diagnosis of enchondroma.

Enchondromas are benign tumors consisting of a lobulated mass of cartilage encapsulated by fibrous tissue. It is more commonly seen in 20 to 30 years of age. Small bones of hands and feet are commonly involved followed by the femur and humerus. 

The patient usually presents with long-standing swelling from one or more phalanges or metacarpals, without much pain. Diagnosis can be done by X-ray, which can show expanding lytic lesions, occasionally, a biopsy will be required if the diagnosis is unclear. Enchondromas of long bones may undergo malignant transformation into chondrosarcoma.

Treatment is removal by curettage and it is indicated if there is pain or pathological fracture.

Other options:

Option A: Osteosarcoma is the most common primary malignancy of bone that produces osteoid matrix or mineralized bone.  X-ray shows periosteal reaction and it may take the form of a Codman's triangle or it may have a sunburst (sunray) appearance as shown below.

Option B: Ewing's sarcoma is the second most common primary malignancy of bone after osteosarcoma. Onion-peel appearance due to deposition of periosteal reaction in layers is seen on radiology (as shown below) and Homer-Wright rosettes, which are round groupings of cells with a central fibrillary core may be seen histologically.

Option C: Osteoclastoma is also called a giant cell tumour because multinucleated osteoclast-type giant cells are present on histology. The image below shows an X-ray of a giant cell tumor showing an eccentrically located solitary lytic lesion in the epiphysis and the typical soap bubble appearance

questions.text: Following the recovery of a beheaded skull bone by the police, the relatives of a missing person want to confirm his identity. Which of the following techniques can be used to figure out a person's identity using the beheaded skull bone and photograph of the person?
questions.solution:
The technique used to figure out a person's identity using the beheaded skull bone and photograph of the person is superimposition.

The superimposition technique is applied to the skull to determine whether it belongs to the person in the photograph. The following points can be used for comparisons such as the eyes, nasion, prosthion, zygomas, lower border of the nose, supraorbital ridges, lower border of the zygomas, angle of the jaw, external auditory meatus, teeth and the lower border of the upper jaw.

Other options:

Option B: Anthropometry is based on the principle that the skeletal dimensions do not change after the age of 21 years and the variation in the size of the different parts to one another. Descriptive data such as the color of the hair, eyes, complexion, and body marks are recorded. Body measurements are estimated such as height, anteroposterior diameter of head and trunk, the span of outstretched arms, the length of the left middle finger, left little finger, left forearm, left foot, length, and breadth of right ear, and color of left iris from the photographs. 

Option C: DNA fingerprinting for forensic analysis is done to detect DNA from small amounts of samples from the crime scene. DNA fingerprinting uses restriction fragment length polymorphism (RFLPs) or Polymerase chain reaction(PCR) to identify a person's unique pattern of DNA. 

Option D: Cheiloscopy is also known as lip printing. Here, the fissures and grooves on the lip characteristic of a person are examined.

questions.text: Identify the segment marked in the image below.
questions.solution:
The liver segment highlighted in green in this CT section is segment V. The section of the CT given is taken below the portal vein as the cross-section of the portal vein before its bifurcation can be viewed.

A horizontal plane known as the portal plane divides the liver where the portal vein bifurcates and becomes horizontal. This divides each section of the liver into superior and inferior segments: 

  • Left lateral section: segment II above and segment III below the portal plane
  • Left medial section: segment IVa above and segment IVb below the portal plane
  • Right anterior (or medial) section: segment VIII above and segment V below the portal plane
  • Right posterior (or lateral) section: segment VII above and segment VI below the portal plane

 Shown below is a section from below the portal plane.

Couinaud classification is the commonly used classification of the liver. It divides the liver is divided into eight segments. It is based on the distribution of portal venous branches in the liver parenchyma. Each segment has its own vascular supply, biliary drainage, and lymphatic drainage.

The Couinaud's liver segments are as follows:

Related Pearl: Couinaud's Liver Segments

The Couinaud classification is currently the most widely used system to describe functional liver anatomy.

  • Based on the distribution of hepatic portal venous branches in the parenchyma
  • Each segment has its own dual vascular inflow, biliary drainage and lymphatic drainage

Segment I corresponds to the gross anatomical caudate lobe and is considered as posterior segment.

Other segments:

Liver sections

Couinaud's Segments

Right Posterior sections

Segments VI, VII

questions.text: Which type of hysterectomy is done in a case of carcinoma cervix stage I B?
questions.solution:
Type 3 hysterectomy/Radical hysterectomy is the treatment of choice in carcinoma cervix stage 1 B.

Stage IB lesions are defined as those with the deepest invasion ≥ 5mm yet still confined to the cervix. The stage is subcategorized either as IB1 if tumors measure <2cm or as IB2 if they measure 2cm to <4cm or as IB3 if the invasion is ≥4cm in greatest dimension.

Radical hysterectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy for stage IB are usually chosen for premenopausal women who wish to preserve ovarian function. Oophorectomy is avoided in younger women who wish to preserve fertility.

questions.text: A 26-year-old male with a history of respiratory tract infection 4 weeks ago is unable to stand or walk for the past 2 weeks and the weakness is progressive, ascending, and symmetrical in nature. The lower limbs were involved before and gradually the upper limbs were also affected. On examination you note areflexia. Pain and proprioception are preserved. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis based on the given clinical scenario is Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS).

GBS is an acute, fulminant polyradiculoneuropathy that is autoimmune in nature. GBS is caused when immune response/antibodies against external antigens like infections, vaccines, etc target similar proteins present in the person's nervous tissue.

Clinical features are rapidly evolving areflexic motor paralysis with or without sensory disturbance. Respiration is compromised when it involves respiratory muscles. In such cases, ventilatory support is needed.

High-dose intravenous immune globulin (IVIg) or plasmapheresis are equally effective for typical GBS. IVIg is the initial therapy chosen because of its ease of administration and good safety record.

Other options:

Option B: Myasthenia gravis is a neuromuscular disorder due to autoimmune damage to the acetylcholine receptors. It is characterized by weakness and muscle fatiguability. Weakness increases with usage. Ocular features like ptosis and diplopia can be seen. Proximal limb weakness is also present. 

Option C: Polymyositis is one of the inflammatory myopathies characterized by symmetric and proximal muscle weakness. This weakness usually worsens over several weeks to months. It is more common in women. Most patients improve with immunotherapies, but they require lifelong treatment.

Option D: Multiple sclerosis (MS) is an autoimmune demyelinating disease characterized by multiple episodes of neurological deficits due to patchy white matter lesions that involve various sites of the brain. It is caused by an autoimmune response directed against components of the myelin sheath. The demyelinated plaques are the hallmark of MS

 

Related Pearl: Mechanism of Immunopathogenesis of Guillain-Barre Syndrome

The following sequence of events, takes into consideration, the development of Guillain-Barre syndrome (GBS) associated with Campylobacter jejuni infection.

  1. B cells recognize glycoconjugates on jejuni (Cj) that cross-react with ganglioside present on Schwann cell surface and subjacent peripheral nerve myelin.
  2. Most of the B cells are activated via a partially T cell–dependent route and secrete primarily IgG autoantibodies. Some B cells, activated via a T cell–independent mechanism, secrete primarily IgM
  3. The activated B cells escape from Peyer’s patches into regional lymph nodes.
  4. Activated T cells also function to assist in the opening of the blood-nerve barrier, facilitating penetration of pathogenic autoantibodies.
  5. The earliest changes in myelin consist of edema between myelin lamellae and vesicular disruption of the outermost myelin layers.
  6. These effects are associated with activation of the C5b-C9 membrane attack complex and mediated by calcium entry; it is possible that the macrophage cytokine tumor necrosis factor (TNF) also participates in myelin damage.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about the following image?

choices.text: Staph. aureus is the causative organism

questions.solution:
The image above indicates that the patient has Fournier's gangrene. It is caused due to mixed infection of aerobic and anaerobic bacteria.

Concurrent illnesses like diabetes mellitus and alcoholism, predispose patients to Fournier's gangrene. 

The sequence of events is as follows: A mixed infection of the aerobic and anaerobic bacteria → fulminating inflammation of subcutaneous tissue → obliterative arteritis of the arterioles that supply the scrotal skin → gangrene

The testes are usually not affected due to their intraabdominal-origin blood supply.

It is a surgical emergency. In Fournier's gangrene, despite the best therapy, mortality rates are high at 50%.

questions.text: Which of the following finding is shown in the given image?
questions.solution:
The given image shows Linea nigra.

Linea nigra is a brownish-black pigmented area that stretches from the xiphisternum to the symphysis pubis in the midline. The pigmentary changes may be due to melanocyte-stimulating hormone from the anterior pituitary. The pigmentation disappears after delivery. Similar changes are observed in women taking oral contraceptives may be due to estrogen and progesterone may be related to it as. 

Other options:

Option A: Striae gravidarum is slightly depressed linear marks with varying length and breadth found in pregnancy. They are predominantly found in the abdominal wall below the umbilicus. They appear pinkish in color. They can sometimes be found over the thighs and breasts. These stretch marks represent the scar tissues in the deeper layer of the cutis. 

Option B: Chloasma gravidarum also called pregnancy mask is an extreme form of pigmentation around the cheek, forehead, and around eyes. It may be patchy or diffuse. It disappears spontaneously after delivery.

Option C: Initially, striae gravidarum are pinkish but after the delivery, the scar tissues contract and obliterate the capillaries and appear glistening white. They are called the linea alba.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient presents with hematuria and a neovascular mass in bilateral  kidney on a CT scan, as shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The CT image showing renal lesions that has hypo-attenuating components consistent with macroscopic fat is highly suggestive of renal angiomyolipoma.

Angiomyolipomas are benign tumors that occur sporadically or in association with tuberous sclerosis. The mean age of presentation is 43 years and there is a female predilection. It can present as spontaneous retroperitoneal hemorrhage, especially with larger tumors. The patient can present with flank pain, palpable mass, hematuria, urinary tract infections, hypertension, or renal failure. 

Imaging in renal angiomyolipoma: Demonstration of macroscopic fat is the main part of making a diagnosis. USG may show hyperechoic lesions in the cortex with posterior acoustic shadowing. In patients with tuberous sclerosis, the entire kidney is affected and produces an echogenic appearance with loss of normal corticomedullary junction.

CT findings:

  • Cortical lesions that demonstrate macroscopic fat (less than -20 HU)
  • Absence of ossification or calcification
  • The presence of macroscopic fat is strongly suggestive of this condition, but not pathognomonic as RCC may rarely demonstrate macroscopic fat.
  • Approximately 5% may be fat-poor.

MRI: It is an excellent tool to demonstrate intramural fat components. Two sequences are used:

  • Fat-saturated techniques 
  • Phase-in and phase-out imaging that shows India ink artifacts at the junction between fat and non-fat components.

Digital subtraction angiography: They are hypervascular lesions showing a 'sunburst appearance' in the arterial phase and an 'onion peel appearance' in the venous phase.

They usually do not require any intervention. mTOR inhibitors like everolimus can be used to decrease the size of the lesion.

Other options:

Renal cell carcinoma (RCC): It is the most common malignant tumor of the kidney. It usually occurs in the age group 50-70 years and macroscopic hematuria is seen in about 60% of the cases. It is a differential for angiomyolipoma but it is important to note that macroscopic fat is almost always associated with ossification or calcification.

Renal oncocytoma: They are relatively benign in nature and usually present in the 6th to 7th decade. An important point regarding this tumor is its similarity with RCC and hence it is very difficult to differentiate between them preoperatively. A sharp central stellate scar may be seen in one-third of the cases. But RCC may also show this stellate scar appearance in some cases.

Renal cyst: It is a broader term that includes the cystic lesions of the kidney. They can be simple cysts that are benign. Complex or complicated cystic lesions needs evaluation and can be malignant. Bosniak classification of renal cysts is given above.

questions.text: A woman presents with a history of headaches for the past 9 months that worsen in a recumbent position and improves as the day progresses. She also gives a history of taking oral contraceptives. Fundal examination shows papilledema. There are no focal neurological deficits. What is the probable cause of her headaches?
questions.solution:
This female patient with recurring headaches, that have a positional and diurnal variation, takes oral contraceptive pills and raised intracranial pressures (as evidenced by papilledema) likely has pseudotumor cerebri (idiopathic intracranial hypertension)

Risk factors include:

  • Female sex
  • Obesity
  • Nalidixic acid
  • Tetracycline
  • Vitamin A
  • Oral contraceptives
  • Use of or withdrawal from corticosteroids

Evaluation requires brain imaging, with MRI being the most common initial study. Elevated CSF opening pressure on lumbar puncture is the hallmark of idiopathic intracranial hypertension (IIH) even in the absence of fundal changes.

The initial treatment is with acetazolamide. Topiramate may also be used. Weight loss and stopping the medications that are causing IIH must also be done.

questions.text: A baby presents to the OPD and the findings are shown in the image below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows a capillary hemangioma involving the left upper lid and periocular area. A capillary haemangioma is the most common tumor of the orbit and periorbital area in childhood.

Hemangioma is a benign tumor caused by the abnormal growth of blood vessels. Types of hemangioma are:

  1. Capillary hemangioma (most common)
  2. Juvenile/ strawberry hemangioma
  3. Cavernous hemangioma
  4. Pyogenic hemangioma

Capillary hemangioma may present as small isolated lesions or large masses that can cause visual impairment (due to mechanical ptosis and the resulting sensory deprivation amblyopia), systemic effects (severe thrombocytopenia), or exist as part of PHACE syndrome (Posterior fossa anomalies, Hemangioma, Arterial lesions, Cardiac abnormalities, Eye or Endocrine abnormalities)

30% of lesions resolve by the age of 3 years and about 75% by the age of 7. On histology, they show thin-walled capillaries with scant stroma as shown below.

Indications for treatment are:

  1. Visual (amblyopia, astigmatism, occlusion, strabismus)
  2. Cosmesis
  3. Optic nerve compression
  4. Exposure keratopathy

Capillary hemangioma regresses spontaneously very often. Treatment options include:

  • Beta-blockers- oral propranolol, topical timolol.
  • Steroids- intralesional triamcinolone or betamethasone, topical clobetasol, systemic steroids.
  • Interferon alfa-2a and vincristine- for steroid-resistant sight-threatening lesions
  • Local resection with cutting cautery or carbon dioxide laser.

Option A: Port wine stain is a congenital low-flow vascular malformation that may occur anywhere in the body and does not fade away with time. Visually they appear as partially or completely blanchable, pink to red or reddish brown patches, mostly on the head and neck. This lesion is associated with syndromes such as Sturge-Weber syndrome and occult spinal dysraphism.

Option B: Cavernous hemangiomas are large, cavernous blood-filled vascular spaces separated by connective tissue stroma. They are infiltrative and involve deep structures. They do not regress spontaneously. Von Hippel–Lindau disease is associated with cavernous hemangiomas. These vascular lesions are commonly found in the cerebellum, brain stem, retina, pancreas, and liver.

Option C: Salmon patches or naevus simplex (as shown below) are small, ill-defined, pink-colored macules commonly seen over the glabella, eyelids, upper lip, and nuchal area, which develop due to vascular ectasia. It is a common vascular birthmark and disappears within 1 year.

Related Pearl: Classification of Vascular Tumors and Tumor-like Conditions

Benign Neoplasms, Developmental and Acquired Conditions
  • Hemangioma
    • Capillary hemangioma
    • Cavernous hemangioma
  • Pyogenic granuloma
  • Lymphangioma
    • Simple/capillary lymphangioma
    • Cavernous lymphangioma (cystic hygroma)
  • Glomus tumor
  • Vascular ectasias
    • Nevus flammeus
    • Spider telangiectasia (arterial spider)
    • Hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasis (Osler–Weber–Rendu disease)
  • Reactive vascular proliferation
    • Bacillary angiomatosis

  • Hemangiopericytoma

questions.text: A patient was brought to the emergency department following a road traffic accident. Skin grafting was done wherein the graft was taken from the same person. Which type of graft is it?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a split skin graft obtained from the same person. This type of graft is autograft.

Skin grafting is the transfer of skin from the donor area to the recipient area. The most preferable donor site is the buttocks in cosmetically sensitive individuals and children. The most commonly used donor site is the thigh. 

Autograft is the transfer of tissue from one location to another location on the same patient.

Skin grafts can be broadly divided into two categories:

Split-thickness skin graft (Thiersch graft): Partial-thickness skin grafts consisting of the epidermis and a portion of the dermis are called split-thickness skin grafts. Less dermis in the split-thickness skin graft translates into less primary contraction (the degree to which a graft shrinks in surface area after harvesting and before grafting) and more secondary contraction (the degree to which a graft shrinks during healing).

Full-thickness skin grafts (Wolfe graft) include the epidermis and entire dermis, with portions of the sweat glands, sebaceous glands, and hair follicles. More dermis in the full-thickness skin graft translates into more primary contraction and less secondary contraction.

Other options:

Option B:Xenograft is tissue transfer from a donor of one species to a recipient of another species. It is also known as heterograft.

Option C: Allograft is the tissue transfer between two genetically different members, e.g. kidney transplantation (human to human). It is also known as homograft.

Option D: Isograft is the tissue transfer between two genetically identical individuals, i.e. between two identical twins.

Related Pearl: Skin graft : phases of uptake of the graft

The take of skin graft occurs in three phases:

  1. Imbibition (Plasmatic circulation): during the first 48 hours, the graft is nourished with plasma exudate from host bed capillaries.
  2. Inosculation, in which cut vessels from the host bed line up with the cut ends of the vessels of the graft to form anastomoses
  3. Neovascularization, in which blood vessels grow from the recipient bed into the graft

Sensibility returns to the graft over time, with reinnervation beginning at approximately 4 to 5 weeks and being completed by 12 to 24 months. Pain returns first, with light touch and temperature returning later.

Note: some books give that the 3 phases are imbibition,revascularisation (inosculation+neovascularisation) and organisation (fibrin layer holds the graft in place and this is replaced by postgraft day 7 with fibroblasts)

questions.text: A patient presented with a fever for 11 days with neck rigidity. A lumbar puncture was done and it showed lymphocytes predominantly, sugar- 50mg, and protein- 3000mg/dl. Gram-staining was negative. Chest X-ray of the patient shows upper lobe involvement with hilar lymph node enlargement. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis based on the given clinical scenario and CSF findings is tuberculous meningitis.

Tuberculous meningitis caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis is caused by the formation of tubercles in the brain parenchyma. This happens during the hematogenous spread of the bacilli during primary infection. It can also be due to the rupture of a subependymal tubercle into the subarachnoid space.

Tuberculous meningitis presents as a subacute infection and has a longer course than bacterial meningitis. Ocular nerve palsy is a common association as there is marked meningeal involvement at the base of the brain. The patient can also develop hydrocephalus.

The CSF sample shows pellicle or cobweb-like clots. Acid-fast bacilli can be best isolated from these. There is usually lymphocytic leukocytosis, low glucose concentration, and elevated proteins. CSF culture remains the gold standard for diagnosis. 

The clinical triad of fever, headache, and nuchal rigidity is common to all types of meningitis. Nuchal rigidity is the resistance of the neck to passive flexion and is pathognomonic of meningeal irritation. Kernig's and Brudzinski's signs are other features of meningeal irritation. Raised intracranial pressure (ICP) is a complication that presents as papilledema, disorientation, or dilated poorly reactive pupils.

questions.text: A 32-year-old patient who is a chronic tobacco chewer presents with a whitish lesion on the gingivobuccal sulcus for 7 months. What is the next best step in the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in the given scenario is leukoplakia. The next best step in management is local excision and biopsy.

Leukoplakia is a premalignant condition of the oral cavity characterized by well-circumscribed whitish patches or plaques that involve large areas of the oral mucosa. Smoking, chronic candidiasis, tobacco chewing, alcohol, spices, and sepsis are some of the risk factors.

They appear as small, well-circumscribed lesions and can extensively involve a large area of the oral mucosa.

Variants of leukoplakia are:

  • Homogenous: Most common type; presents has uniform white patches
  • Nodular: Fine nodules on the surface, has more malignant potential
  • Speckled leukoplakia is whitish lesions on an erythematous base. They have the highest risk of malignant transformation. 
  • Proliferative verrucous leukoplakia is rare and has a high risk for malignant transformation.

Hairy leukoplakia is more commonly seen in AIDS patients, characterized by severe hyperkeratosis and acanthosis. The most common cause of this condition is Epstein-Barr virus.

Leukoplakia in the elderly and of long duration has more risk of turning into malignancy. So an excisional biopsy confirms the diagnosis and also helps to rule out carcinoma. Management includes smoking cessation and reduction in alcohol consumption.

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct sequence of vaginal discharge during puerperium?
questions.solution:
The correct sequence of vaginal discharge during puerperium- Lochia rubra>Lochia serosa>Lochia alba.

Lochia is the vaginal discharge for the first fortnight during puerperium that originates from the uterine body, cervix, and vagina.

Depending upon the variation of the color of the discharge, it is named:

(1) Lochia rubra- Seen in 1–4 days after delivery. The color of the discharge is red. It consists of blood, shreds of fetal membranes and decidua, vernix caseosa, lanugo, and meconium.

(2) Lochia serosa- Seen during 5-9 days. The color is yellowish or pink or pale brownish. It consists mainly of leukocytes, wound exudate, mucus from the cervix, and micro-organisms (anaerobic streptococci and staphylococci). The presence of bacteria is not pathognomonic unless associated with clinical signs of sepsis.

(3) Lochia alba- Seen during 10–15 days. The color of the discharge is pale white. Lochia alba contains plenty of decidual cells, leukocytes, mucus, cholesterin crystals, fatty and granular epithelial cells, and microorganisms.

questions.text: A patient presents with complaints of sudden onset headache, palpitation, and profuse sweating. The patient has had multiple similar episodes in the past. During these episodes, the patient's blood pressure is elevated. A 24-hour urinary metanephrine is elevated. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this patient is pheochromocytoma.

Pheochromocytoma is a rare tumor of the sympathetic system arising from the adrenal medulla. Patients commonly present with a classical triad of palpitation, headache, and profuse sweating. Patients also present with hypertension and cardiac arrhythmias. These symptoms are due to an excess of catecholamines secreted by the tumor.

Other options:

Option A: Addison's disease is a primary adrenal insufficiency in which the adrenal is unable to secrete adequate amounts of cortisol (glucocorticoid), and aldosterone (mineralocorticoid). The features are fatigue, weight loss, anorexia, low blood pressure, postural hypotension, hypoglycemia, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, salt craving, hyponatremia, and hyperkalemia.

Option B: Renal artery stenosis is a relatively common finding in older patients with chronic essential hypertension. However, it is clinically significant (i.e. renovascular hypertension) only if the stenosis is greater than 75% in both renal arteries or 50% stenosis with post-stenotic dilatation.

There are two major causes of bilateral renal artery stenosis:

  • Atherosclerosis (most common) - It affects patients over the age of 45 years.
  • Fibromuscular dysplasia - Most often affects women under the age of 50 years.

Option D: Hyperthyroidism presents with clinical features that include heat intolerance and sweating, tachycardia, and palpitations, weight loss with increased appetite, diarrhea, and oligomenorrhea. Clinical findings include exophthalmos, tremors, and myopathy.

 

 
 

Related Pearl: Pheochromocytoma

Features:

  • When pheochromocytoma is associated with the MEN syndrome it is rarely malignant.
  • Phaeochromocytomas are greyish-pink on the cut surface and are usually highly vascularised.
  • Zellbalen cells and nuclei with salt and pepper chromatin are seen.

Factors indicating more chances of malignancy:

  • An increased PASS (phaeochromocytoma of the adrenal gland scale score)
  • High number of Ki-67-positive cells
  • Vascular invasion or a breached capsule

Diagnosis:

  • Urinary catecholamine and VMA level assay are most sensitive screening test.
  • MRI is the IOC.
  • Biopsy and CT Contrast scan are contraindicated in order to avoid Hypertensive crisis.

Treatment:

  • Adrenalectomy is preferred TOC.
  • Size<5 cm -  Laparoscopic adrenalectomy
  • Preop Alpha blockers should be given
  • Mitotane should be started as adjuvant or palliative treatment

 

Related Pearl: Clinical features of Pheochromocytoma (By frequency of occurrence)

  • Clinical triad:
    • Headaches – M/C symptom
    • Profuse sweating
    • Palpitations and tachycardia
  • Hypertension, sustained or paroxysmal – M/C Sign
  • Anxiety and panic attacks
  • Weight loss
  • Polyuria and polydipsia
  • Constipation
  • Orthostatic hypotension
  • Dilated cardiomyopathy
  • Erythrocytosis
  • Elevated blood sugar
  • Hypercalcemia
